questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is sent to the hospital from a nursing home after 2 days of fever, confusion, and lethargy. The patient has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. Her temperature is 38.8 C (102 F), blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 116/min. She has mild suprapubic and right costo-vertebral angle tenderness. Her leukocyte count is 18,000/mms, and urinalysis is consistent with acute cystitis. A femoral venous access is planned for administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics. The femoral artery pulsation is palpable immediately below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following describes the optimal cannulation site for the femoral vein?

choices.text: Immediately lateral to the femoral artery
Immediately medial to the femoral artery
Midway between the iliac crest and the femoral artery
Superior and medial to the pubic tubercle

questions.solution:
Femoral vein catheter placement is usually done in patients with unavailable preferred access sites (eg subclavian, jugular vein) or those at increased risk of complications (eg, emergency access, uncooperative patient). The femoral vein is the major deep vein of the lower extremity and passes through the femoral triangle beneath the inguinal ligament before entering the pelvis as the external iliac vein. The femoral triangle is a sub-fascial space in the upper thigh that is bordered by the inguinal ligament (superiorly), adductor longus muscle (medially), and sartorius muscle (laterally). Within the femoral triangle lies (lateral to medial) the femoral nerve, femoral artery, femoral vein, and deep inguinal nodes/lymphatic vessels. The femoral artery is located at the mid-inguinal point (midway between the pubic symphysis and anterior superior iliac spine), and the femoral vein lies immediately medial to the artery (Option B). Cannulation of the femoral vein should occur approximately 1 cm below the inguinal ligament and 0.5-1.0 cm medial to the femoral artery pulsation

(Options C and D). Option A - The femoral nerve is approximately 1 cm lateral to the femoral artery pulsation and could be damaged by needle insertion at this site.

Educational objective-

The femoral triangle (lateral to medial) consists of the femoral nerve, femoral artery, femoral vein, and deep inguinal nodes/lymphatic vessels. Cannulation of the femoral vein should occur approximately I cm below the inguinal ligament and just medial to the femoral artery pulsation.

questions.text: A 2 day old neonate born to a 30 year old  female develops persistent bilious vomiting. Laparotomy performed after initial work up reveals that the cecum is fixed to the right upper abdominal quadrant. Which of the following embryologic processes most likely failed in this patient?

choices.text: Fusion of the ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds
Hindgut descent along the inferior mesenteric artery
Midgut rotation around the superior mesenteric artery

questions.solution:
Midgut rotation around the superior mesenteric artery

Solution:

Lateral and cephalic flexion of an embryo results in formation of the primitive gut tube, a precursor of the Gl tract. It divides into foregut, midgut, and hindgut. The blood supply of the adult intestine reflects its embryologic source.
 

  • The foregut gives rise to the esophagus, stomach, liver, gallbladder, pancreas, and upper duodenum. These organs are supplied by the celiac trunk.
  • The midgut derivatives are supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). They include the lower duodenum, small intestine, ascending colon, and proximal 2/3 of the transverse colon.
  • The distal third of the transverse colon, descending, and sigmoid colon are derived from hindgut. They are supplied by inferior mesenteric artery (IMA)
  • The midgut herniates through the umbilical ring at the 6' week of embryonic development to allow the rapid growth of the intestine and liver despite the slower growth of the abdominal cavity. The midgut returns to the abdominal cavity at the 10' week of fetal life, simultaneously completing a 270-degree tum counterclockwise around the SMA. This rotation allows for the proper placement and fixation of the intestine in the abdominal cavity.
    If this process is abnormal, intestinal mal-rotation occurs. In this condition, the cecum is found in the right upper quadrant, fixed with fibrous bands (Ladd's bands) to the second portion of the duodenum. The entire midgut is fixed to the superior mesenteric artery. Intestinal obstruction usually occurs due to adhesive bands compressing the duodenum. Obstruction manifests with bilious vomiting during the first days of life. Twisting of the intestine around the SMA can cause impaired perfusion and midgut volvulus with intestinal gangrene and perforation as possible complications.

Option A - Failure of ventral and dorsal pancreatic buds to fuse during the 8' week of embryonic life results in pancreas divisum. This condition is usually asymptomatic and is an incidental finding on imaging study or autopsy.

Option B - The omphalomesenteric duct connects the lumen of the midgut with yolk sac. Complete failure to obliterate causes vitelline fistula, a small connection between ileum and the outside of the body at umbilicus. Partial failure leads to formation of Meckel diverticulum.

Option C - Hindgut descent along the inferior mesenteric artery occurs after the midgut returns to the abdominal cavity. As the intestine grows, the ascending and descending loops of the colon are pressed against the posterior wall of the abdominal cavity and are fixed in this position.

Educational objective:

Abnormal rotation and fixation of the midgut early during fetal lif-e results in intestinal mal-rotation. Two main manifestations of this condition are intestinal obstruction (due to compression by the adhesive bands) and midgut volvulus (intestinal ischemia due to around the blood vessels).

questions.text: A 45 year old female, went for a checkup, when she noticed several lumps in her anterior neck region. She had these lumps over the period of three years. Full physical examination was done. Malignancy was suspected on fine needle aspiration. Thyroidectomy was proposed. On the operating table, while ligating superior thyroid artery , the surgeon accidentally severs a nearby nerve. Which muscle will be denervated, as a result ?
questions.solution:
Blood supply for thyroid and parathyroid is provided by external carotid artery via superior thyroid artery and by inferior thyroid artery a branch of thyrocervical trunk. The superior thyroid artery , the superior thyroid vein and the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve course together in a neurovascular triad that originates superior to the thyroid gland and lateral to the thyroid cartilage. The external branch of superior laryngeal nerve is at the risk of injury during thyroidectomy because this nerve courses just deep to the superior thyroid artery. This nerve innervates cricothyroid muscle only. The recurrent laryngeal nerves innervates the remaining laryngeal muscles which also provide sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.

Options A,B, & C :Recurrent laryngeal nerve innervates these muscles.

Learning objective

Due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery and vein , the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is at risk of injury during thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old came to OPD with pain in the right ear. He is a swimming coach and spends most of his time in the swimming pool. Irritation to which of the following structure causes fainting while inserting a speculum into the external auditory meatus, when the patient has an external ear infection?
questions.solution:
When the posterior wall of the external auditory canal is stimulated with a speculum during otoscope examination, it results in vasaovagal syncope. In this, parasympathetic outflow via the vagus nerve (CN X) leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure.

Small auricular branch of the vagus nerve innervates the posterior part of the external auditory canal. Trigeminal nerve through its auriculotemporal branch innervetes the remainder of the external auditory canal mostly. Glossopharyngeal nerve through its tympanic branch innervates the inner surface of the tympanic membrane.

Choice A - the chorda tympani a branch of facial nerve is represented in the middle ear. The chorda tympani nerve carries the afferent taste fibers from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue as well as efferent parasympathetic preganglionis fibers that will ultimately innervate the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands. Facial nerve carries a small motor component to the stapedius but no cutaneous sensory information.

Choice C - accessory nerve innervates voluntary motor function to the trapezius and the sternocleidomastoid muscle

Choice D - trigeminal nerve (mandibular branch) innervates the majority of the external auditory meatus for sensory function except the posterior wall.

Learning objective

Small auricle nerve branch of vagus nerve innervates the posterior external audiotry canal and when stimulated causes vasovagal syncopal episode. (decrease in blood pressure and heart rate)

questions.text: All of the following cervical Somites (Myotomes) contribute to the skeletal muscles of the diaphragm, except?
questions.solution:
SOMITES:

- First pair appear at about 20thday in the craniocaudal sequence at 3 pairs per day.

- At the end of 5thweek, 42 to 44 pairs.

- 4 Occipital

- 8 Cervical

- 12 Thoracic

- 5 Lumbar

- 8 to 10 Coccygeal

- Out of 8 cervical somites, C3,C4,C5 contributes to skeletal muscles of diaphragm.

questions.text: On a busy day in the emergency bay, your wife brought your 4 year old child. When you attended them your son was holding his right upper extremity at his side with his elbow extended and forearm pronated. Any motion of the right elbow produces pain. (-) visible bruises or edema. Your son mumbled that he was playing ‘ring-a-ring-a-rosies’ in the park with other kids and fell down. Which structure is most likely injured in your son ?
questions.solution:
It is a case of nursemaid’s elbow (radial head subluxation.) the most common injury in children below 5 years. This injury happens when there is a sharp pull of the hand while there the forearm is pronated and the elbow is extended. The sudden increase in the axial traction on the proximal radius causes the annular ligament to tear from its periosteal attachment at the radial neck. At the age 5, the annular ligament becomes thick and strong , thus making it hard to be easily torn or displaced. Affected children present with the injured arm held close to the body with the elbow extended and the forearm pronated.

The annular ligament is a strong, fibrous collar which encircles the head of the radius and retains it in contact with the radial notch on the ulna. It is attached to the anterior and posterior margins of the radial notch. It is slightly conical and is loosely attached to the neck of the radius. Thus, the head of the radius is free to turn within the ligament but cannot be pulled down out of it. Proximally, the annular ligament is continuous with, and strengthened by, the lateral and anterior ligaments of the elbow joint.

Choice A- the long head of the biceps tendon inserts into the supraglenoid tubercle, while the short head tendon attaches to the tip of the coracoid process. The common distal tendon inserts into the radial tuberosity.

Choice C- it is present on the medial side of the elbow joint and strengthens the ulnohumeral joint. Injury to this ligament is most commonly seen in throwers due to intense valgus stress at the elbow.

Choice D- it is a broad sheet of connective tissue that spans the space between the radius and ulna.

Learning objective

Sudden traction on the outstretched and pronated arm of a child results in the radial head subluxation. (nursemaid’s elbow). the annular ligament is displaced and torn in this injury.

questions.text: A lesion or injury to the marked nerve  (arrow) will result in ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure in the image is radial nerve. It receives fibers from C5-C8 and T1. it is one of the terminal branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus in the axila. In the axila it gives off the nerve to the long head of triceps. It innervates the skin of the posterior arm and forearm and innervates the extensor muscles of the upper limb. Radial nerve tracks within the radial groove on the humerus, thus it is vulnerable to injury incase of humerus fracture. Lesion or injury to the radial nerve results in wrist drop (wrist and fingers cannot be extended).

Choice A- limitation to the finger abduction results from damage of the recurrent branch of the median nerve or deep branch of the ulnar nerve.

Choice B and C- limited hand flexion and affected opposition of the thumb results from a lesion on the median nerve

questions.text: A well known Neuro-Endocrinologist, 60 year old male, came to the emergency bay due to fever, chills and malaise. He states that his intuition says that there is a heart pathology and requests you to evaluate his cardiac parameters first. Physical examination revealed a new holosystolic heart murmur that radiates towards the axilla. Blood cultures were obtained. He underwent transesophageal echocardiography. The ultrasound probe was placed in the mid-esophagus facing anteriorly and the cardiac chambers were interrogated. Which of the following chambers is closest to the probe, anatomically ?
questions.solution:
This given case is most compatible with the working diagnosis of acute endocarditis. It is to be confirmed from the blood culture results and cardiac imaging. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) uses ultrasound waves generated from within the esophagus to produce the clear images of the neighbouring cardiac structures. The posterior surface of the heart is majorly made up by the left atrium. The esophagus passes immediately posterior to the heart. Thus, the esophagus is in closest proximity to the left atrium. This allows the left atrium, atrial septum and mitral valve to be particularly well visualized on TEE.

Choice A- right ventricle. This forms up the anterior surface of the heart and majority of the inferior border of the

Choice B- right atrium. It forms the right lateral cardiac border along with the superior vena cava.

Choice C- left ventricle. This forms up the apex and left border of the heart.

Learning objective

The left atrium forms up the majority of the posterior surface of the heart.

questions.text: You were in your weekly family gathering after a very long time. Your uncle who is healthy and has no significant past medical history complains of chronic abdominal pain. All of a sudden he grabbed his tummy and cried out in pain. You took him to the hospital and there , CT of the abdomen was done (given below). which of the following, is consistent with the marked structure in the image ?

choices.text: It joins the splenic vein to form the portal vein
It is formed by the union of the common iliac veins
It gives rise to the right and left renal arteries
It drains through the cystic duct into the common bile duct

questions.solution:
The given abdominal CT image is at the level of the L1 vertebra. The renal arteries originate from the aorta at this level. The inferior (IVC) lies anterior to the right renal artery and to the right of the aorta. The right and left common iliac veins merge together to form the IVC at the level of L4-L5 and drains into the right atrium. IVC drains the deoxygenated blood from the lower extremities, portal system and abdominal and pelvic viscera.

Choice A- the portal vein is formed by the union of the superior mesenteric vein and the splenic vein.

Choice C- the abdominal aorta lies posteromedial to the inferior vena cava within the abdomen. The given image shows the abdominal aorta giving rise to the left and right renal arteries.

Choice D- the cystic duct drains bile into the common bile duct from the gallbladder. In this given image , the gallbladder is not visualized due to its higher anatomical location.

Learning objective

The right and left common iliac veins merge together to form the IVC at the level of L4-L5. The renal arteries and veins lie at the level of L1.

questions.text: There is a stab wound at the fifth intercostal space along the midclavicluar line. The victim is conscious but in distress. Which structure is most likely be punctured ?
questions.solution:
Lungs occupy most of the volume in the thoracic cavity. The apex of the lungs extends into the neck just above the first rib. The lung bases are in direct contact with the diaphragm. The diaphragm separates the right lung from the liver and the left lung from the left lobe of the liver, the stomach and the spleen. The anterior surface of the heart is partially covered by the lungs and is located behind the sternum. Left ventricle forms the apex and is covered by the left lung. It lies behind the fifth left intercostal space at the left midclavicular line. The right ventricle forms the anterior surface of the heart. The inferior surface is formed by the right and left ventricles. The posterior surface is mainly formed by the left atrium.

Penetrating injury to the chest wall (fifth intercostal space) at left midclavicular line would most likely injure the left lung. At the same location, much more deeper penetrating injury would injure the apex of the heart.

Choice A- right ventricle is medial to the left mid clavicular line. It forms the anterior surface of the heart and majority of the right ventricle forms the inferior surface as well.

Choice C- left atrium forms the base of the heart and is located posterior to the left ventricle

Choice D- inferior vena cava lies to the right of the midline.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of exertional chest pain. He first noticed the pain a couple of months ago when he was shoveling debris off his driveway and has since experienced several episodes while doing other strenuous tasks. He describes the pain as a heavy crushing sensation and says it is relieved with rest. The patient undergoes coronary angiography and is found to have severe stenosis of the right coronary artery and left anterior descending and circumflex arteries. He is referred to a surgeon for coronary artery bypass grafting. During the procedure, a portion of his great saphenous vein is removed and grafted to one of the diseased coronary arteries to bypass its atherosclerotic narrowing. The vein used as a graft during this patient's procedure can be accessed at which of the following sites?

choices.text: At midline of the popliteal fossa
Just inferior to the anterior superior iliac spine
Just inferolateral to the pubic tubercle
Just superior to the inguinal ligament

questions.solution:
When the left anterior descending artery (LAD) alone is occluded by an atherosclerotic plaque, the left internal mammary (thoracic) artery is the preferred vessel for bypass grafting due to superior patency rates. However, when multiple coronary arteries or vessels other than the LAD require revascularization, great saphenous vein grafts are routinely used. The great saphenous vein is located superficially in the leg and is the longest vein in the body. It courses superiorly from the medial foot, anterior to the medial malleolus, and up the medial aspect of the leg and thigh. In the proximal anterior thigh, 3-4 centimeters inferolateral to the pubic tubercle (Option C), the great saphenous vein dives deep through the cribriform fascia of the saphenous opening to join the femoral vein. Surgeons access the great saphenous vein in the medial leg or, less commonly, near its point of termination in the femoral triangle of the upper thigh. The femoral triangle is bordered by the inguinal ligament superiorly, sartorius muscle laterally, and adductor longus muscle medially.

Option A - The popliteal artery and vein course centrally through the popliteal fossa together with the tibial nerve. Common medical problems that occur in the popliteal fossa include popliteal artery aneurysms, which account for the majority of peripheral artery aneurysms, and synovial (Baker's) cysts, which are commonly associated with arthritis.

Option B - No major vessels are located immediately inferior to the anterior superior iliac spine (ASIS). The ASIS serves as the superior attachment of the inguinal ligament, and a penetrating injury to the region below the ASIS could damage the lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh.

Option D - The deep circumflex iliac vessels course parallel and just superior to the inguinal ligament. The superficial and inferior epigastric veins course above the mid-position of the inguinal ligament.

Educational objective:

The great saphenous vein is a superficial vein of the leg that originates on the medial side of the foot, courses anterior to free medial malleolus, and then travels up the medial aspect of the leg and thigh. It drains into the femoral vein within the region of tie femoral triangle, a few centimeters inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.

questions.text: A 25 year old female is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient presents with severe bleeding from her left hand due to a penetrating injury in the “anatomical snuff box’’ region. The patient is alert and conscious. Her temperature is 98.6 F, pulse is 98 bpm, blood pressure is 130/82 mmHg and respirations are 15/min. The artery responsible for bleeding in this patient is ?
questions.solution:
The artery responsible for bleeding in this patient is the radial artery. The radial artery is a content of the anatomical snuff box. The anatomical snuff box is a triangular deepening on the radial aspect of the dorsum of the wrist. The lateral border (or the radial) of the anatomical snuffbox is formed by the tendons of the extensor pollicis brevis and adductor pollicis longus. The medial border(or the ulnar border) is formed by the tendon of the extensor of extensor pollicis longus. The floor is formed by the scaphoid and trapezium. The roof of the anatomical snuffbox is the skin. The proximal border is formed by the styloid process of the radius. The contents of the anatomical snuff box include the cephalic vein, radial artery and the superficial branch of radial nerve.

Option A- The ulnar artery is not a content of the anatomical snuff box. It is located on the medial side of the forearm. The anatomical snuff is on the lateral side of the wrist.

Option B- The brachial artery bifurcates into radial artery and ulnar artery when it reaches the cubital fossa. This artery does not travel through the anatomical snuff box.

OptionD- The proper palmar digital arteries does not pass through the anatomical snuff box. This artery arises from the common palmar digital artery.

Educational Objective

The anatomical snuff box is a triangular deepening on the radial aspect of the dorsum of the wrist. The contents of the this region include the cephalic vein, radial artery and the superficial branch of radial nerve.

questions.text: A 34 year old male was brought to the emergency department after being involved in a road traffic accident. He suffered blunt trauma and bilateral femur fractures. He has no significant past medical or surgical history. His blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg and pulse is 110/min. During resuscitation, he received several units of packed red blood cells. Once stabilized, patient started complaining of tingling sensation in his toes and fingers. His serum calcium level noted to be 7.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the likely cause of patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Increased renal tubular secretion of calcium
Calcium chelation by a substance in the transfused blood
Electrolyte leakage from red blood cells during pre-transfusion storage
Antibody mediated red blood cell membrane damage

questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing paresthesia due to hypocalcemia. He has had significant blood loss as a result of his injuries, and received several units of packed red blood cells as a part of his resuscitation efforts. Prior to storage, thewhole blood is usually mixed with solution containing citrate anticoagulant. This infused citrate can chelate serum calcium, causing hypocalcemia(option b). It is most likely to occur following massive transfusions of more than 5-6 liters of blood over 24 hours.

Option a –Increased renal tubular excretion of calcium can cause hypocalcemia, but there is no significant clinical history to say the patient’s renal function is compromised.

Option c –Stored red blood cells gradually lose intracellular potassium to the surrounding solution. This can land up in hyperkalemia, not hypocalcemia.

Option d –Antibody mediated red blood cell damage occurs in autoimmune hemolytic anemia, and patient doesn’t have any significant history to support that.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE –Patients who receive massive transfusions over a period of 24 hours, may develop elevated plasma levels of citrate, which chelates calcium and magnesium and reduce their plasma levels, thereby causing hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female, with a long history of menorrhagia, came to the physician with low levels of hemoglobin identified by routine lab investigation. She was diagnosed to have iron deficiency anemia and started on ferrous sulfate. After 3 months of therapy, her lab values have improved. She now asks about stopping her supplements as she is concerned about iron buildup and damage to vital organs. The doctor reassures her that iron hemostasis is maintained by multiple cells in the body. Which of the following cells secrete a substance that controls iron storage and release by other cells involved in iron hemostasis?
questions.solution:
Hepcidin is an acute phase reactant synthesized by liverthat acts as the central regular of iron hemostasis. High iron levels and inflammatory conditions increase the synthesis of hepcidin, while hypoxia and increased erythropoiesis lower hepcidin levels. Hepcidin influence body storage level through interaction with ferroportin. On binding with hepcidin, ferroportin is degraded, decreasing intestinal iron absorption and inhibit release of iron by macrophages. This hepcidin is secreted by the hepatic parenchymal cells (option d).

Option a – Hepcidin is mainly secreted by hepatocytes, biliary cells produce only limited amount of hepcidin, which is mainly excreted by the bile.

Option b and c – When senescent red blood cells are destroyed by macrophages, the iron is recycled by the reticuloendothelial system, for use in new erythroid precursors. Iron released by macrophages under governance of hepcidin binds to transferrin and delivered to bone marrow, and erythroid precursors use them to synthesize hemoglobin.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – Hepcidin is a polypeptide synthesized by the liver that acts as a central regulation of iron hemostasis. High iron levels and inflammatory conditions increase the synthesis of hepcidin, while hypoxia and increased erythropoiesis act to lower hepcidin levels. Low hepcidin levels increase intestinal iron absorption and stimulates iron release by macrophages.

questions.text: A 5 year old boy, is bought to the physician with jaundice and pallor for a very long time. He was adopted at the age of 1 year, and hence family history is unknown. Laboratory studies done, showed anemia, reticulocytosis and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells without central pallor. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
The patient’s anemia, reticulocytosis and increased indirect bilirubin is indicative of hemolytic anemia. His peripheral smear shows red blood cells without central pallor, which indicates hereditary spherocytosis. Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by defective binding of red cell cytoskeleton to plasma membrane due to mutations of Ankyrin, spectrin or band 3 proteins. Compared to normal red blood cells, spherocytes are smaller and have more intensely staining cytoplasm due to membrane loss and red cell dehydration. The red cell index most specific for spherocytosis is elevation in mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) (Option c).

Option a – Lactate dehydrogenase is an enzyme present in red blood cells. It will be elevated in hemolytic anemia.

Option b – Haptoglobin is an acute phase reactant that combines with free hemoglobin in the circulation to preserve body iron stores and prevent tissue damage. Hence, haptoglobin decreases in hemolytic anemia.

Option d – The mean corpuscular volume is usually normal to low in hereditary spherocytosis.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – In spherocytosis, the mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is increased due to mild dehydration of the red blood cells. The markers of hemolysis are often evident and include elevated lactate dehydrogenase, reticuloytosis and decreased haptoglobin.

questions.text: A 25 year old female, came to medicine OP with complaints of chronic fatigue. She has a history of heavy menstrual periods since menarche and also has frequent nosebleeds as a child. Her past medical history is otherwise insignificant and takes no medications. Laboratory studies show hemoglobin of 9.2 g/dL, a mean corpuscular volume of 72 fl and decreased levels of von Willebrand factor in serum. The protein normally binds to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The patient has microcytic anemia with low von Willebrand factors level in serum, indicating von Willebrand disease. In vWD, a mutation results in impaired synthesis of von Willebrand factor, leading to qualitative defect in platelet binding and aggregation. Hence, such patients experience easy bleeding from skin and mucosal sites, including gingival, nasal mucosa, gastrointestinal tract and endometrium. Von willebrand factor serves 2 important roles in hemostasis – a)Promotes platelet adhesion at site of injury by binding to and crosslinking platelet glycoprotein with exposed collagen (option a)underneath the damaged endothelium. b)Acts as a protective carrier protein for factor VII that increases its plasma half life.

Option b – A hemostatic fibrin polymer is the end result of coagulation cascade. Fibrin plays a role in inflammation and coagulation regulation.

Option c – Prostacyclin functions as an inhibitor of platelet aggregation and vasodilator

Option d – Protein C is a vitamin K dependent anticoagulant activated by bound thrombin in presence of endothelium thrombomodulin. It acts with protein S to inactivate the active forms of factors V and VIII.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – von Willebrand factor functions as a promoter of platelet adhesion at sites of vascular injury by binding platelet glycoproteins to subendothelial collagen on injured blood vessel walls. It also acts as a protective barrier protein for circulating factor VIII.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl from Gujarat was rescued after a major earthquake. She was initially treated for minor injuries and dehydration but was referred for further investigations due to persistently low blood pressure (95/44 mm Hg). A continuous machinery-like murmur was heard upon auscultation of her chest. An ECG and an echocardiogram revealed left ventricular hypertrophy. Which of the following cardiac abnormalities is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
A patent ductus arteriosus (Option e) is a communication between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which normally closes shortly after birth. In most cases, this disorder becomes apparent in infants. A continuous murmur is produced because turbulent blood flow occurs along the ductus throughout the cardiac cycle (because pressure is always higher in the aorta than in the pulmonary artery). Increased pulmonary blood flow and venous filling to the left side of the heart have, over time resulted in left ventricular hypertrophy. Low diastolic blood pressure results from pathologic runoff of blood along the patent ductus. The increased pulse pressure reflects the large left ventricular SV, which is the result of increased venous filling on the left side.

Option A – Aortic valve insufficiency is a form of valvular heart disease, occurs when the aortic valve of the heart leaks and causes blood to flow in the wrong direction. As a result, the heart cannot pump efficiently, causing symptoms like fatigue, palpitations, angina pectoris, cyanosis and shortness of breath. It is caused by infective endocarditis, aortic dissection or trauma.

Option B– Aortic stenosis is another valvular disease, due to narrowing of the aortic valve opening. It restricts the blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta and affect the pressure in the left atrium. It is presented as decreased ability to exercise, loss of consciousness, shortness of breath, chest pain and leg swelling. It can cause heart failure.

Option C – Mitral valve prolapse is the bulging of one or both of the mitral valve flaps into the left atrium during the contraction of the heart. On auscultation, a mid systolic click, followed by late systolic murmur is heard, and is accentuated by standing and Valsalva maneuver and diminished with squatting.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE - A patent ductus arteriosusis a communication between the aorta and the pulmonary artery, which normally closes shortly after birth. In most cases, this disorder becomes apparent in infants. A continuous murmur is produced because turbulent blood flow occurs along the ductus throughout the cardiac cycle (because pressure is always higher in the aorta than in the pulmonary artery). Increased pulmonary blood flow and venous filling to the left side of the heart have, over time resulted in left ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents for a routine checkup. His blood pressure is 180/70 mmHg, and his heart rate is 75/min. Physical examination findings are unremarkable. The doctor explains to the patient that his hypertension is most likely caused by age-related _________?
questions.solution:
The patient’s systolic Blood pressure exceeds the 140/90 mmHg cutoff for the diagnosis of hypertension and initiation of antihypertensive therapy. However, the patient’s diastolic blood pressure is within the normal range. After age 50, the pattern of isolated systolic hypertension (ISH) becomes quite common. SBP greater than 160 mmHg with a DBP below 90 mmHg is found in approximately 20% to 30% of all people 80 years and older. ISH is caused by age related decrease in compliance of the aorta and its proximal major branches. Numerous alterations in vessel wall structure and function, including atherosclerotic changes, have been proposed to this aortic stiffening (Option E).

Option A – A primary decrease in cardiac output (CO) tends to decrease the mean arterial pressure at any given value of total peripheral resistance (TPR), as MAP = CO x TPR. In contrast, this patient’s MAP = DBP + 1/3 (SBP-DBP) = 106 mm Hg, which is elevated above the normal adult values of 90-100 mmHg.

Option B – Although sympathetic cardiovascular tone generally increase with age, this tends to increase TPR more than it affects aortic compliance. Increased sympathetic vasoconstriction in muscular arteries and arterioles would tend to elevate both SBP and DBP.

Option C – A decrease in total lung capacity might be associated with some increase in pulmonary vascular resistance. However, this would be necessarily have a significant effect on arterial pressure in the systematic circulation.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – An age related decrease in compliance (increased stiffness) of the aorta and its proximal major branches often causes isolated systolic hypertension.

questions.text: The research division of a large pharmaceutical company focuses on their efforts on studying renal tubular transport proteins. A substance is identified that specifically and completely inhibits glucose transport in the proximal renal tubules. In a healthy volunteer receiving the substance, glucose clearance will best approximate the clearance of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Glucose is normally freely filtered at the glomerulus and completely or partially reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, depending upon the filtered glucose load. Because glucose is freely filtered, its concentration in the tubular fluid in bowman space is equal to its plasma concentration. Proximal convoluted tubule reabsorption of glucose occurs via Na/glucose co transporters in the apical membranes of the proximal tubular cells. Because this process is carrier mediated, it is saturable in the setting of high glucose concentration, like in diabetes mellitus, resulting in glycosuria. The renal tubules do not secrete glucose.An agent that inhibits proximal tubule glucose reabsorption will cause all filtered glucose to be excreted. Thus, the glucose clearance will equal the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). Inulin is also freely filtered at the glomerulus and is neither absorbed nor secreted by the renal tubules. Hence, for this reason, the inulin clearance is commonly used for calculating the GFR.

Option B :Para amino hippuric acid (PAH) is freely filtered in the glomerulus and is also secreted into the urine by an energy dependent organic acid transporter in the proximal tubule. The amount of PAH excreted is greater than the filtered load and the clearance of PAH is used to calculate the renal plasma flow. Creatinine is also secreted by the renal tubules, although not nearly to the extent of PAH.

Option C :Like glucose, amino acids are also filtered at the glomerulus and then reabsorbed in the proximal tubule.

Option D :Urea is filtered at the glomerulus and then passively reabsorbed in the proximal tubule and inner medullary collecting ducts. It is also passively secreted by thin regions of the loop of henle. The remainder of the nephron is impermeable to urea. The net result is excretion of 10-70% of the filtered urea load, depending on the flow rate and concentration. Urea clearance is normally less than the GFR.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE :Glucose is normally filtered at the glomerulus and completely reabsorbed by the proximal tubule. Inhibition of sodium coupled, carrier mediated transport of glucose by the proximal tubule would cause glucose clearance to approach the value of the GFR, which is estimated by calculating the clearance of inulin.

questions.text: A new dialysis technique is developed to clear circulating autoantibodies from plasma. The technique is based on using a semipermeable membrane. Which of the following is most likely to increase the rate of dialysis?

choices.text: Increase surface area of the membrane
Applying negative charge to the membrane

questions.solution:
Multiple factors affect the rate of molecular diffusion across a semipermeable membrane separating two well mixed compartments. The number of molecules that cross the membrane per second is proportional to the molecular concentration difference across the membrane, the surface area of the membrane and the solubility of the substance. Diffusion is inversely proportional to the total membrane thickness and the molecular weight of the molecule.

Option A and B :A decrease in membrane pore size would slow or prevent the diffusion of larger molecules across the membrane and increasing membrane thickness would decrease the diffusion rate.

Option D :Applying a charge to generate a voltage difference between two adjacent compartments can alter the transmembrane flow rate of charged particles. Small particles with high charge density and high mobility in solution would be affected by such a change. However, autoantibodies will have a low net charge and mobility.

Option E :The diffusion constant of a macromolecule can vary with temperature. A decrease in temperature will cause slowing of rate of dialysis.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE :The net number of molecules diffusing across the semipermeable membrane per second is proportional to the molecule’s concentration difference across the membrane, total membrane surface area and the solubility of the substance. Diffusion is inversely proportional to the total membrane thickness and molecular weight of the molecule.

questions.text: A 40 year old male is diagnosed with hepatic cirrhosis due to prolonged heavy alcohol consumption. He develops massive ascites and low extremity edema that responds well to furosemide therapy. However, a week later the patient receives high dose ibuprofen for joint pains and soon develops worsening abdominal distension. Blunting of the diuretic response in this patient is due to interruption of which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
Furosemide is a loop diuretic that works by inhibiting the Na-K-2 Cl symporters in the ascending limb of loop of henle. It binds to the symporters and effectively blocks Na and Cl transport resulting in increased Na, Cl and fluid excretion. Also, loop diuretics also stimulate the prostaglandin release. Prostaglandins have vasodilatory effects, thereby increasing the renal blood flow and GFR and enhanced drug delivery. All these factors enhance the diuretic response.Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, naproxen and indomethacin inhibit prostaglandin synthesis(Option A ). Thus, this concurrent use of NSAIDs with loop diuretics can cause decreased diuretic response.

Option B :Endothelin is a peptide found in the smooth muscles that cause smooth muscle contraction. It is a very potent vasoconstrictor. Endothelin does not affect the effects of loop diuretics.

Option C :Angiotensin II is a peptide responsible for vasoconstriction and aldosterone release. Although loop diuretics stimulate renin release leading to angiotensin II formation, it does not play an important role in diuretic response of loop diuretics.

Option D :Aldosterone is secreted by adrenal cortex. It promotes Na reabsorption in the distal tubule and the collecting duct. Aldosterone antagonist diuretics spironolactone work by inhibiting aldosterone.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE :Furosemide is a loop diuretic that works by inhibiting Na-K-2 Cl symporters in the loop of henle effectively causing increased Na, Cl and fluid excretion. It also stimulates prostaglandin release. By stimulating prostaglandin release, loop diuretics also increase renal blood flow leading to increased GFR and enhanced drug delivery. Thus concurrent use of NSAIDs with loop diuretics can result in decreased diuretic response.

questions.text: A 40 year old male, came to the emergency department with complaints of one episode of upper gastrointestinal bleeding at home two hours back. He is unable to provide any information, but his medical records show history of alcoholism. After undergoing emergency evaluation and appropriate resuscitation, his condition stabilizes. Gastric lavage was done, which initially contained blood, but then cleared quickly. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy was done, which showed a linear mucosal tear at the gastrointestinal junction. The process directly responsible for causing this tear, will most likely result in which of the following acid base disturbance?
questions.solution:
This patient has Mallory Weiss tear, of gastric mucosa near gastrointestinal junction. Mallory Weiss tears are caused by high intragastric pressure being transmitted to esophagus through tight lower esophageal sphincter. Most likely caused by repetitive retching and vomiting but ethanol abuse or straining during defecation, heavy weight lifting, seizures, blunt injury and upper GI endoscopy. Repetitive vomiting leads to metabolic alkalosis(Option b) due to net loss of acidic gastric secretions.

Option a – Chronic alcoholism can cause ketoacidosis in malnourished patients, and ethanol intoxication usually does not cause high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option c – Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is caused by loss of bicarbonate, which can occur with prolonged diarrhea. Vomiting usually will not cause metabolic acidosis.

Option d– Respiratory acidosis occurs in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or CNS depression.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – A mallory Weiss tear is a tear in the gastric mucosa near gastroesophageal junction. It occurs due to repetitive forceful vomiting, which can cause metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 40 year old male, came to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The pain radiates to the back and improved on bending forward. Physical examination shows vitals are stable, abdominal examination reveals tenderness over epigastrium and decreased bowel sounds. The patient is admitted and started with IV fluids and analgesics, but the condition did not improve. Hence, abdominal CT scan done which shows diffuse pancreatic enlargement with areas of necrosis. The inappropriate activation of which of the following enzymes has created this condition?
questions.solution:
Pancreatic enzymes are synthesized by pancreatic acinar cells as inactive precursors called as zymogens. These zymogen granules are then secreted from apical surface of acinar cells through exocytosis and released into the ampulla of vater in descending part of duodenum. The enzyme enterokinase cleaves trypsinogen to trypsin (Option e), its active form. Once a small amount of trypsin is produced, it activates other zymogens including chymotrypsin, elastase, carboxypeptidase. Moreover, trypsin can also cleave trypsinogen into more trypsin, allowing the cycle of proteolytic enzyme activation in duodenum. The pathogenesis of acute pancreatitis begins with damage to pancreatic acinar cells through direct toxic insult or ischemia resulting in pancreatic ductal obstruction. This triggers the abnormal activation of trypsin by enzymes, activating other proteolytic enzymes and autolysis. Severe cases land up in acute necrotizing pancreatitis with high propensity for secondary bacterial infection.

Option a – Amylase hydrolyzes starch to produce maltose and limit dextrins. It does not require activation by trypsin.

Option b – Lipase hydrolyzes triglycerides to fatty acids and glycerol. It is synthesized in an active form and not require activation by trypsin. Lipase can cause fat necrosis after leaking out of damaged acini.

Option c– Chymotrypsin and elastase are secreted by pancreas as inactive precursors and activated by trypsin, but do not initiate the formation of pancreatitis.

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – All of the pancreatic zymogens are converted into their active forms by trypsin. Intracellular cleavage of trypsinogen to trypsin within pancreas leads to premature activation of zymogens and pancreatic auto-digestion. Thus, abnormal activation of trypsinogen to trypsin in the central event in pathogenesis of acute necrotizing pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 50 year old male, with history of hepatitis C infection, was brought to the emergency department by his wife after several episodes of vomiting bright red blood. He was admitted to the hospital and appropriate treatment was started. During morning rounds the next day, the treating physician found that the patient is disoriented and cannot identify the date/day or the current location. Physical examination done shows significant abdominal distention and gynecomastia. Repetitive flicking motions of the hands are seen when the patient is asked to outstretch his arms and dorsiflex his wrists. Which of the following event is the most likely precipitant of the patient’s altered mental status?

choices.text: Decreased concentration of gamma aminobutyric acid
Increased load of nitrogenous substance absorbed by the gut

questions.solution:
This patient has hepatic encephalopathy, which was precipitated by his recent gastrointestinal bleeding. Hepatic encephalopathy refers to a reversible decline in neurologic function that occurs due to failure of liver to metabolize the waste products such as ammonia. Ammonia is normally produced by the GI tract as a result of the enterocytic catabolism of glutamine and colonic bacterial catabolism of dietary protein. GI bleeding causes increased nitrogen delivery to the gut in the form of hemoglobin, which is then converted into ammonia and absorbed into the bloodstream. The ammonia then enters the liver through portal vein and detoxified into urea. In chronic liver failure, hepatocytic dysfunction and shunting of blood through portosystemic collaterals impair the liver’s detoxification ability, leading to accumulation of ammonia and other neurotoxins in the circulation, causing altered amino acid transport across blood brain barrier, impaired neurotransmitter metabolism and depressed cerebral glucose metabolism. This results in increased levels of Gamma aminobutyric acid (Option c)and impaired excitatory neurotransmitter release. In hepatic encephalopathy, lowering of blood ammonia is done by oral administration of disaccharide (lactulose), thereby increase the fecal nitrogen excretion.

Option a – Accumulation of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is suggestive of renal failure, heart failure or dehydration. No affected in liver failure.

Option b – Bacterial meningitis presents with altered mental status, high fever, photophobia, nuchal rigidity.

Stage

Symptoms

I

Mild Confusion, agitation, irritability, sleep disturbance, decreased attention

II

Lethargy, disorientay, inappropriate behaviour, drowsiness

III

Somnolent but arousable, slurred speech, confused, aggressive

IV

Coma

 

LEARNING OBJECTIVE – Hepatic encephalopathy is caused by increased levels of ammonia and other neurotoxins in the circulation that leads to increased inhibitory neurotransmission and impaired excitatory neurotransmitter release. Hepatic encephalopathy is frequently precipitated by a stressor that alters the ammonia balance (gastrointestinal bleeding, increased diet protein).

questions.text: 25-year-old male seeks evaluation for increased fatigue and muscle aches during exercise. He stated that recently he joined an exercise program to lose weight. Stress testing reveals normal cardiac function, but serial blood tests show increased serum lactic acid and ammonia levels when he was at rest. His physician postulates a mitochondrial DNA depletion disorder that affects mitochondrial function due to defects in mitochondrial DNA polymerase or tRNAs. Which of the following options: (1) list mitochondrial pathways that would explain the man’s blood findings, and (2) name a compound linking these pathways?

choices.text: Citric acid cycle, electron transport, and isocitrate
Citric acid and urea cycles, and fumarate

questions.solution:
Option D: Fumarate and arginine are produced from argininosuccinate in the urea cycle, after which arginine is converted to ornithine to yield urea, and fumarate is converted to malate and then oxaloacetate in the citric acid cycle. Depending upon the organism’s needs, oxaloacetate can either enter gluconeogenesis or react with acetyl-CoA to form citrate and traverse the citric acid cycle with the generation of NADH and then energy through oxidative phosphorylation. Starvation will simultaneously increase urea cycle activity to remove ammonia from protein degradation and increase fumarate for oxaloacetate production; the oxaloacetate is then available for gluconeogenesis to maintain glucose levels that are essential for brain metabolism. Depletion of mitochondrial pathway functions will mainly impact electron transport and cause more dependence on glycolysis and lactate production as exercise depletes blood oxygen saturation. A vicious cycle of exercise intolerance leading to muscle inactivity with fewer mitochondria exacerbates myopathy (muscle weakness and incoordination) in mitochondrial disorders

Options A, B: The citric acid and urea cycle are located primarily in the mitochondria, while pathways for glycogen and glucose metabolism are primarily in the cytosol.

Options C, D: Isocitrate and fumarate are intermediates of the citric acid cycle, but the only fumarate is an intermediate of both the citric acid and urea cycles.

Learning Objective: Depletion of mitochondrial pathway functions will mainly impact electron transport and cause more dependence on glycolysis and lactate production as exercise depletes blood oxygen saturation. A vicious cycle of exercise intolerance leading to muscle inactivity with fewer mitochondria exacerbates myopathy (muscle weakness and incoordination) in mitochondrial disorders.

questions.text: A 26-year-old medical student contracts a skin infection from an elderly patient and notes expanding circular red lesion on the thigh at dinner that night. He places a warm washrag on the lesion at bedtime and awakens with shortness of breath. After reluctantly going to health clinic, he faints during the registration process and awakens in ICU. The attending physician tells him he has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus with toxic shock syndrome and adult respiratory distress syndrome. He wishes to use a new antibiotic that acts on the earliest step of protein synthesis. Which of the following steps are targeted?

choices.text: Loading of the small ribosomal subunit with initiation factors, messenger RNA, and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA
Sliding of the ribosome three bases forward to read a new codon
Binding of the small ribosomal subunit to the large ribosomal subunit

questions.solution:
Despite more complex initiation factors loading small ribosomal subunit (correct answer b), protein synthesis in prokaryotes and eukaryotes is quite similar. The ribosomal subunits are odd numbers the 30S and 50S in prokaryotes and even numbers 40S and 60S in eukaryotes. At start of translation, initiation factors, mRNA, and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA bind to tdissociated small ribosomal subunit(options A, C, D thus incorrect).

Only after small ribosomal subunit is primed with mRNA and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA does large ribosomal subunit bind to it. Once this happens, elongation factors bring first aminoacyl-tRNA of nascent protein to the A site. This is the step inhibited by tetracycline. Then, peptidyl transferase copies a peptide bond between initiation amino acid and first amino acid of forming peptide. The now uncharged initiation tRNA leaves P site, and peptidyl-tRNA from A site moves to vacant P site with two amino acids attached. The ribosome advances three bases to read next codon, and the process repeats. Macrolide antibiotics (eg, azithromycin, Zithromax, and erythromycin) bind to the bacterial 50S ribosome and inhibit this translocation step. When stop signal is reached, complete polypeptide has been synthesized, releasing factors bind to the stop signal, causing peptidyl transferase to hydrolyze the bond that joins the polypeptide at the A site to the tRNA. Factors prevent the reassociation of ribosomal subunits in the absence of a new initiation complex.

Learning objective: Despite the more complex initiation factors loading the small ribosomal subunit protein synthesis in prokaryotes and eukaryotes is quite similar. The ribosomal subunits are odd numbers the 30S and 50S in prokaryotes and even numbers 40S and 60S in eukaryotes. At the start of translation, initiation factors, mRNA, and initiation aminoacyl-tRNA bind to the dissociated small ribosomal subunit.

questions.text: A coal mine worker was brought in an unconscious state to the emergency room after a blast in the mine. His blood Carboxyhemoglobin level was high and he was diagnosed with CO poisoning. CO is a known inhibitor of the electron transport chain. Which complex of electron transport chain is inhibited by CO?
questions.solution:
Carbon monoxide (CO) toxicity is the result of a combination of tissue hypoxia and direct CO-mediated damage at a cellular level since not all the signs and symptoms presented can be explained only by the formation of carboxyhemoglobin. Mitochondria, especially the electron transport chain, seem to be the target for CO at a subcellular level. CO inhibits mitochondrial respiration by binding the ferrous heme a3 in the active site of cytochrome c oxidase (complex IV of the mitochondrial respiratory chain), effectively shutting down oxidative phosphorylation, similar to the effects of cyanide and nitric oxide. COX has only a threefold preference for CO compared to O2, Thus, due to the competitive binding of O2 and CO to COX, CO-mediated mitochondrial inhibition is greatest under hypoxic conditions. With COX inhibited, oxidative phosphorylation slows down, decreasing ATP production in tissues, such as the brain or heart. Other complexes in the electron transport chain continue to shuttle electrons, generating superoxide, leading to further damage of cells and tissues

Option A: Complex I is one of the main sites at which premature electron leakage to oxygen occurs, thus being one of the main sites of the production of superoxide.

Option B: Complex II is a parallel electron transport pathway to complex 1, but unlike complex 1, no protons are transported to the intermembrane space in this pathway. Therefore, the pathway through complex II contributes less energy to the overall electron transport chain process.

Option C: The complex III is inhibited by dimercaprol, Napthoquinone, and Antimycin.

Learning objectives: Carbon monoxide binds to and inhibits cytochrome c oxidase (complex IV). In addition to the disruption of the ETC, carbon monoxide also binds to hemoglobin at an oxygen-binding site converting it to carboxyhemoglobin. In this state, oxygen is displaced from hemoglobin, effectively blocking delivery to body tissues.

questions.text: A- 29 year- old hotel worker presented to emergency department complaining of chills and breathing difficulty. He was a heroin abuser who was admitted in the same hospital 7 years ago because of drug over dosage. He had lost 10 kg of body weight since his last clinical visit. On examination, he had multiple enlarged lymph nodes. Several red nodules were there on the chest and arms. His body temperature was 40oC, B.P. 170/50 mm Hg and respiration was shallow with a respiratory rate of 40 breaths per minute. The chest radiograph showed diffuse pneumonia. Sputum smear revealed numerous Pneumocystis organisms while skin biopsy revealed Kaposi’s sarcoma. The patient is diagnosed with AIDS. What is the specific exam to diagnose AIDS?

choices.text: Diminished cell-mediated immunity as indicated by skin tests
Lymph node biopsy shows profound abnormalities

questions.solution:
Non Specific Tests- The following tests help to establish the immunodeficiency in HIV infection.

  1. Total Leukocyte and lymphocyte count- to demonstrate leucopenia and lymphopenia. The lymphocytic count is usually below 2000/mm3
  2. T cell subset Assays- Absolute CD4+ cell count is less than 200 /L.T4 T8 ratio is reversed.. The decrease in CD4 is the hall mark for AIDS.
  3. Platelet count- shows Thrombocytopenia.
  4. IgA and Ig G levels are raised
  5. Diminished cell mediated Immunity as indicated by skin tests
  6. Lymph node biopsy shows profound abnormalities. .

Specific Tests for HIV infection- These include demonstration of HIV antigen, antibodies. Viral nucleic acids or other components and isolation of virus ) Detection of antigen- Following a contact, as by blood transfusion, the viral antigen may be detectable in blood after about 2 weeks. The major core antigen p24 is the earliest virus marker to appear in blood. IgM antibodies appear in about 4-6 weeks, to be followed by IgG antibodies

Detection of antibodies

Demonstration of antibodies is the simplest and most widely employed technique for the diagnosis of HIV infection. However it takes 2-8 weeks to months for the antibodies to appear in circulation and during that period the person may be highly infectious. Once antibodies appear they increase in titer for the next several months. IgM antibodies disappear in 8-10weeks while IgG antibodies remain through out. When immunodeficiency becomes severe following clinical AIDS some components of anti p24 may disappear.

Screening tests and supplemental tests.

ELISA- ELISA is the most frequently used method for screening of blood samples for HIV antibody. The sensitivity and specificity of the presently available commercial systems approaches 100% but false positive and false negative reactions occur.

  1. First generation - whole viral lysates
  2. Second generation - recombinant antigen
  3. Third generation - synthetic peptide
  4. Fourth generation - antigen + antibody (Simultaneous detection of HIV antigen and antibody) - HIV duo

Antibody can be detected in a majority of individuals within 6-12 weeks after infection using the earlier generation of assays. But it can be detected within 3-4 weeks when using the newer third generation ELISA. Due to their ability to detect p24 antigen, the fourth generation ELISA will be of value in detecting early infection. The window period can be shortened to two weeks using p24-antigen assay.

LEARNING EXPLANATION: Non Specific Tests- The following tests help to establish the immunodeficiency in HIV infection.

  1. Total Leukocyte and lymphocyte count- to demonstrate leucopenia and lymphopenia. The lymphocytic count is usually below 2000/mm3
  2. T cell subset Assays- Absolute CD4+ cell count is less than 200 /L.T4 T8 ratio is reversed.. The decrease in CD4 is the hall mark for AIDS.
  3. Platelet count- shows Thrombocytopenia.
  4. IgA and Ig G levels are raised
  5. Diminished cell mediated Immunity as indicated by skin tests
  6. Lymph node biopsy shows profound abnormalities.

questions.text: A 65- year –old patient presents with weight loss, loss of appetite, dull dragging pain in the right hypochondrium and jaundice from the last 1 month. Stool is reported to be clay colored from the same duration. Blood biochemistry reveals Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Urine shows the presence of bilirubin. The patient has been diagnosed with carcinoma of head of the pancreas. Which serum enzyme is expected to be much higher than normal for this patient?
questions.solution:
ALP- Patients with higher serum alkaline phosphatase-to-albumin ratio (APAR) level were probable to sustain poorer overall survival (OS). Significant positive correlations were found between APAR and tumor site, and several serum biochemical indexes, such as aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), etc. The results of multivariate analysis showed, APAR was also identified as an independent prognostic indicator for OS in both primary and validation cohorts (P=0.004, P=0.038, respectively). Compared with the AJCC 8thedition, the nomogram consisting of APAR, pathological differentiation and the TNM staging system of AJCC 8thedition showed superior predictive accuracy for OS. All these results were further verified in the validation cohort.

APAR can be considered as a novel independent prognostic biomarker for PDAC following curative resection. One more accurate and advanced predictive model will be achieved via the incorporation of APAR into nomogram.

Pathophysiology of liver associated enzymes

Alanine Transaminase (ALT):

 

Produced in hepatocytes

 

 

 

 

Very specific marker of hepatocellular injury

 

 

 

Relatively low concentrations in other tissues so more specific than AST

 

Levels fluctuate during the day

 

 

 

Rise may occur with the use of certain drugs or during periods of strenuous exercise.

Aspartate Transaminase (AST):

 

Occurs in two isoenzymes, indistinguishable on standard AST assays.

 

 

 

The mitochondrial isoenzyme is produced in hepatocytes and reacts to membrane stresses in a similar way to ALT.

 

The cytosolic isoenzyme is present in skeletal muscle, heart muscle and kidney tissue.

 

Caution must be exercised in its use to evaluate hepatocellular damage.

 

 

Usually rises in conjunction with ALT to indicate hepatocellular injury: a hepatitis picture.

Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP):

 

A group of isoenzymes that act to dephosphorylate a variety of molecules throughout the body.

 

Produced in the membranes of cells lining bile ducts and canaliculi.

 

 

Released in response to the accumulation of bile salts or cholestasis.

 

 

Non-hepatic production in the kidney, intestine, leukocytes, placenta and bone.

 

Physiological rise in pregnancy or in growing children.

 

 

Pathological rise in Paget’s disease, renal disease and with bone metastases.

Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT):

 

Present in liver, kidney, pancreas and intestine.

It is found in the microsomes of hepatocytes and biliary epithelial cells.

Elevation of GGT in association with a rise in ALP is highly suggestive of a biliary tract obstruction and is known as a cholestatic picture.

Subject to rise with hepatic enzyme induction due to chronic alcohol use or drugs such as rifampicin and phenytoin.

questions.text: A 23 –year-old young woman, who recently began taking birth control pills, presents to emergency room with cramping abdominal pain, anxiety, hallucinations and paranoid behavior. A surgical evaluation, including Ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scan have failed to demonstrate any abdominal process. Examination reveals vesicles and bullae on the skin of arms and face. Urine analysis reveals the presence of porphyrins (ALA, PBG, Uro and Coproporphyrins). What is the possible diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Variegate porphyria (VP) is an autosomal dominant genetic disorder due to partially deficient activity of the mitochondrial enzyme protoporphyrinogen oxidase (PPOX) . VP is both a cutaneous porphyria (with chronic blistering skin lesions) and an acute porphyria (with severe episodic neurovisceral symptoms).In adult-onset cutaneous blistering lesions (sub epidermal vesicles, bullae, and erosions that crust over and heal slowly) of sun-exposed skin, especially the hands and face. Facial hyperpigmentation and hypertrichosis may occur. Acute neurovisceral symptoms can occur any time after puberty, are highly variable, but may be similar from episode to episode in a patient with recurrent attacks. Symptoms may become chronic. The most common manifestations are abdominal pain, constipation, tachycardia, hypertension, pain in the back, chest, and extremities, anxiety, agitation, seizures, and neuromuscular weakness that may progress to quadriparesis and respiratory paralysis. The biochemical diagnosis of VP is established in an individual with elevated urine porphobilinogen (PBG) or porphyrins and a fluorescence peak at ~626 nm on plasma fluorescence scanning The molecular diagnosis of VP is established by identification of a heterozygous pathogenic variant in PPOX on molecular genetic testing.
  2. Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP )characteristically demonstrate acute episodes of neurovisceral symptoms but may not manifest fully for a long time. AIP manifests as episodes of abdominal pain, neuropathies, and constipation, but, unlike most other porphyrias, patients with AIP do not develop a cutaneous rash. The primary enzymatic defect in AIP is the deficiency of porphobilinogen - deaminase, also called hydroxymethylbilane synthase (HMBS), the third enzyme in heme synthesis. The acute attacks of AIP are a result of the uncontrolled upregulation of the ALA synthase enzyme. The diagnosis of AIP gets delayed due to nonspecific symptoms and similarities with other diseases. The only cure is orthoptic liver transplantation.
  3. Congenital erythropoietic porphyria is an autosomal recessive genetic disorder by markedly reduced enzyme activity of uroporphyrinogen III synthase, characterized in most individuals by severe cutaneous photosensitivity with blistering and increased friability of the skin over light-exposed areas. Onset in most affected individuals occurs at birth or early infancy. The first manifestation is often pink-to-dark red discoloration of the urine. Repeated light exposure can lead to scarring, infection and loss of facial features and digits.
  4. Hereditary coproporphyria (HCP) is an acute (hepatic) porphyria in which the acute symptoms are neurovisceral and occur in discrete episodes. Attacks typically start in the abdomen with low-grade pain that slowly increases over a period of days (not hours) with nausea progressing to vomiting. In some individuals, the pain is predominantly in the back or extremities. When an acute attack is untreated, a motor neuropathy may develop over a period of days or a few week. Acute hepatic porphyria should be suspected in individuals with the following symptoms or findings are Nausea for at least 48 hours, Abdominal, back, or extremity pain for at least 48 hours, New-onset seizures, Hyponatremia, Family history of porphyria. The most sensitive and specific biochemical screening test for any one of the acute porphyrias (including HCP) during an acute attack is a striking increase in urinary porphobilinogen. Quantitative analysis of porphyrins in both urine and feces is essential to distinguish between the different acute porphyrias and establish the diagnosis of HCP.
  5. Learning objectives: The porphyria diseases are a group of metabolic disorders caused by abnormal functioning of heme biosynthesis enzymes and characterized by the excessive accumulation and excretion of porphyrins and their precursors. Precisely which of these chemicals builds up depends on the type of porphyria. Porphyria is not a single disease but a group of nine disorders. Each porphyria results from overproduction of heme precursors secondary to partial deficiency or, in XLP, increased activity of one of the enzymes of heme biosynthesis.

questions.text: A middle aged women on oral contraceptives for many years developed neurological symptoms such as depression, irritability, nervousness and mental confusion. Her hemoglobin level was 8g/dl. Biochemical investigations revealed that she was excreting highly elevated concentrations of xanthurenic acid in urine. She also showed high levels of triglycerides and cholesterol in serum. All of the above findings are most probably due to deficiency of vitamin b6 caused by prolonged use of oral contraceptives except?

choices.text: neurological symptoms by decreased synthesis of biogenic amines

questions.solution:
Increased triglyceride and cholesterol levels are best attributed to the metabolic effects of steroidal contraceptives themselves rather than as consequence of decreased vitamin B6 levels. Regarding metabolic effects of oral contraception on lipid metabolism, plasma lipids and lipoproteins are increased. Total cholesterol and triglycerides are increased. Use of oral contraception with deficiency of pyridoxine vit B6 – all other features mentioned in the question may be attributed to pyridoxine deficiency.

INCREASED XANTHIURIC ACID EXCRETION IN URINE: Pyridoxine acts as a coenzyme for kynureninase which converts 3OH kynureinine to 3 OH anthranilic acid which ultimately forms nicotinic acid. In pyridoxine deficiency the substrates are increased and they are converted into xanthurenic acid in extrahepatic tissues which is excreted in urine.

DECREASED HEMOGLOBIN LEVEL: Pyridoxal-p is required for conversion of A amino B ketoadipic acid 10 D-ALA an important step in heme synthesis. In B6 deficiency heme synthesis suffers, thus explaining anemia or decreased hemoglobin levels.

NERUROLOGICAL SYMPTOMS: Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with peripheral neuropathy seizures in infants and abnormal electroencephalograms

Learning objective: increased triglyceride and cholesterol levels are best attributed to the metabolic effects of steroidal contraceptives themselves rather than as consequence of decreased vitamin B6 levels. Regarding metabolic effects of oral contraception on lipid metabolism, plasma lipids and lipoproteins are increased. Total cholesterol and triglycerides are increased. Use of oral contraception with deficiency of pyridoxine vitamin B6 – all other features mentioned in the question may be attributed to pyridoxine deficiency

questions.text: A 4-year-old child showing symptoms of muscle pain and weakness after playing is taken to the hospital for examination. Tests reveal slight hepatomegaly and cardiomegaly. Biopsy of liver shows extreme but nonspecific fatty changes, and a muscle biopsy showed large amounts of cytoplasmic vacuoles filled with neutral lipid. Fasting for a period of 24 hours resulted in blood glucose levels drop without a corresponding production of ketone bodies. The pH of the blood is normal. Which of the following is the best diagnosis for this child’s problems?
questions.solution:
Skeletal muscles (slow-twitch fibers) use free fatty acids at rest. As carnitine is required for the oxidation of long chain fatty acids (see fig), the patient is having muscle weakness. Carnitine deficiency leads to defective fatty acid oxidation and hypoglycemia.

  • There is no jaundice in the patient. So, Bilirubin diglucuronide transporter deficiency (option a) is ruled out.
  • Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (Von-Gierke’s disease) leads to ketoacidosis. The patient is not having ketosis, so, option b is excluded.
  • Complete 3-hydroxy 3-methylglutaryl-CoA (HMG) reductase deficiency is incompatible with life (option c is ruled out).

questions.text: A 44-year-old male is concerned about his risk of a heart attack since his brother just had a heart attack at the age of 46. His physician orders an HbA1C, lipid panel, and homocysteine level. The biochemical examination of blood shows normal Hb1AC levels and normal lipid profile but higher than normal homocysteine levels. Which one of the following amino acids is not properly formed in his body?
questions.solution:
Methionine, obtained from the diet, is metabolized as shown in figure:

A defect in either the enzyme that forms methionine from homocysteine (homocysteine methyl transferase) or the enzyme that forms cystathionine (cystathionine ß-synthase) will lead to elevated homocysteine levels. Also, deficiency of either cobalamin or folate or both can also lead to homocysteine accumulation. As this patient has no genetic enzyme deficiencies so the most probable cause of his homocystinuria is deficiency of vitamins which can be treated by vitamin supplementation.

All other amino acids given in options do not require homocysteine for their synthesis.

Incorrect options

Option A;Alanine is anamino acid that can be used for making proteins. This can also be used for breaking down tryptophan and vitamin B-6. This is a source of energy for muscles and the central nervous system. This will strengthen the immune system and will help the body to use sugars.

Option B; Amino acids are also serving as the building blocks of protein. The body makes tyrosine from another amino acid called phenylalanine. Tyrosine can also be found in many of the dairy products such as meats, fish, eggs, nuts, beans, oats, and wheat.

Option C;Phenylalanine is anamino acid which is serving as a "building block" of protein. It is the only form that is found in proteins. Major dietary sources of L-phenylalanine will include meat, fish, eggs, cheese, and milk. Phenylalanine is the most common used amino acid for a skin disorder. This will cause white patches to develop on the skin which is seen in vitiligo.

Learning objective

As this patient has no genetic enzyme deficiencies so the most probable cause of his homocystinuria is deficiency of vitamins which can be treated by vitamin supplementation. All other amino acids given in options do not require homocysteine for their synthesis.

questions.text: A 11 month old boy weighing 3kg presented with polyuria, polydipsia and delayed motor milestones. Physical examination revealed alert, awake, not in respiratory distress , afebrile, blood pressure was 95/58. Blood investigation was done. It shows PH of 7.46, creatinine of 0.5mg/dl, potassium of 3mEq/l, sodium of 125mEq/l, chloride of 88mEq/l, calcium of 8.8mg/dl, bicarbonate of26mEq/l. Ultrasonography shows medullary nephrocalcinosis. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
First the clinical features and laboratory investigation of this infant

  • polyuria
  • polydipsia
  • delayed motor milestones
  • growth retardation(weight of 11 month old boy should be 9)
  • normal creatinine level
  • decreased potassium
  • decreased sodium
  • decreased chloride
  • decreased calcium
  • normal bicarbonate
  • increased pH alkalosis

C/F of barters syndrome is

  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal to low blood pressure
  • Polyuria
  • Nocturia
  • Growth retardation

RENAL TUBULAR ACIDOSIS: it can be easily ruled out because patient presented with alkalosis

DIABETES INSCIPIDUS: in DI there is loss of water in urine as a consequence of concentration of sodium and potassium is increased.

PSEUDOHYPOALDOSTERONISM: aldosterone level is normal or increased but there are features of aldosterone deficiency such as decreased sodium and increased potassium.

Learning objective: First the clinical features and laboratory investigation of this infant, polyuria, polydipsia, delayed motor milestones, growth retardation(weight of 11 month old boy should be 9kgs), normal creatinine level, decreased potassium, decreased sodium, decreased chloride, decreased calcium, normal bicarbonate, increased pH alkalosis

questions.text:
A man 63 yr old was reported dead. He was admitted with a history of worsening congestive heart failure before 2 months. ECG reading shows mitral valve stenosis with left atrial dilatation. A thrombus is present in the left atrium. One month later, he experiences flank pain on the left side and irritation and blood when urinating. An elevated serum AST was shown in the lab test report. Even after proper life-saving measures he died. A photograph of a section of the kidney obtained at autopsy is shown.



Which of the following patterns of tissue necrosis is most likely to be present in this man?
questions.solution:
Embolization of the thrombus lead to blockage of a renal arterial branch, causing an acute renal infarction in this patient.

Coagulative necrosis occurs due to ischemia in solid organs (heart, liver, spleen, and kidneys). Ischemia is characterized by decreased oxygen delivery, which reduces the amount of ATP produced via aerobic glycolysis. By switching to anaerobic metabolism,resulting in acidosis causes denaturation of proteins and prevents the cell from dissolving (temporary preserved cellular architecture either without cell nuclei or with nuclei that are still undergoing karyolysis).

Option b: Liquefactive necrosis occurs after ischemic injury to the brain and is seen with abscess formation.

Option c: Fat necrosis is usually seen in pancreatic and breast tissue. .

Option d: Caseous necrosis can be seen in various forms of granulomatous inflammation,as in tuberculosis.

Educational objectives: An ischemic injury to most internal organs produces a pattern of cell death called coagulative necrosis, which occurs in most tissues except the brain

questions.text: A 78 year old presents to the emergency department due to crushing chest pain. Medical history include hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. After 7 days he is pronounced dead.The microscopic appearance of myocardium section during autopsy is shown in the image. Which of the following mediator produce this appearance?
questions.solution:
In a subacute infarction, granulation tissue formation is stimulated by vascular endothelial growth factor, representing a healing response. Histologic appearance is characterized by blood vessels, edema, and a loose ECM containing inflammatory cells.
