The amount of granulation tissue that is formed depends on the size of the tissue defect created by the wound and the intensity of inflammation.

Option a: Epidermal growth factor aids in re-epithelialization of a surface wound.

Option c: Interleukin-2 (IL-2) mediates lymphocyte activation.

Option d: Leukotriene B4 mediates vasoconstriction and bronchoconstriction.

Educational objective:

Granulation tissue formation is stimulated by vascular endothelial growth factor. Histologic appearance is characterized by capillaries in a loose ECM, with inflammatory cells.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl comes to the office due to an earache for 3 years. Each time on examination, the pain has been accompanied by a red, bulging tympanic membrane, sometimes with a small amount of yellowish exudate. Otoscopy shows a small perforation in the right tympanic membrane and a pearly mass behind the membrane. Conductive hearing loss is noted in the right ear. The girl responds to antibiotic therapy. The likely complications of these events are?
questions.solution:
Cholesteatomas are cystic lesions lined by squamous epithelium. The desquamated epithelium and keratin degenerates, resulting in cholesterol formation and giant cell reaction. They can occur congenitally or may develop in adults either as acquired primary lesion/ secondary to infection.

Cholesteatomas commonly caused painless otorrhea. They can produce lytic enzymes and erode through the auditory ossicles, causing conductive hearing loss. If the mass becomes large it can erode into the vestibular apparatus or facial nerve, causing vertigo or facial palsies.

Incorrect options             

Option A: Facial nerve neuroma can grow in the middle ear, however it present with unilateral facial paralysis.

Option B: Granulomatous disease of the ear is uncommon and usually develops along with systemic diseases.

Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the ear canal. It typically appears as an ulcerated plaque or nodule; with local or regional pain.

Educational objective:

Cholesteatomas are a collection of squamous cell debris that form a mass behind the tympanic membrane. They can erode into the ossicles, labyrinth, adjacent bone, or surrounding soft tissue and sometimes produce visible neck masses.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man came into the emergency department with complaints of severe fatigue lasting over the past few months. He also mentions having swelling that started in the ankles. He also complains of his urine being foamy and dark. He decided to come in now due to the emergence of a rash. Cbc shows a severe increase in microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. His blood results were also positive for antinuclear antibodies and showed markedly raised esr. Upon physical examination, he was noted to be hypertensive with a rash noted over the malar bones and nasal bridge. Further histopathologic testing led to a diagnosis of lupus nephritis. An electron microscopy finding shows electron-dense deposits in mesangial, intramembranous, subendothelial, and subepithelial areas. There is a predominance in deposition noted in the subepithelial regions. There was severe mesangiocapillary proliferation with subendothelial immune deposits seen. Diffuse thickening of capillary walls is seen. Light microscopy demonstrates a “wire-loop” lesion. Which of the following morphological classification of lupus nephritis is likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Minimal Mesangial is the first of 5 types (class I) of morphologic patterns recognized in SLE associated with glomerulonephritis. This is characterized by mesangial cell proliferation and immune complex deposition without the involvement of glomerular capillaries. There is no or slight increase in the mesangial matrix and the number of mesangial matrices.
  2. Mesangial proliferative is the second type (class II) of glomerulonephritis in SLE that is associated primarily in the mesangium along with class 1. This is classified as type II Lupus Nephritis by the WHO. Mesangial cells in renal glomerulus use endocytosis to absorb and degrade circulating immunoglobulins. This normal physiologic process tends to stimulate mesangial cell proliferation and matrix deposition. Hence, in cases of elevated circulating immunoglobulins like in SLE, there would be an increased number of mesangial cells and matrix in the glomerulus. Persistent or recurring microscopic hematuria with mild-moderate proteinuria is commonly noted in this type. Isolated granular deposits of immunoglobulins with scanty subendothelial or subepithelial deposits are always seen on electron microscopy along with complement activation.
  3. Focal Proliferative Glomerulonephritis is the third type of lupus nephritis (Class III). This is seen in 20-35% of patients. Class III is characterized by the involvement of less than 50% of all glomeruli. Usually, one or two foci within an otherwise normal glomerulus may exhibit crescent formation, fibrinoid necrosis, the proliferation of endothelial and mesangial cells, infiltrating leukocytes, and eosinophilic deposits with intracapillary thrombi. These lesions may be segmental or global. Focal glomerulonephritis is usually associated with mild microscopic hematuria and proteinuria. These proliferative inflammatory lesions may heal completely or lead to chronic glomerular scarring. Wire loop lesion can be noted in light microscopy to demonstrate an active disease, which may also be noted in classes IV and V.
  4. Diffuse Proliferative Glomerulonephritis is classified as Class IV. This is the most severe form of Lupus Nephritis. Class IV tends to occur in around 35%-60% of patients. The majority of the pathological glomerular changes tend to be identical to Class III. This includes the proliferation of endothelial, mesangial, and at times epithelial cells. The epithelial cells produce cellular crescents that fill Bowman's space. Generally, the entire glomerulus is affected with possible segmental lesions occurring as well. How class IV differs from class III is based solely on the percentage of glomerular involvement. Class III has the involvement of less than 50% while class IV has more than 50%. Light microscopy of Class IV shows globally increased cellularity, numerous polymorphonuclear cells, cellular crescent, and fibrinoid necrosis which are characteristic of diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis. Wire loop lesion can be noted in light microscopy to demonstrate an active disease, which may be noted in classes III and V.
  5. Class V is namely membranous lupus nephritis which is characterized by diffuse thickening of the capillary walls. This is similar to idiopathic membranous glomerulonephritis. This class is noted in 10-15% of lupus nephritis patients. The affected patients usually have severe proteinuria or nephrotic syndrome and may have occurred concurrently with focal or diffuse lupus nephritis. Granular deposits of antibodies and complements can be detected by immunofluorescence testing. Electron microscopy shows electron-dense deposits in the mesangial in varying degrees, intramembranous, subepithelial, and subendothelial locations. These subendothelial deposits tend to create a homogenous thickening of the capillary wall which is demonstrated by light microscopy as a “wire loop” lesion which may be noted in class III and IV to reflect an active disease. This type is more common in men. In 30-50% of patients, progression to end-stage kidney disease is seen.

Learning Objective: Class V is noted to have thickening of capillary walls. And patients tend to have symptoms of membranous nephropathy, Wire loop lesions are more commonly seen but are also present in class III and V. Also remember, electron-dense deposits seen can be seen in all parts but predominantly in the subepithelial.

questions.text: When innate immunity is to be studied, cells that participate in innate immunity are capable of recognizing certain microbial components that are shared among related microbes and are often essential for infectivity. Collectively, these cellular receptors are often called pattern recognition receptors. The best known among the pattern recognition receptors are the Toll-like receptors. Where are these receptors present in a cell?
questions.solution:
Cells that participate in innate immunity are capable of recognizing certain microbial components that are shared among related microbes and are often essential for infectivity. The best known of pattern recognition receptors is the Toll-like receptors. (TLR). The TLR is present in the plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles.

OTHER OPTIONS:

(b)TLR are not found in the nucleus or nuclear membrane

LEARNING OBJECTIVE: The TLR is present in the plasma membrane and endosomal vesicles.

questions.text: A 53-year-old man presents to the emergency room with complaints of headaches. He claims the pain increases progressively. A prompt CT scan of the head was done and revealed irregularly shaped hypodense lesions with a peripheral ringlike zone of contrast enhancement and a penumbra of cerebral edema. A subsequent MRI of the brain with contrast reveals an irregular mass lesion with peripheral contrast enhancement and central hyperenhancement. A biopsy of the tumor was taken. Histopathology revealed highly malignant astrocytic tumor cells surrounding areas of necrosis. Which of the following geneticmanifestations is seen in this patient?

choices.text: loss of heterozygosity on chromosome arm 10q
loss of NF2 gene on chromosome 22q

questions.solution:
1. Oligodendrogliomas are primary glial brain tumors that are divided into grade II and anaplastic grade III tumors based on the WHO criteria. Affected patients typically have a somewhat less aggressive course and thus patients tend to survive for many years post-onset of symptoms with a mean patient survival of 5-10 years. These are slow-growing tumors originating in the cerebral hemispheres. They usually occur in the cerebral white matter. The densely packed cells with halos of cytoplasm surrounding large round nuclei are characteristic of oligodendrogliomas. Oligodendrogliomas occur in both sexes but have a male predominance with a ratio of 2:1. The majority of cases are noted to be diagnosed with a median age of 40-50 years old. In anaplastic oligodendrogliomas, the combined loss of 1p/19q is a significant predictor of overall survival. Meanwhile, the phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted by chromosome 10(PTEN) is associated with a poor prognosis. Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly present with seizures due to the frequent cortical involvement. Other clinical presentations are nonspecific and are related to focal cerebral dysfunction, and increased intracranial pressure. Based on the WHO classification of CNS tumors, the diagnosis of oligodendrogliomas is made by identifying a diffuse infiltrating glioma with isocitrate dehydrogenase(IDH) mutation and 1p19q codeletion. They are generally well-circumscribed, gelatinous grey masses that are often calcified(70-90% on histology). They also tend to demonstrate frequent focal hemorrhage along with cystic changes. Under microscopy, oligodendroglioma (WHO grade II) appear as regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin surrounded by a halo of cytoplasm that gives a “fried egg” appearance. It also contains a network of anastomosing capillaries that portrays a “chicken wire” appearance. Anaplastic oligodendrogliomas(WHO grade III) on the other hand demonstrate increased cellular density, increased mitotic activity, microvascular proliferation, and necrosis. Nuclear anaplasia is also seen to be common. On CT, tumors are of mixed density with high attenuation areas within the tumor due to the calcification and hemorrhage. MRI finding includes the increased vascularity depicting “chicken wire” network and the tumor does not show any enhancement just like in CT unless the tumor is very aggressive.
  2. Ependymomas are glial tumors that arise from ependymal cells within the CNS. They are thought to arise due to oncogenetic events that transform normal ependymal cells into tumor phenotypes, with some evidence pointing towards radial glia cells being the cell of origin. They tend to occur intracranially in children and intraspinal in adults. Affected patients present with masses in the fourth ventricle that causes progressive lethargy, headache, nausea and vomiting, cranial nerve palsies(mainly CN VI or X palsy), cognitive impairment, and focal/general neurological deficits. In spinal tumors, occipital or cervical pain, paresthesia, neck stiffness and wasting, spastic tetraplegia, or hemiplegia may occur. Ependymomas are classified into 4 divisions based on histological appearance by WHO. are namely: WHO grade I - myxopapillary ependymoma(occurs exclusively in the region of the cauda equina and has a more benign nature) and subependymoma, WHO grade II - ependymoma with cellular, papillary and clear cell variants WHO grade III - RELA fusion-positive ependymoma WHO grade IV - anaplastic ependymoma The intracranial ependymomas present as intraventricular masses with frequent extension into the subarachnoid space most commonly located in the fourth ventricle of the posterior fossa, while the spinal ependymomas present as intramedullary masses arising from the central canal or exophytic masses at the CONUS and cauda equina. CT scan of intracranial ependymoma shows an isodense tumor with minimal to moderate heterogeneous enhancement on contrast. MRI shows perivascular pseudorosettes with tumor cells surrounding vessels are characteristic of ependymomas which are tumors located in the periventricular space or in the spinal cord that may obstruct the flow of CSF. Microscopically, these tumors are characterized by well-differentiated cells with pathognomonic features of the ependymal rosette( a halo or wheel arrangement of tumor cells surrounding an empty central tubule lumen). Perivascular pseudorosette is a common finding that is described by papillary structures composed of tumor cells arranged radially around a central vessel with a clear cytoplasmic region rich in Glial fibrillary acid protein located in between the vessel and tumor cells. In immunochemistry, GFAP is always positive in the cytoplasmic process around the perivascular pseudorosettes, epithelial membrane antigen(EMA) is positive in the luminal surface of the ependymal rosettes. Prognosis is relatively poor due to the tumors presenting surgically difficult locations.
  3. Glioblastomamultiforme is the most common primary brain tumor and the most malignant of glial tumors. Patients affected with GBM commonly present with a slowly progressive neurologic deficit(usually motor weakness), headaches( frequently more severe in the early morning or when waking up), generalized symptoms of increased intracranial pressure, and seizures. Physical examination tends to show changes in personality, mood, mental capacity, and concentration. Focal signs that are noted include hemiparesis, sensory loss, visual loss, and aphasia. The exact etiology is unknown in most cases but suggested causes include genetic factors and occupational hazards. MRI is the study of choice to make the diagnosis. The MRI shows an irregular mass lesion with avid peripheral contrast enhancement and central hyperenhancement, which is due to central necrosis suggestive of high-grade malignancy. Look for the butterfly shape of the lesion because it narrows as it travels through the corpus callosum while crossing the midline. This is a classic imaging finding. On CT scans, they appear as irregularly shaped hypodense lesions with a peripheral ringlike zone of contrast enhancement and a penumbra of cerebral edema. In histopathology, the lesion consists of highly malignant astrocytic tumor cells that surround areas of necrosis, this is known as pseudopalisading. GBM is associated with genetic alterations such as loss of p53 function(25-40% of all cases), increased activity of epidermal growth factor receptor gene(EGFR)(40-50% of all cases), and loss of heterozygosity on the chromosome arm 10q(60-90% of cases). Lumbar punctures are generally contraindicated. GBM has a poor prognosis with a mean survival of 8-10months post-diagnosis. Most diagnosed patients tend to pass away within 2 years. GBM primarily affects adults with a peak incidence at 45-70 years of age and is located most commonly in the cerebral hemispheres. That being said, they may affect the spinal cord and brainstem in children uncommonly. Primary GBM accounts for the majority of cases and has a short clinical history of just 3 months or less. GBM contains the most genetic changes/mutations. GMB occurs more commonly in males than females with a ratio of 3:2.
  4. Meningiomas are a set of tumors that arise contiguously to the meninges. They are non-glial neoplasms that originate from the meningocytes or arachnoid cap cells of the meninges. They tend to occur more commonly in women with a ratio of 2:1 intracranially and 4:1 in the spine. They generally occur in patients of any age but have a higher incidence rate in the aging population after the age of 40 years. If found in younger patients, then an increased suspicion of neurofibromatosis type 2 is noted. It is also more prevalent in Africans compared to Caucasians. Risk factors include obesity and sedentary lifestyles. Affected patients are usually asymptomatic but may present with headaches, paresis, and change in mental status depending on the tumor location. Genetic causes that are implicated in the development of meningiomas include the loss of the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q, which is the most common genetic alteration. Other cytogenetic changes include chromosomal loss of 1p, 3p, 6q, and 14q. A whorled pattern of concentrically arranged spindle cells with calcified psammoma bodies is characteristic of meningiomas. They are the second most common primary intracranial neoplasm. Meningiomas are benign, slow-growing tumors of the meninges. On CT scans, they are seen as dural-based tumors with perilesional edema, hyperostosis, and intratumoral calcifications. On MRI( investigation of choice), they appear as well-circumscribed extra-axial masses with a broad dural base and a dural tail sign(seen in 60-72%). The MRI may also show a “CSF crest” around the tumor indicating its extra-axial location. Upon histopathological findings, it is a lobulated design with meningothelial whorls. An arachnoid plane is also present between the meningioma and the CNS parenchyma.

Learning objective: Meningiomas are slow-growing extra-axial tumors, nonglial neoplasms that originate from meningocytes/arachnoid fap cells of the meninges. They are usually found located anywhere on the meninges. They are found to be more common in African women aged 40 and above. Risk factors include obesity and sedentary lifestyles. Affected patients are usually asymptomatic but may present with headaches. The most common genetic alteration implicated in the development of meningiomas includes the loss of the NF2 gene on chromosome 22q. A whorled pattern of concentrically arranged spindle cells with calcified psammoma bodies is characteristic of meningiomas. MRI is the imaging modality of choice and shows well-circumscribed extra-axial masses with a broad dural base and a dural tail sign.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presented to the emergency room with complaints of severe lower abdominal pain radiating to the flank. He mentions he has not been able to urinate in the past 36 hours. He also claims to have pelvic distention. He has a previous history of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Upon physical examination, a palpable distended bladder is noted along with palpable kidneys. Rectal examination was done and revealed a reduced anal tone with prostatic enlargement. Cbc was normal, serum chemistry studies revealed elevated BUN and creatinine levels. Renal ultrasound confirmed the presence of urinary tract obstruction and dilation of the urinary collecting system of the kidneys. Which of the following is most likely seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
1. Hydronephrosis is defined as the distention of the renal calyces and pelvis due to a buildup of urine. This accumulation occurs as a result of obstruction to the outflow of urine distal to the renal pelvis. The etiology and presentation of hydronephrosis tend to differ in adults and children (including neonates). In adults, calculi, prostatic hypertrophy/carcinoma, and retroperitoneal/pelvic neoplasms are the primary causes of hydronephrosis. In children, however, the majority of cases are accounted for by anatomical abnormalities like a urethral valve, stricture, and stenosis at the ureterovesical or ureteropelvic junction. The obstruction causes an interruption in the flow of urine. This leads to increased ureteral pressure which in turn causes reduced GFR, tubular function, and renal blood flow. The increased ureteral pressure may also cause myelogenous and pyelolymphatic backflow. In acute nephrosis, once corrected, full recovery of the renal function is possible. Meanwhile, in chronic hydronephrosis, the loss of renal function is irreversible even after the correction of the obstruction. More serious renal effects include compression of the papillae, thinning of the parenchyma around the calyces, and coalescence of the septa between calyces. Eventually, the cortical atrophy progresses to the point at which only a thin rim of parenchyma remains. Microscopic changes consist of dilation of the tubular lumen and flattening of the tubular epithelium. Fibrotic changes and increased collagen deposition are observed in the peritubular interstitium. In pregnant women, however, hydronephrosis can be a normal finding as the renal pelvises and calyceal systems may be dilated due to the effects of progesterone and mechanical compression of the ureters at the pelvic brim. These dilations are more commonly seen on the right side. Hydronephrosis is more common in females aged 20-60 years old. Renal calculi remain the most common cause in young adults. In females, gynecological cancers and pregnancy are common causes after renal calculi and meanwhile, in men, obstruction secondary to prostatic hypertrophy and prostate cancer are the major causes of hydronephrosis. Thus, in affected males, the majority are aged over 60 years. In pediatric settings, fetal hydronephrosis is diagnosed via antenatal ultrasound examination that is detected as early as the 12th to 14th week of gestation.
  2. Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma that can lead to renal scarring. The involved bacteria generally tend to have ascended from the lower urinary tract or in some cases via the bloodstream. Affected patients most commonly present with the classic triad of high-grade fever, costovertebral angle pain that is generally unilateral, nausea, and/or vomiting with associated anorexia. In affected young females, gross hematuria may occur. In children aged 2 or less, the most common signs and symptoms include failure to thrive, feeding difficulty, fever, and vomiting. An episode of acute pyelonephritis may lead to significant renal damage, acute kidney injury, abscess formation, sepsis, and multiorgan system failure. The most common bacteria involved are gram-negative bacterias like E. coli. The pathogenesis is explained by the mannose-sensitive adhesins (usually type 1 fimbria) which are present on all E.coli. They allow the bacteria to attach to epithelial cells thus effectively resisting being flushed out by urine flow. The P fimbriae family of adhesins are closely associated with nearly 70-90% of strains for pyelonephritis. Once the E.coli is attached to the epithelium, it triggers an inflammatory response involving 2 receptors, namely glycosphingolipid (GSL) which is the primary receptor, and toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4). The TLR4 is recruited for the release of chemokines. Thus it is understood that the genetic lack of TLR4 would mean the development of an asymptomatic carrier state. Pyelonephritis is more common in females compared to males. In females, the trimodal peak incidence is noted at ages 0-4, 15-34, and over 80 years of age. In males, however, a bimodal peak rate of incidence is noted at ages 0-4 and over 80 years of age. Diagnosis is usually supported by urine culture and urinalysis which shows cloudy urine with positive dipstick for blood, protein, leukocyte esterase, and nitrite. Microscopy of urine shows pyuria. CRP, ESR, and plasma viscosity may be increased. Recent studies have identified procalcitonin as a biological marker in diagnosing acute pyelonephritis in children. Ultrasound is the first line in investigating renal scarring.
  3. calyceal diverticula aka pyelocalyceal diverticulum is congenital outpouching from the renal calyx or pelvis into the renal cortex. These diverticula are lined with transitional cell epithelium. Females are more commonly affected than males with a ratio of 2:1. They have a high incidence of stone formation which is caused by the stagnation of urine. The diverticulum occurs due to a failure of regression of the 3rd and 4th generation ureteric buds as a result of obstructing stones or infections. Calyceal diverticula can be classified into 2 subtypes, type 1 and type 2. Type 1 is more common and affects mostly the minor calyx or infundibulum and is generally asymptomatic. Type 2 however, affects the major calyx and/or the renal pelvis and tends to be larger, symptomatic, and located in the central part of the kidney. Diagnosis is made with contrast CT, where a calyceal diverticulum will have an appearance similar to that of a simple cyst. It is confirmed when the cystic structure fills with contrast material due to the connection with the collecting system. The layering of the contrast is seen within. This differentiates it from renal cysts as cysts do not get filled with contrast.
  4. congenital megacalyces is an incidental find that mimics hydronephrosis. It is usually a result of underdevelopment of the renal medullary pyramids with resultant enlargement of the calyces. It is more frequently seen in males. These enlarged calyces have a predisposition to stasis, infection, and calculus formation. It has an association with congenital megaureter and Schinzel-giedion syndrome. Intravenous urography and CT urography will show enlarged calyces with a flat appearance that lack normal imprint from the papillae. The renal pelvis is of normal size which differentiates it from hydronephrosis. There is often polycalycosis that occurs which shows a crowded and multifaceted appearance with a mosaic-like pattern. Generally, no treatment is required unless complicated by calculus.

Learning objective: Hydronephrosis is defined as the distention of the renal calyces and pelvis due to a buildup of urine. This accumulation occurs as a result of obstruction to the outflow of urine distal to the renal pelvis. The etiology and presentation of hydronephrosis tend to differ in adults and children (including neonates). In adults, calculi, prostatic hypertrophy/carcinoma, and retroperitoneal/pelvic neoplasms are the primary causes of hydronephrosis. In children, however, the majority of cases are accounted for by anatomical abnormalities like a urethral valve, stricture, and stenosis at the ureterovesical or ureteropelvic junction. In pregnant women, however, hydronephrosis can be a normal finding.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of periodic substernal chest pain. The pain radiates down the left arm and goes away when he takes a break. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type 2 diabetes mellitus. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg, and pulse is 85/min with irregular beats. Which of the following is most likely to explain the pathogenetic mechanism of this patient?

choices.text: Ulcerated atherosclerotic plaque with partially obstructive thrombus
Ruptured atherosclerotic plaque with fully obstructive thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 50% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus
Atherosclerotic plaque obstructing 80% of the coronary artery lumen, no thrombus

questions.solution:
He has stable angina from a fixed atherosclerotic coronary obstruction without superimposed thrombosis. It typically becomes clinically observable when coronary artery stenosis reaches 75%.

Incorrect options

Option A: Ulcerated atherosclerotic plaque with a partially obstructive thrombus most likely result in unstable angina or a subendocardial myocardial infarction.

Option B: Ruptured plaque with a fully occlusive thrombosis would be most likely to produce an acute transmural myocardial infarction.

Option C: Atherosclerotic plaque <75% does not produce an imbalance of myocardial oxygen supply and demand sufficient to cause angina.

Educational objective:

Fixed atherosclerotic plaques obstructing >75 % of the lumen of a coronary artery are associated with stable angina.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man undergoes cardiac catheterization and stent placement for severe myocardial infarction. He does well until day 5 of hospitalization, then begins to complain of severe shortness of breath and chest pain. Physical examination reveals heart rate is 130/min, blood pressure is 65/40 mmHg and respiratory rate is 12 /min. He is clearly in distress and shows distant heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure. Which of the following complication is causing these symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient is in shock due to cardiac tamponade secondary to the rupture of the ventricular free wall, which usually occurs 3-7 days after infarction. During this time of the healing process, the lysis of the necrotic myocardium is maximal and most of the infarct has been converted to soft, friable granulation tissue.

Option b: Papillary muscle rupture is a complication that usually occurs 3 - 14 days post-MI. This condition usually presents with acute mitral regurgitation, causing the abrupt onset of heart failure.

Option c: Aneurysm formation may occur post-MI. Ventricular aneurysm formation sequelae include decreased cardiac output, increased risk of arrhythmias, and potential mural thrombus formation with risk of embolization.

Option d: Fibrinous pericarditis occurs 1- 3 days post-MI. This condition usually presents with chest pain that relieves when leaning forward, and a pericardial friction rub on cardiac auscultation.

Educational objective:

Free wall rupture is a complication that occurs 3-7 days after MI and can result in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman is having abdominal pain after 3 episodes of urinary tract infection during the past year. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows 2+ hematuria, 1+ proteinuria, hypercalciuria, and no glucose or ketones. An abdominal contrast CT scan is shown below. Her condition improves after increasing daily intake of fluids. Which renal cystic diseases are most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
In the Medullary sponge kidney (MSK), multiple cystic dilations are present in the inner medullary and papillary collecting ducts. This condition occurs in adults and renal functions are usually normal. Patients usually develop kidney stones, infections, or recurrent hematuria.

The abdominal contrast CT scan shows linear striations radiating into the renal papillae and small cystic collections of contrast material in dilated collecting ducts.

Incorrect options

Option B: Multicystic renal dysplasia occurs sporadically or as part of various genetic syndromes in fetuses and newborns. A multicystic dysplastic kidney is the result of abnormal fetal development of the kidney. The kidney will be consisting of irregular cysts of varying sizes that resemble a bunch of grapes. A multicystic dysplastic kidney will be having no any functions and nothing can be done to save it.

Option C: Urethral atresia produces bladder dilation, hydroureter, and hydronephrosis. This is a rare fetal lower urinary tract obstruction which is characterized by closure or failure to develop an opening in the urethra and that will be resulting in the obstructive uropathy which is presenting in utero as megacystis, oligohydramnios or anhydramnios, and potter sequence.

Option D: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) produces larger cysts that involve the entire kidney, leading to massive splenomegaly.

Educational objective

Medullary sponge kidney represents a defect in the development of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilation of medullary and papillary collecting ducts

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has a fever, abdominal pain, and three episodes of hematuria. On palpation, there is a tender abdominal mass on the right side extending across the midline. His cousin at a younger age also had a similar abdominal mass. An abdominal CT scan shows a large solid mass in the right kidney. A right-sided nephrectomy is performed and histopathology is shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma) is one of the most common childhood neoplasms. Loss of one allele of the Wilms tumor suppressor gene (WT1) leads to genitourinary defects and in the development of Wilms tumor. Microscopically, the classic triphasic combination of blastemal, stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed.

Option a: Renal cell carcinoma is rare in children, and the most common patterns are clear cell, papillary, and chromophobe.

Option b: Transitional cell carcinomas arise in the urothelium in adults.

Option d: Angiomyolipomas may be sporadic or part of the genetic syndrome of tuberous sclerosis.

Educational objective: Wilms tumor, the most common renal neoplasm in children shows WT1 gene mutation. The microscopic pattern resembles the fetal kidney nephrogenic zone.

questions.text: A Caucasian diabetic male presents to the nephrologist with flank pain. Abdominal ultrasound revealed a large mass on the left kidney. An abdominal CT scan revealed a well-defined, heterogeneous large mass originating from the left lower pole with cystic and solid areas. Laboratory studies show hematuria without proteinuria. Which of the following organelle is seen in abundance in the following renal tumor?
questions.solution:
Oncocytoma, benign epithelial cell tumor composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round, benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. It arises from the intercalated cells of collecting ducts.

In gross appearance, the tumors are tan or mahogany brown, relatively homogeneous, and usually well encapsulated with a central scar. Electron microscopy shows eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.

Educational objective:

Oncocytoma, an epithelial benign neoplasm shows eosinophilic cells have numerous mitochondria.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is complaining of fever, rigor, and abdominal pains. She claims the pain was initially localized at the lower abdomen and was associated with urinary frequency and dysuria but has since become more generalized especially radiating to the right loin. She has felt occasional uterine tightening. CTG is reassuring. What is the single most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. Acute fatty liver of pregnancy is usually supported with the finding of low platelets, deranged liver function, hypoglycemia, and raised serum ammonia. AFLP is a rare form of jaundice in pregnancy. It occurs late in pregnancy and is part of the spectrum of disorders related to preeclampsia. This patient does not show any signs to consider AFLP.
  2. The signs and symptoms present in this patient are indicative of acute pyelonephritis. It is more common in pregnancy. Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma that can lead to renal scarring. The involved bacteria generally tend to have ascended from the lower urinary tract or in some cases via the bloodstream. Affected patients most commonly present with the classic triad of high-grade fever, costovertebral angle pain that is generally unilateral, nausea, and/or vomiting with associated anorexia. In affected young females, gross hematuria may occur. In children aged 2 or less, the most common signs and symptoms include failure to thrive, feeding difficulty, fever, and vomiting. An episode of acute pyelonephritis may lead to significant renal damage, acute kidney injury, abscess formation, sepsis, and multiorgan system failure. The most common bacteria involved are gram-negative bacterias like E. coli. The pathogenesis is explained by the mannose-sensitive adhesins (usually type 1 fimbria) which are present on all E.coli. They allow the bacteria to attach to epithelial cells thus effectively resisting being flushed out by urine flow. The P fimbriae family of adhesins are closely associated with nearly 70-90% of strains for pyelonephritis. Once the E.coli is attached to the epithelium, it triggers an inflammatory response involving 2 receptors, namely glycosphingolipid (GSL) which is the primary receptor, and toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4). The TLR4 is recruited for the release of chemokines. Thus it is understood that the genetic lack of TLR4 would mean the development of an asymptomatic carrier state. Pyelonephritis is more common in females compared to males. In females, the trimodal peak incidence is noted at ages 0-4, 15-34, and over 80 years of age. In males, however, a bimodal peak rate of incidence is noted at ages 0-4 and over 80 years of age. Diagnosis is usually supported by urine culture and urinalysis which shows cloudy urine with positive dipstick for blood, protein, leukocyte esterase, and nitrite. Microscopy of urine shows pyuria. CRP, ESR, and plasma viscosity may be increased. Recent studies have identified procalcitonin as a biological marker in diagnosing acute pyelonephritis in children. Ultrasound is the first line in investigating renal scarring.
  3. Round ligament stretching may explain the loin pain but does not explain the fever. And infection is more likely to be present in this patient.
  4. Cholecystitis is not correct as it would present with epigastric pain. This patient's pain originated in the lower abdomen and radiated to the right loin. Therefore the involvement of the gallbladder is highly unlikely in this patient.

Learning objective: Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma that can lead to renal scarring. The involved bacteria generally tend to have ascended from the lower urinary tract or in some cases via the bloodstream. Affected patients most commonly present with the classic triad of high-grade fever, costovertebral angle pain that is generally unilateral, nausea, and/or vomiting with associated anorexia. The most common bacteria involved are gram-negative bacterias like E. coli.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female presents to the emergency room with fever, dysuria, suprapubic pain, nausea, and vomiting. Her past medical history is significant for uncontrolled diabetes. Upon physical examination, she is found to be febrile, tachycardia, and grossly unwell. Tenderness is noted on palpation of the right costovertebral angle. Urine culture was positive for E. coli. A diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis is made. What is the primary receptor involved when E. coli triggers an inflammatory response?

choices.text: DC associated C-type lectin type 1 receptors (dectin)

questions.solution:
1. Glycosphingolipid (GSL) is the primary receptor for E. coli infections as seen in this patient.
  2. Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) is also seen in this patient due to E. coli infection but it is not the primary receptor. TLR4 is recruited for the release of chemokines.
  3. DC-associated C-type lectin type 1 receptors (dectin) is involved when triggered by a broad range of fungal pathogens like C.albicans, Aspergillus fumigatus, and Pneumocystis carinii.
  4. Retinoic acid-inducible gene I (RIG-I)-like receptors (RLRs are key receptors of virus infection, mediating the transcriptional induction of type I interferons and other genes that collectively establish an antiviral host response.

Learning objective: Acute Pyelonephritis is a bacterial infection of the renal parenchyma that can lead to renal scarring. The involved bacteria generally tend to have ascended from the lower urinary tract or in some cases via the bloodstream. Affected patients most commonly present with the classic triad of high-grade fever, costovertebral angle pain that is generally unilateral, nausea, and/or vomiting with associated anorexia. The most common bacteria involved are gram-negative bacterias like E. coli.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency room with diffuse abdominal pain. The pain was of sudden onset, sharp and colicky with progressing intensity. The pain was exacerbated by lifting the right leg and relieved by leaning forwards. The patient did not smoke, drink occasionally, and denied drug use. Physical examination reveals rebound tenderness in the right lower quadrant. Laparotomy reveals the following findings



The first event in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition is?
questions.solution:
An inflamed hyperemic and edematous appendix, along with periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant, suggests acute appendicitis.

Acute appendicitis is initiated by a progressive increase in intraluminal pressure that compromises venous outflow. In most cases, acute appendicitis is associated with luminal obstruction, usually caused by a small mass of stool, or fecalith. Peri-appendiceal lymphoid hyperplasia and the resulting compression have also been proposed as a mechanism of venous and luminal obstruction. Stasis of luminal contents allows bacterial proliferation that leads to ischemia and inflammation.

Incorrect options

Option A and C: Venous thrombosis and atrial spasm can cause mesenteric ischemia. Venous thrombosis isthrombosis in a vein which is caused by a thrombus. A common form of venous thrombosis is deep vein thrombosis, when there is a blood clot which is formed in the deep veins. If a thrombus breaks off and flows towards the lungs, it can become a pulmonary embolism.

Option B: Peptic ulceration is seen in the development of lower intestinal bleeding due to Meckel's diverticulum. Peptic ulcers areopen sores that will be developing on the inner lining of our stomach and the upper portion of our small intestine. The most common symptom of a peptic ulcer is the occurrence of stomach pain.

Educational objective

Obstruction of the lumen of the appendix is the first event in the pathogenesis of acute appendicitis. Fecaliths, hyperplastic lymphoid follicles, foreign bodies, or tumors may cause the obstruction. Right lower quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and fever are other typical manifestations of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old white male presents with concern due to the increasing severity and frequency of his acid reflux symptoms. The patient describes symptoms as burning in his upper and middle chest, as well as a sour taste in his mouth over the last several months. He has experienced the symptoms of acid reflux intermittently from his 20s, and more consistent symptoms over the last 10 years. He undergoes upper gastrointestinal endoscopy. Microscopic findings on an esophageal biopsy are shown below. The patient is at increased risk of developing?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Barrett's esophagus requires endoscopic evidence of metaplastic columnar mucosa above the gastroesophageal junction. Microscopically, intestinal-type metaplasia is seen as a replacement of the squamous esophageal epithelium with goblet cells.

Genomic sequencing of Barrett's esophagus biopsies has revealed the presence of pathogenic mutations in cancer genes that are also found in esophageal adenocarcinoma. A pre-invasive neoplastic change is associated with prolonged symptoms, longer segment length, increased patient age, and Caucasian race.

Option a: The pathogenesis of Crohn's disease includes genetic factors and immunologic hyperactivity.

Option b: Esophageal varices develop in the setting of high portal venous pressure, due to alcoholic or post-viral liver cirrhosis.

Option c: Achalasia is an esophageal motility disorder caused by the loss of ganglion cells of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES).

Educational objective: Barrett's esophagus is intestinal metaplasia of the esophageal epithelium. It occurs in GERD and is the most important risk factor for the development of esophageal adenocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 30 years old 4 month pregnant female comes to your clinic with complaints of dysuria and fever, it was diagnosed as a case of Urinary Tract Infection, which of the following medications should be avoided in this Patient?
questions.solution:
Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum tetracycline-class antibiotic. Treat­ment of pregnant patients with tetracyclines may produce discoloration of the teeth in their children.

Option A - Amoxicillin is used in most uncomplicated urinary tract infections that is caused by Enterobacteriaceae, and E. coli (most common species). Aminopenicillins can be effective agents for urinary tract infections, but the high prevalence of resistance amongst E. coli and Klebsiella makes empiric use of these drugs for urinary tract infections challenging.

Option B – Penicillin G

Penicillin G (IV), penicillin V (PO); IM depot formulations (benzathine, procaine) are used effectively in the treatment of Syphilis. Excellent activity vs. Treponema pallidum, β-hemolytic streptococci, N. meningitidis, gram-positive anaerobes.

Option C –Cephalexin comes under the class of 1st Generation Cephalosporin useful antibacterial activity against Streptococci , Staphylococcus aureus andsome Proteus, E. coli & Klebsiella.
 

Learning Objectives: Tetracyclines and glycylcyclines inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S bacterial ribosome. These drugs enter gram-negative bacteria by passive dif­fusion through channels formed by porins in the outer cell membrane and by active transport that pumps tetracyclines across the cytoplasmic membrane. Tetracyclines are bacteriostatic antibiotics with activity against a wide range of bacteria. Tetracyclines intrinsically are more active against gram-positive than gram-negative microorganisms

questions.text: A 52 year old women underwent kidney transplant 2 months ago. She was under Immunomodulators for her Rejection prophylaxis.Upon examination her Blood Pressure was 140/80 mmhg, Pulse rate was 80/min.Physical Examination revealed swollen gums. Her Laboratory workup shows serum hyperlipidemia. Which of the following drugs is the cause of this adverse effect in this patient ?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine is a commonly used immunomodulation agent, it acts by inhibition of Calcineurin (inhibits phosphatase activity) .Calcineurin catalysed dephosphorylation is required for movement of a component of the NFAT (nuclear factor of activated T lymphocytes) into the nucleus. NFAT, in turn, is required to induce number of cytokine genes, including IL-2, a prototypic T-cell growth and differentiation factor.

The principal adverse reactions to cyclosporine therapy are renal dysfunction and hypertension; tremor, hirsutism, hyperlipidemia, and gum hyperplasia also frequently encountered. Hypertension occurs in about 50% of renal transplant and almost all cardiac trans­plant patients.

Cyclosporine, as opposed to tacroli­mus, is more likely to produce elevations in LDL cholesterol.

Option A:Like cyclosporine, tacrolimus inhibits T-cell activation by inhibiting calcineurin. The adverse reactions of tacrolimus includes nephrotoxicity; neurotoxicity (e.g., tremor, headache, motor disturbances, seizures); GI complaints; hypertension; hyperkalemia; hyperglycemia; and diabetes all are associated with tacrolimus use.

Option C:Prednisolone is a Glucocorticoid,

Broad effects on cellular immunity

  • Affects transcription of many genes; ↓ NF-κB activation, ↓ pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1 and IL-6
  • ↓ T-cell proliferation, cytotoxic T-lymphocyte activation and neutrophil and monocyte function.
  • Can cause ↑ blood glucose, hypertension, Cushingoid habitus, ↑ weight, ↑ risk of infection, osteoporosis, glaucoma, cataracts, depression, anxiety, psychosis.
  • Long-term treatment causes adrenal suppression; withdraw slowly on alternate days.

Option D:Sirolimus is an Antiproliferative and Antimetabolic Agent, mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin ) inhibitor, used in prophylaxis of organ transplant rejection, incorporated into stents to inhibit occlusion.

Learning Objectives: Immunosuppressive drugs are used to dampen the immune response in Organ transplantation and autoimmune disease. In transplantation, major classes of immunosuppressive drugs used today are the following:

  • Glucocorticoids
  • Calcineurin inhibitors
  • Antiproliferative/antimetabolic agents
  • Biologicals (antibodies)

questions.text: A 10 year old male child is brought in emergency with complaint of fever, headache, and confused state of mind. There is history of severe allergic reaction 5 years back due to injection penicillin. Presently he is investigated and his CBC shows the following: Hemoglobin: 8.5.0 g%, RBC count: 2.2 million/ mm3, platelets: 88,000/mmm3, leukocyte count: 2100/ mm3 Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for causing this reaction?
questions.solution:
As the CBC shows decreased counts of erythrocytes, leukocytes, and platelets, this is called pancytopenia or aplastic anemia. This occurs because of suppression of stem cells in bone marrow.

Common causes include radiation exposure, toxins (e.g. arsenics, benzene), certain infections, drugs. Chloramphenicol is one such drug that can cause aplastic anemia. The mechanism of action of chloramphenicol is inhibition of peptidyl transferase enzyme when it binds to 50s ribosomal subunit. This leads to inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis. It can be both dose dependent and dose independent. Dose dependent anemia is reversible if the drug is stopped but dose independent anemia is usually severe and can be fatal.

Choice A: Clindamycin is active against Bacteroides and gram positive cocci. The most common side effect of clindamycin is pseudomembranous colitis.

Choice B: Gentamicin adverse effects are ototoxicity (both vestibular and cochlear), nephrotoxicity, and neuromuscular paralysis.

Choice D: Vancomycin when given rapidly, it causes flushing called redman syndrome. It also causes ototoxicity.

Educational objective: Aplastic anemia can be caused by radiation, toxins and drugs. Chloramphenicol can cause both dose dependent and dose independent anemia.

questions.text: A 49-year-old, 65 kg male had a frontal craniotomy for excision of an astrocytoma after presenting with increasing bifrontal headaches. Patient was induced giving an intravenous and inhalational anesthesia with a skeletal muscle relaxant. Procedure went uneventful. However, after 30 mins of arrival in recovery room. Patient developed generalized tonic-clonic seizures which was controlled by anti-epileptic drug. Patient was discharged on 10th post-operative day without any further episode of seizures. Which of the following drug is responsible for GTCS in this patient?
questions.solution:
Here, the patient developed post-operative seizures due to injection of a skeletal muscle relaxant – atracurium. Atracurium is an intermediate-acting isoquinoline nondepolarizing muscle relaxant that no longer in widespread clinical use. In addition to hepatic metabolism, atracurium is inactivated by form of spontaneous breakdown known asHofmann elimination. The main breakdown products arelaudanosineand related quaternary acid, neither of which possesses neuromuscular blocking properties. Laudanosine is slowly metabolized by liver and has longer elimination half-life (ie, 150 minutes). readily crosses the blood-brain barrier and high blood concentrations may cause seizures and an increase in volatile anesthetic requirement.

Other options-

[A]. Rocunorium- is a fast-acting non-depolarising skeletal muscle relaxant and used in endotracheal intubation.

[B]. Succinylcholine- can cause increase in intracranial pressure intraocular pressure. It can lead to malignant hyperthermia and hyperkalemia in patients with nerve and muscular disorders.

[C]. Gantacurium- represents a new class of nondepolarizing neuromuscular blockers, called asymmetric mixed-onium chlorofumarates. At higher doses, cardiovascular adverse effects (eg, hypotension) have occurred, probably due to histamine release. No bronchospasm or pulmonary vasoconstriction reported at these higher doses.

Educational objectives-Atracurium is a non-depolarizing skeletal muscle relaxant which under spontaneous elimination and forms laudanosine which accumulates in CNS and causes seizures.

questions.text: A 6 years old boy presented with multiple episodes of seizures with behavioral disturbances for past 2 years. On examination, patient has a low intelligent quotient [IQ] with a slow spike and wave pattern on EEG. Which of the following drug is likely to be beneficial in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, patient is having Lennox-Gastaut syndrome [LGS] which is characterized by triad of-

  1. Multiple types of generalized seizures, which are difficult to control.
  2. Slowness of intellectual growth, often accompanied by mental retardation and behavioral problems.
  3. A specific electroencephalogram (EEG) pattern called a slow spike-and-wave pattern (< 2.5 Hz), which is present when the child is awake.

Rufinamide is effective for atonic seizures in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome, but there is also some evidence of efficacy in the treatment of focal seizures. In the USA and Europe, rufinamide is only approved for treatment of seizures associated with the Lennox-Gastaut syndrome. Mechanism of action include blocking of voltage-gated sodium channels. Most drug-drug interactions are minor except that valproate may decrease the clearance of rufinamide; dosing with valproate, particularly in children, may need to be decreased, typically by 50%. Adverse effects include sedation, fatigue, dizziness, ataxia, diplopia, leucopenia andQT prolongation.

Other options-

[A]. Ethosuximide- is used in treatment of generalized absence seizures. It can be used as monotherapy unless generalized tonic-clonic seizures are also present, in which case valproate is preferred or ethosuximide can be combined with another drug effective against generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

[B]. Carbamazepine- is effective for the treatment of focal and focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures. Carbamazepine is also effective for the treatment of trigeminal and glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and mania in bipolar disorder.

[C]. Phenytoin- is effective in preventing focal onset seizures and also tonic-clonic seizures, whether they are focal-to-bilateral tonic clonic (secondarily generalized). Phenytoin may worsen other seizure types in primary generalized epilepsies, including absence epilepsy, juvenile myoclonic epilepsy, and Dravet’s syndrome.

Educational objectives- Rufinamide is a voltage gated sodium channel blocker used in treatment of seizures in Lennox-Gastaut syndrome especially atonic seizures.

questions.text: A 35 year old male came in the outdoor clinic with complaint of right knee pain and swelling for last 12 hours. On examination his knee is swollen and red. Synovial fluid analysis shows increased white blood count of 100,000/ mm3. The best initial treatment of this patient is :
questions.solution:
In young patients, acute monoarticular arthritis is most commonly of septic arthritis type. Gonococcus is most common organism. Although acute monoarticular arthritis is also caused by gout and pseudo gout, but white blood count in the synovial fluid is generally < 20,000/ m3. Definitive diagnosis is made by Gram stain, culture, and microscopy for crystals. While other test results are pending, ceftriaxone should be given to cover gonococcus.

Choice A: Colchicine decreases acute inflammation in gout, by inhibiting neutrophil migration into the involved area.

Choice B: Indomethacin is an NSAID that can relief pain, but it is not best initial treatment. It can also be given for non infectious inflammatory arthritis.

Choice D: Allopurinol is an isomer of hypoxanthine. It lowers serum uric acid levels. Allopurinol cannot treat acute attacks but can prevent acute gouty arthritis.

Educational objective: A high synovial fluid white blood count (100,000/ mm3) and absence of crystals in the fluid strongly suggest bacterial joint infection. Immediate antibiotic treatment is needed so that joint destruction, osteomyelitis and sepsis can be avoided.

questions.text: A 63 years old male came to your clinic with complaints of myalgia. On physical examination ,there is no weakness or loss of sensation, the patient’s vitals are Blood Pressure of 130/80, Heart rate- 86/min, Further history revealed that the patient suffered an Heart Attack an year ago and under medication. Which of the following combination of drugs are responsible for the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Atorvastatin is an HMG-CoA-Reductase inhibitor, the major adverse effects are Myopathy and rhabdomyolysis (disintegration of skeletal muscle; rare) have been reported.

In most cases of rhabdomyolysis, patients had renal insufficiency, vitamin D deficiency,hypothyroidism, advanced age, were female, or were taking drugs that increase the risk of muscle adverse effects, such as azole antifungals, protease inhibitors, cyclosporine, erythromycin, gemfibrozil, or niacin.

Option A: Niacin strongly inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue, thereby reducing production of free fatty acids, it can be used in combination with other lipid lowering agents and no adverse effects are reported when used along with ezetimibe

Option C: Cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrants.Cholestyramine is anion-exchange resins that bind negatively charged bile acids and bile salts in the small intestine.The resin/bile acid complex is excreted in the feces, thus lowering the bile acid concentration. It has shown no adverse effect when combined with Rosuvastatin.

Option D:No adverse effect was found till now when Niacin is used in combination with gemfibrozil.

Learning Objectives: Reduction of LDL-C is the primary goal of cholesterol-lowering therapy. According to cholesterol guidelines, the need for antihyperlipidemic drug therapy should be determined based on an assessment of risk for Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.

questions.text: A 10 year old female has history of repetitive episodes of lower lobe pulmonary infiltrates, longstanding malabsorption and steatorrhea, and abnormally high chloride levels in sweat. An aerosol that contains N acetylcysteine is given to the patient for intermittent inhalation. Role of N acetylcysteine is:
questions.solution:
This is a case of cystic fibrosis (CF). In CF, there is decreased secretion of chloride and increased absorption of sodium in mucosa of pulmonary airways. This results in dehydration of the inner surfaces of trachea and bronchi and abnormal thickening of secreted mucus. Hyper viscosity of mucus in the small airways causes decreased mucus clearance leading to mucus plugging. This causes obstruction and infection. N acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent. It cleave the disulfide bonds of glycoproteins present in the mucus. This leads to thinning of mucus and its easy clearance.

Educational objective: N acetylcysteine breaks the disulfide bonds of glycoproteins present in the mucus. This leads to thinning of mucus and its easy clearance. N acetylcysteine is used in treatment of CF.

questions.text: An 81 year old male who is known case of coronary artery disease, hypertension and dementia came with complaint of abdominal discomfort and pain. Similar episodes of abdominal pain has occurred in the past with no other symptoms. There has been no bowel movement in past 5 days. There is no history of diarrhea and rectal bleeding. The patient is mainly bed ridden with minimal activity with help of nurse. He has undergone colonoscopy examinations in past which showed only benign lesion. Abdominal examination shows non tender distension. There is no mass or hepatomegaly or splenomegaly. Patient is given polyethylene glycol and passes stool in 24 hours. Mechanism of action of polyethylene glycol is similar to pathophysiology of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
Elderly, debilitated patients commonly suffer from constipation. Such patients are treated with osmotic laxatives (e.g. Magnesium citrate, polyethylene glycol), stool softeners and enemas. Lifestyle modification cannot be done in such elderly bed ridden patients.

Osmotic laxatives are non-absorbable substances. In intestinal lumen, they extract the water into the intestinal lumen, distending intestinal wall and increasing peristalsis. Magnesium hydroxide, magnesium citrate are other laxatives although its effects are still under investigation.

In Lactase deficiency, there is deficiency of lactase enzyme in brush border epithelium of intestine. This leads to no breakage of lactose into glucose and galactose. Lactose being a non-absorbable substance, causes accumulation of water in the intestinal lumen. Accumulated lactose is acted upon by gut flora and fermented resulting in gas production. Symptoms of lactase deficiency are abdominal pain ,distension and watery diarrhea. Such patient needs diet free from milk products.

Choice A: Irritable bowel syndrome is characterized by diarrhea alternating with constipation, abdominal pain, and distension. It is a functional disorder with no organic cause. Fecal water and electrolyte content are normal.

Choice C: In carcinoid syndrome, there is secretory diarrhea with high electrolyte content.

Choice D: In Crohn’s disease, there is intestinal inflammation that causes increased water loss and poor absorption. This results in secretory diarrhea with high electrolyte content.

Educational objective: Polyethylene glycol is an osmotic laxative. In lactase deficiency, accumulation of osmotic substance lactulose occurs, which causes diarrhea.

questions.text: A 35 years old male walks into your clinic with complaints of headache. His Blood Pressure was 170/100, Heart Rate 86/min. Laboratory findings revealed Hypokalemia . An Abdominal CT was done as shown in the image. Which of the following drug is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from Aldosterone secreting Adenoma leading to Primary hyperaldosteronism also known as Conn’s Syndrome. Eplerenone is an aldosterone receptor antagonists, it reduce potassium loss in the urine.Eplerenone have fewer adverse effect than Spirinolactone.

Option A: Propranolol is a Non-selective beta blocker, it is not used in the treatment of Conn’s Syndrome.

Option B: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker, will reduce the bloodpressure causing vasodilation, will not be an effective treatment in Hyperaldosteronism.

Option C:Amilodipine is a Calcium Channel Blocker, may only reduce the blood pressure temporarily but not an effective treatment for Hyperaldosteronism.

Learning Objectives: The signs of hyperaldosteronism are Hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis and decreased plasma renin concentration. Aldosterone causes reabsorption of sodium & water and wasting of potassium & hydrogen ions at the distal portion of the nephrons.

questions.text: A 52 year old male with known case of disseminated histoplasmosis is put on treatment with amphotericin B. He came with complaint of weakness and palpitations. ECG was done which showed premature ventricular beats and drug toxicity is suspected. Which of the following is most related to the new signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is most common drug given in systemic fungal infections. Amphotericin B decreases glomerular filtration rate leading to nephrotoxicity. It also directly damages tubular epithelium. Nephrotoxicity causes anemia and electrolyte imbalances. Increased membrane permeability of distal tubules causes hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia. Hypokalemia then can lead to arrhythmias and weakness. ECG changes include T wave flattening, ST segment depression, prominent U waves, and premature atrial and ventricular contractions. Severe hypokalemia causes ventricular tachycardia and fibrillations.

Choice A: Amphotericin B is not hepatotoxic. Halothane and Acetaminophen cause liver necrosis.

Choice B: Bone marrow suppression does not cause ECG changes. Chloramphenicol, phenylbutazone, zidovudine and gold-containing medications are associated with bone marrow suppression.

Choice D: Busulphan and Bleomycin causes pulmonary fibrosis and pulmonary hypertension.

Educational objective: Amphotericin B causes renal dysfunction leading to hypokalemia. This further causes ECG changes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man, suffered a myocardial infarction . After that he was hospitalized for the same ailment .He is now being treated with warfarin (among other drugs). What is the main mechanism by which warfarin is causing the effects for which it is given?

choices.text: Increase in the plasma level of Factor IX
Inhibition of thrombin and early coagulation steps
Inhibition of synthesis/activation of prothrombin and Factors VII, IX, and X

questions.solution:
Warfarin is a coumarin derivative that is generally used for long-term anticoagulation, and is wholly unsuitable for immediate anticoagulation because it takes at least 5 days of administration for meaningful inhibition of prothrombin time (reported as the International Normalized Ratio [INR]) to develop and stabilize. It antagonizes the gamma carboxylation of several glutamate residues in prothrombin and the coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X. All other options are incorrect.

Option A- Increase in the plasma level of Factor IX can be done by infusing fresh frozen plasma. Fresh frozen plasma contains all clotting factors , fibrinogen , plasma proteins , electrolytes , protein C and S, antithrombin and tissue factor pathway inhibitors.

Option B -Inhibition of thrombin is seen with Bivalirudin , Argatroban and Dabigatran . This class is used in treatment of venous thromboembolism and atrial fibrillation. No Lab monitoring is required.

Option C -Activation of plasminogen directly or indirectly is aided by thrombolytics( like Alteplase,reteplase , streptokinase , tenecteplase) , which cleave thrombin and fibrin clots . Used in early MI , early ischemic stroke and in direct thrombolysis of severe PE.

Summary -The process is coupled to the oxidative deactivation of vitamin K. The reduced form of vitamin K is essential for sustained carboxylation and synthesis of the coagulation proteins. It appears that warfarin inhibits the action of the reductase(s) that regenerate the reduced form of vitamin K. The prevention of the inactive vitamin K epoxide from being reduced to the active form of vitamin K results in decreased carboxylation of the proteins involved in the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: A 10 yr old boy was brought to the ER with the H/O fever, headache and malaise since 3 days. The patient became unresponsive on day 2, and examination revealed a Glasgow scale of 14/15 with no focal deficit. The CSF findings on day 8 was remarkable with turbidity, elevated protein and leukocyte levels. There was also presence of motile amoeboid trophozoites. The boy died on day 12. CSF cultivated on non-nutrient agar with E coli showed a trail on culture. There was a recent H/O of travel to Australia where he engaged in water sports in a lake. What could be the most possible causative organism?
questions.solution:
Naegleria is a free living amoeba which is found in warm fresh water such as ponds, lakes, river and hot springs. It exists in 2 forms- 1.cysts, 2.trophozoite. trophozoite occurs in 2 forms amoeboid and flagellated form. The infective form is the amoeboid form which is invasive. Naegleriafowleri causes acute suppurative fulminant infection of CNS known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. Mode of transmission is by nasal contamination during swimming in ponds or rivers.

Treatment - amphotericin B has considerable anti- Naeglerial effect.

Incorrect options

Option A; Acantamoeba culbertsoni exists as cyst and trophozoite form unlike Naegleria fowleri it doesn’t have flagellated form. It causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis(GAE) in immune-compromised patients. Mode of transmission is by inhalational route due to contaminated aerosols, or direct skin or through broken skin or infected eye.

Option B; Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free living amoeba which causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis(GAE). It has a trophozoite and cyst form. There is no flagellated form. Mode of transmission - It enters the body through respiratory tract or open wounds.

Option D; Taenia solium is also known as pork tapeworm which causes intestinal taeniasis and cysticercosis in man. Host man acts as a definitive host and pig is the intermediate host. Entamoeba histolytica – exists in 3 stages –

  1. trophozoite,
  2. Precyst,
  3. Cyst .

It completes it’s life cycle in a single host i.e man. The infective form is mature quadri-nucleated cyst. Mode of transmission is faeco-oral route.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

Naegleria fowleri – Naegleria is a free-living amoeba which is found in warm fresh water such as ponds, lakes, river and hot springs. It exists in 2 forms- 1.cysts, 2.trophozoite. trophozoite occurs in 2 forms amoeboid and flagellated form. The infective form is the amoeboid form which is invasive. Naegleria fowleri causes acute suppurative fulminant infection of CNS known as primary amoebic meningoencephalitis(PAM)

questions.text:
A 3 yr old boy was brought to the emergency department with sudden difficulty in breathing since 5-6 hrs. There is a 2 day history of sore throat and fever. On examination enlarged bilateral tonsils with exudates was seen. Petechiae on palate and cervical lymphadenopathy was also seen. On day 8 he developed maculopapular rash which was associated with rise in temperature. Investigations revealed the following findings:-


	Blood investigation revealed monocytosis, lymphocytosis and thrombocytosis.
	Monospot test was positive
	Culture on Loeffler’s serum slope-negative.


Which of the following cells are likely to be infected in this condition?
questions.solution:
B-cells – Epstein-Barr virus binds to specific receptors CD21 or CR2 present on B-cells. Following entry into B-cells it enters a latent stage. Majority of infected cells are eliminated but small number of infected cells persist for a lifetime. Infected B-cells become immortalised by the virus and synthesize immunoglobulins which are auto-antibodies. Persistent Epstein-Barr virus infection can induce malignant transformation of B-cells.

INCORRECT OPTION:

OPTION A;Dendritic cells – are specialised antigen presenting cells. They originate from bone marrow. They possess long membranous cytoplasmic extensions resembling dendrites of neurons. Some of the dendritic cells are langherhans cells, interstitial dendritic cells, follicular dendritic cells, circulating dendritic cells.

OPTION B;NK-cells – They are also known as large granular lymphocytes and play important role in innate immune system. It plays an important role in immunity against virus and immune surveillance of tumours.

OPTION C;Mast cells – contain granules rich in histamine, acid hydrolases etc. It is mainly involved in type 1 hypersensitivity.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE-

Epstein-Barr virus binds to specific receptors CD21 or CR2 present on B-cells. Following entry into B-cells it enters a latent stage. Majority of infected cells are eliminated but small number of infected cells persist for a lifetime. Infected B-cells become immortalised by the virus and synthesize immunoglobulins which are auto- antibodies.

questions.text:
A 65 yr old diabetic patient was brought to the ER with complaints of fever, purulent rhinorea and confusion since 3 days. On examination black necrotic eschar was seen on the nasal turbinates. The investigations revealed the following findings:-

 Random blood sugar – 327 mg/dl

 HBA1C – 9.1%

 Complete blood picture showed a WBC count of 25000/micro litre

Histopathological examination of biopsy specimen with grocott-gomori methenamine silver stains showed broad ribbon like non septate right wide angled branching hyphae.

 Culture on SDA shows cotton woolly colonies filling the entire SDA plate. The colonies later turned brown black due to sporulation.



Identify the organism responsible in this case?
questions.solution:
Rhizopus – the history suggestive of rhinocerebralmucormycosis. Histopathological examination showing aseptate hyaline hyphae with wide angled branching along with culture showing cotton woolly colonies. The colonies later turned brown- black giving it a salt pepper appearance which is seen in rhizopus.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION B;Fusarium – is a filamentous fungi which produces woolly colonies spreading white to pink. LPCB of the colony shows hyaline septate hyphae with round conidia and sickle shaped macro conidia. It causes keratitis in contact lens wearers.

OPTION C;Aspergillus fumigatus – it shows narrow septate hyaline hyphae with acute angle branching. Colonies on SDA is seen as smoky green velvety to powdery appearance.

OPTION D; Aspergillus flavus – colonies are yellow green velvety on SDA which incubated on 25*C. Aspergillus flavus is unique in that it is a thermotolerant fungus, so can survive at temperatures that other fungi cannot.

Educational objective- Rhinocerebral mucormycosis is seen most commonly in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis. Acidosis causes release of iron from the sequestered proteins in serum, and agents causing mucormycosis require iron as a growth factor.

questions.text: A 7 yr old was brought to the dental OPD with pain in the tooth, swelling in the right cheek. The child complains of sensitivity of the tooth and fever associated with the swelling. The child was diagnosed to have Ludwig’s Angina and was treated with broad spectrum antibiotics. Gram culture from the site of the lesion showed gram positive cocci in long chains, insoluble in bile and resistant to optochin. What could be the likely associated condition be?
questions.solution:
Dental caries is caused by Streptococcal mutans. It mainly acts by breaking down sucrose to acid and dextrans. The acid formed damages the dentine and dextrans binds with food debris and bacteria to form dental caries.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION A; Apthous ulcer, are also known as canker sores. It is characterised by formation of benign non contagious mouth ulcers in healthy individuals. It is associated with nutritional deficiencies, local trauma and stress with hormonal influences.

OPTION B; Leukoplakia is seen as a white patch on the mucous membrane on the roof of the mouth tongue and gums. It is common in smokers. It is considered to be a pre-malignant condition.

OPTION D; Lichen planus – is an inflammatory condition characterised by itchy rash on the arms and legs. They may be covered with thin white streaks wickham’s striae.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE-Dental caries is caused by Streptococcal mutans. It mainly acts by breaking down sucrose to acid and dextrans. The acid formed damages the dentine and dextrans binds with food debris and bacteria to form dental caries

questions.text: A 35 yr old man presents to the dermatology and venerealogy clinic with painful, vesicular lesions seen in groups on the shaft of penis since 6 days. There is a history of unprotected sexual contact. On examination painful enlarged inguinal lymph nodes were felt. Scraping from the base of the lesion was stained by Giemsa stain which showed ballooning of cells and formation of multi nucleated giant cell. What will be the most appropriate treatment for the patient in this case?
questions.solution:
Valacyclovir – It is used for the treatment of herpes zoster and genital herpes. After oral administration valacyclovir is readily absorbed via human peptide transporter 1 and is rapidly converted to acyclovir during hydrolysis in liver by an enzyme valacyclovirhyrolase.

Incorrect option;

Option A; Ribavarin – acts by altering the cellular nucleotide pools, inhibits viral RNA synthesis and causes lethal mutagenesis of RNA virus genomes. Aerosol administration of ribavarin is more effective than parenteral administration and is used for treatment of respiratory syncytial virus bronchiolitis and pneumonia.

Option B; Oseltamivir –It is a specific neuroaminidase inhibitor of influenza A and B viruses. It is used in the prophylaxis of H1N1.

Option C; Lamivudine – is approved for treatment of HIV and chronic hepatitis B infection. It belongs to the class of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTIs).

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Valacyclovir is a nucleoside analogue antiviral agent and a pro-drug of acyclovir. It is used for the treatment of herpes zoster and genital herpes

questions.text:
A 60 yr old presents to the ENT OPD with C/O of burning sensation in the throat since 5 days. On oral examination, white curdled milk-like patches on the palate and tonsils was seen. There is a past H/O admission in ICU with complaints of drowsiness, vomiting and abdominal pain 1 month back. The patient was treated with IV fluids, potassium replacement therapy and other medications. Further investigations revealed the following findings:-

 Direct microscopy showed the presence of budding yeast cells.

Fungal culture showed creamy white pasty colonies.

What is the probable history with which the patient presents in this case?
questions.solution:
Diabetes mellitus – the previous history of admission 1 month back is suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis.

There is a high incidence of candidiasis in diabetes patients due to various reasons such as

  1. Candidal colonisation and subsequent infection due to yeast adhesion to epithelial cell surface,
  2. higher salivary glucose levels,
  3. reduced salivary flow,
  4. microvascular degeneration and impaired candidacidal activity of neutrophils.

INCORRECT OPTIONS :

OPTION A ; Cystic fibrosis – allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a pulmonary disorder that often occurs in patient with cystic fibrosis and asthma due to a hypersensitivity response to allergens of the fungus aspergillus fumigatus. Management of ABPA involves use of systemic steroids to reduce inflammation and to modulate immune response.

OPTION B;Asthma - allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is a pulmonary disorder that often occurs in patient with cystic fibrosis and asthma due to a hypersensitivity response to allergens of the fungus aspergillus fumigatus. Management of ABPA involves use of systemic steroids to reduce inflammation and to modulate immune response. It occurs in less than 1% of asthma patients.

OPTION D;Hypertensive crisis – It is characterised by severe abrupt increase in blood pressure with impending or progressive acute organ damage. It can be divided into hypertensive emergency or hypertensive urgency.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE - There is a high incidence of candidiasis in diabetes patients due to various reasons such as

  1. Candidal colonisation and subsequent infection due to yeast adhesion to epithelial cell surface,
