  2. higher salivary glucose levels,
  3. reduced salivary flow,

microvascular degeneration and impaired candidacidal activity of neutrophils.

questions.text: A 25 yr old biker sustained a traumatic accident and presented to the ER with urine in blood, difficulty in voiding urine and abdominal pain. The bladder injury was repaired by double layered closure. A Foley’s catheter was left in insitu after repair. After 15 days the patient complained of suprapubic tenderness and fever. Urine culture on CLED medium showed – non lactose fermenting colonies with fresh tortilla odour. Which is the most likely organism in the case?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa – causes infections and various sites like skin, lungs and soft tissues. In hospital acquired UTI the commonly isolated organism are Staphylococci pseudomonas, Acinetobacter, along with other Enterobacteriaceae species. Pseudomonas is more commonly isolated in urinary tract infection in catheterised patients. It shows non lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. The colonies have alcohol like fruity odour/Fresh tortilla odour. The selective medium is cetrimide agar.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION A; E.coli – accounts for 70-75% of all cases of UTI. It is catalase test- +ve and oxidase - -ve, nitrate is reduced to nitrite. MacConkey agar shows flat pink LF colonies. Indole test positive, citrate test- negative, urease test- negative.

OPTION B; Klebsiella pneumonia – MacConkey agar - large mucoid dome shaped lactose fermenting colonies are seen. It is indole test negative, citrate test- positive, urease test- positive, TSI- acid/acid, gas- present.

OPTION C; Enterococcus – they are gram positive oval cocci arranged in pairs. MacConkey agar produces minute magenta pink colonies. Bile aesculin hydrolysis test- positive.

Educational objective

Pseudomonas aeruginosa – causes infections and various sites like skin, lungs and soft tissues. In hospital acquired UTI the commonly isolated organism are Staphylococci pseudomonas, Acinetobacter, along with other Enterobacteriaceae species. . It shows non lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey agar. The colonies have alcohol like fruity odour/Fresh tortilla odour.

questions.text: An 18 yr old visits an STD clinic in a remote suburb for a painless ulcer on the penis since 10 days. On examination the ulcer was indurated and hard , covered with thick exudates , enlarged, non-tender, firm bilateral inguinal lymphnodes were felt on palpitation. Which is the most suitable method of diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Dark ground microscopy – under dark ground microscopy Treponema pallidum appears as spirally coiled bacilli with tapering ends. It shows cockscrew motility. Sensitivity of dark ground microscope approaches 80% with detection limit of 10^4 bacilli/ml. Hence it can be used in a less resourceful area.

RPR test is a slide flocculation test. .

VDRL test is a rapid serological test where VDRL antigen is a cardiolipin antigen to which cholesterol and lecitin are added.

VDRL:-

  • Results read microscopically.
  • Antigen which is reconstituted should be used within 24 hrs.
  • Blood plasma serum and CSF can be tested

RPR:-

  • Results red macroscopically.
  • Carbon particles are coated with cardiolipin antigen, hence results can be read macroscopically.RPR antigen can stored for longer time because EDTA is used a stabiliser.
  • Blood plasma and serum can be tested, CSF can not be tested.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION A; Staining with Lugol’s iodine - Chlamydia trachomatis is most important cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, epididymitis, proctitis, post gonococcal urethritis. The patient presents with mucopurulent discharge, dysuria. Microscopy with Lugol’s iodine detects inclusion bodies of Chlamydia. The inclusion body of Chlamydia trachomatis can be stained with Lugol’s iodine because of the presence of glycogen mass.

OPTION C; Growth on rabbit blood agar – Haemophilus ducreyi is cultured on rabbit blood agar or chocolate agar enriched with isovitalex. Haemophilus ducreyi causes sexually transmitted disease known as chancroid.

OPTION D; Tzank preparation – genital lesions caused by herpes simplex virus are painful multiple tiny vesicular ulcers. Scrapings obtained from the base of the lesions can be stained with Wright’s or Giemsa( Tzank preparation ). Cytopathological changes seen are A) cow dry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies B) ballooning of infected cells. C) formation of multi-nucleated giant cells.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE- Under dark ground microscopy Treponema pallidum appears as spirally coiled bacilli with tapering ends. It shows cockscrew motility .A positive dark field result is an almost certain diagnosis of primary, secondary, or early congenital syphilis.

questions.text:
A 40 yr old man visits a Dermatology OPD with the complaint of painless ulcer on the shaft of the penis since 6 days. He later developed swelling with discharge and tenderness in the groin. There is a past H/O of homosexual contact 2 weeks back.

Microscopy-: Grams staining and Lugol’s staining of the discharge detected the presence of inclusion bodies.

Which of the following is the causative organism for this disease?
questions.solution:
Chlamydia trachomatis – is most important cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, epididymitis, proctitis, post gonococcal urethritis. The patient presents with mucopurulent discharge, dysuria. Microscopy with Lugol’s iodine detects inclusion bodies of Chlamydia. The inclusion body of Chlamydia trachomatis can be stained with Lugol’s iodine because of the presence of glycogen matrix.

Chlamydia trachomatis serovar L1,L2,L3 cause LGV.

Lymphogranuloma venereum is a systemic sexually transmitted disease, it presents as a painless ulcer on the penis, enlarged lymphnodes in the groin which are tender( bubo ).

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION B; H. ducreyi – causes sexually transmitted disease known as chancroid. It presents with genital ulcers and enlarged inguinal lymphnodes ( bubo ). Microscopy shows gram negative coccobacillus. The arrangement is known as rail-track appearance or school of fish appearance.

OPTION C; Treponema palladium - is the causative agent of the sexually transmitted disease syphillis. Clinical manifestations of syphillis can be divided into 4 stages – 1) primary, 2) secondary, 3) latent, 4) tertiary. Primary syphillis is characterised by a painless ulcer which is hard and indurated. Most common sites are – penis, cervix or labia, anal canal, rectum.

OPTION D; Niesseria gonorrhoea - gonococcal infection usually presents as mucopurulent cervicitis. Mode of transmission is by sexual contact or from mother to baby during birth. Cervical swab is the preferred specimen. It is transported in Stuart’s and Amies transport medium. Gram staining reveals gram negative intracellular kidney shaped diplococcic.

Educational objective :- Chlamydia trachomatis – is most important cause of non-gonococcal urethritis, epididymitis, proctitis, post gonococcal urethritis. The patient presents with mucopurulent discharge, dysuria. Microscopy with lugol’s iodine detects inclusion bodies of Chlamydia. The inclusion body of Chlamydia trachomatis can be stained with Lugol’s iodine because of the presence of glycogen matrix.

questions.text: Picornavirus belongs to the family picornaviridae and consist of 2 major groups - Entero viruses and Rhino viruses. Enteroviruses are transmitted by faeco-oral route, where as Rhino viruses are transmitted by respiratory route. Few Rhino viruses and all Enteroviruses can be inactivated by heating at 55*C for 30 mins but enteroviruses can easily pass through the stomach to colonise it. Which property helps the virus to do so?

choices.text: By destroying mature erythrocytes in the villi of proximal small intestine
By adhesion to intestinal epithelium with toxin co-regulated pilus

questions.solution:
Acid stable – Enteroviruses are transmitted by feco-oral route. Though they do not cause any intestinal manifestations, they multiply in the intestine. The Enteroviruses are stable at acidic PH and hence can easily pass through the stomach.

Incorrect options

Option A; Acid labile – Picornaviruses belong to the family Picornaviridae which includes two major groups Enteroviruses and Rhinoviruses. Enteroviruses are transmitted by feco-oral route and rhinoviruses are transmitted by respiratory route. They differ from each other because Enteroviruses are stable at acidic PH whereas Rhinoviruses are acid labile. Enteroviruses are inactivated by heating 55*C for 30 mins.

Option C; By destroying mature erythrocytes in the villi of proximal small intestine – Rotavirus infect and destroy the mature erythrocyte in the villi of the proximal small intestine. They multiply in the cytoplasm of erythrocytes and damage the transport mechanism resulting in secretory diarrhoea. The damaged cells may slough into the intestinal rumen releasing viruses in the faeces.

Option D; By adhesion to intestinal epithelium with toxin co-regulated pilus – vibrio cholera is transmitted by ingestion, contamination by water and food. Adhesion to the intestinal epithelium is regulated by a special type-4 fimbriae called toxin co-regulated pilus(TCP).

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Enteroviruses are transmitted by feco-oral route. Though they do not cause any intestinal manifestations, they multiply in the intestine. The Enteroviruses are stable at acidic PH and hence can easily pass through the stomach.

questions.text: If a husband or relatives of the husband of a women subject the female to cruelty shall be punished with 3 years’ imprisonment and also liable to fine under
questions.solution:
Sec. 498 A IPC - Cruelty to a women by husband / relatives shall be punished with 3 years’ imprisonment and also liable to fine

Sec. 304 B - Dowry death- death of a married women within 7 yrs of marriage under suspicious conditions.

questions.text: Kevorkian sign is one of the earliest changes seen after death. It is seen in the retina and it is the fragmented appearance of the blood in retinal vessels. All of the following statements about the sign are true, except?

choices.text: Persist even after 1 day of death

questions.solution:
Kevorkian sign/ Cattle trucking sign: fragmentation & segmentation of retinal vessels

  • It is the earliest sign of death seen after death.
  • Seen in retina
  • Blood in the retinal vessels appears fragmented, visualized by ophthalmoscope.

It appears within a few seconds to minutes after death and persists for an hour.

questions.text: Husband had intercourse with wife during separation without consent. Section which deals with it:
questions.solution:
Husband having intercourse with wife during separation without consent is punishable under 376 B IPC.

376 A IPC             Punishment for causing the victim to suffer persistent vegetative state during rape

376 C IPC             Custodial rape

376 D IPC             Gang rape

376 E IPC           Rape by repeated offender

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Naphthalene poisoning?

choices.text: It causes haemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency patients
It causes hypothermia due to formation of naphthylamines
Oily and fatty preparation should be avoided during treatment

questions.solution:
• It causes haemolysis in G-6-PD deficiency patients
  • It causes hyperthermia due to the formation of naphthylamines
  • Oily and fatty preparation should be avoided during treatment
  • Fatal dose – 2 grams
  • chronic exposure can results in aplastic anemia, hepatic necrosis and jaundice.

questions.text: The derivatives of the cannabis plant are known by many names – marijuana, weed, pot, ganja, charas, hashish, and more. They have a socio-religious association in India dating back hundreds of years, but never before have cannabis products been under so much scrutiny as they are now. The arrest of a Bollywood actress (now out on bail) by the NCB in the drug case related to another Actor's death has led to a larger debate. Which among the following is the active component of Ganja?
questions.solution:
Cannabis

  • Active Principle: Cannabidiol which is inert, is converted to active tetra-hydrocannabinols (THC) on exposure to heat
  • It does not produce physiological dependence or addiction, but psychological dependence and tolerance develop

questions.text: A baby girl was declared dead on arrival at the hospital. The husband and his family allege that the baby was born dead but the woman alleges that the baby was fine at birth but the local midwife had conspired with her in-laws to kill the child as they didn't want a girl child. The forensic doctor will perform all of the following tests to detect live birth, except?
questions.solution:
TESTS FOR LIVE BORN VS DEAD BORN

  • Hydrostatic rest or raygart’s test:
    • The specific gravity of unrespired lung is 1.04,
    • which is reduced to 0.94 after respiration.
    • Since during respiration the specific gravity is reduced, it will float on water.
  • Fodere’s test:
    • Weight of the unrespired lung is 30g, which becomes 60g after respiration.
    • due to increase in blood flow after respiration.
  • Plocquet’s test:
    • The ratio of weight of lung to weight of body almost doubled after respiration,
    • from 1:70 before respiration to 1:35 after respiration
  • Breslau’s second left test:
    • Checks whether the stomach is floating or sinking.
    • If the body has respired the stomach will float due to the swallowed or ingested air during breathing.
  • Werden’s test:
    • presence of air in middle ear after respiration.
    • Dip ears in water, puncture tympanic membrane, if air escape - Live birth

#Gettler’s test: To check chloride content in heart. (If difference between right and left heart chloride content is 25% or more, it is suggestive of antemortem drowning )

questions.text: Of the different epidemiological study designs available to test the association between risk factor and disease, the best design is of-
questions.solution:
• Cohort study gives the strongest evidence of association.
  • Cohort study is best to find out the incidence and compare it with exposed and not exposed.
  • Strength of association in cohort study is calculated by:
  • Relative risk - Best indicator as it has lower biases as compared to other studies.
  • Attributable risk.
  • Population attributable risk.

questions.text: A 23 year old male working in iron factory visited to the hospital for taking his TT dose. Injectable tetanus toxoid (TT) is an example of which of the following immunity?
questions.solution:
• The toxins produced by organisms such as Diptheria & Tetanus are detoxicated and used in preparation of Vaccines (Toxoids).
  • This detoxified toxins when administered in the body can elicit immune response resulting in antibody production & memory.
  • The Antibodies produced neutralize the toxic moeity produced during infection by these organisms thus providing active immunization to the body.
 

Active Immunity

Passive Immunity

Definition

Include humoral and cellular responses of host

Results in Ab production in the body.

Formed by transfer of ready made antibodies

Host body does not produce its own Ab.

Modes of acquiring

Following clinical infection, subclinical/ inapparent infection or immunization with an Ag.[vaccinations]

Administering Ig / antiserum or transplacental transfer of Ab/ Transfer of lymphocytes.

questions.text: A microbiologist is preparing vaccine in the laboratory for Mumps disease. Which of the following strain is used in Mumps vaccine?
questions.solution: The various strains used for Mumps include Jeryl-Lynn, RIT-4385, Leningrad-3, L-Zagreb and Urabe strains.

questions.text: For the calculation of Negative predictive value of screening test, the denominator is comprised of:
questions.solution:
Criteria

Numerator

Denominator

Sensitivity

True positive + False negative (a+c)

Specificity

questions.text: ‘Mid-year population’ is not the denominator of which mortality rate?
questions.solution: In proportional mortality rate, the denominator is the total number of deaths due to all causes

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant female visited the rural PHC to ask the physician about antenatal visits. How many antenatal visits covering the entire period of pregnancy are minimum required?
questions.solution:
Minimum no. of Antenatal visits required in Pregnancy : 4

  • 1st visit - within 12 weeks, preferably as soon as the pregnancy is suspected, for registration of pregnancy and first antenatal check-up.
  • 2nd visit between 14 and 26 weeks POG.
  • 3rd visit - between 28 and 34 weeks POG.
  • 4th visit - between 36 weeks - Delivery

Recommended Antenatal visits: 13-14

  • 0-7 months = once a month = 7 visits
  • 8th month = twice a month = 2 visits
  • 9th month onwards = one visit/ week =4-5 visits

Post natal visits: 3-4

  • 3 in institutional delivery- Day 3,7,42
  • 4 in home delivery- Day 1,3,7,42

questions.text: A rural village PHC reported many cases of post neonatal infant mortality. All of the following are common causes of Post neonatal infant mortality in India, except?
questions.solution:
Tetanus - cause of Neonatal Mortality (0-4 wks)

Causes of Post Neonatal mortality (1-12 months) -

  1. Diarrheal diseases
  2. Acute respiratory infections
  3. Other communicable diseases
  4. Malnutrition
  5. Congenital anomalies
  6. Accidents

questions.text: A rural PHC worker found that a group of population in the village did not consume adequate diet to meet their energy needs which is resulting in energy deficit. Which of the following is the correct method to assess Protein quantity?
questions.solution:
PROTEIN QUANTITY

The protein content of many Indian foods has been determined and published in food composition tables. One way of evaluating foods as source of protein is to determine what per cent of their energy value is supplied by their protein content. This is known as Protein-Energy Ratio(PE ratio or percentage).

Energy from protein

PE per cent = ------------------------X 100

Total energy in diet

This concept is useful because in many population groups adequate diet is not consumed to meet energy needs, resulting in energy deficits.

questions.text: Antioxidants are compounds that inhibit oxidation, a chemical reaction that can produce free radicals and chain reactions that may damage the cells of organisms. All of the following are Anti-oxidant vitamins except?

  • Oxidation is a chemical reaction that can produce free radicals, thereby leading to chain reactions that may damage the cells of organisms.
  • Thus, anti-oxidants protects the cell from free radical injury.
  • Anti-oxidant vitamins are:

    • Vitamin C
    • Vitamin E

questions.text: Water chlorination is done to kill bacteria, viruses and other microbes inwater and prevent the spread of waterborne diseases. In chlorination of water, the main disinfecting action is due to?
questions.solution:
Chlorination of water:

  • Used for large scale purification of water & for drinking water.

  • Disinfection action of chlorine in water is due to:

Hypochlorous acid – major role in disinfection (HOCl).

  • Hypochlorite ions – minor role in disinfection.
  • Chloride has residual germicidal effect.
  • It kills bacteria, many viruses but not spores .[except in high doses]
  • It oxidizes iron, manganese & hydrogen sulphide. It also destroys taste & odorproducing components.
  • Chlorine acts best as a disinfection for water at: pH around 7.0
