questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician with a 2-day history of left-sided chest pain worsening with inspiration. He began a high-intensity interval training program with his friend 3 days ago in an attempt to lose weight after being sedentary and stuck indoors for most of the summer. He doesn't take any medication normally and he doesn't smoke and drink. His BMI is 25 kg/m2. His pulse is 82/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/82 mm Hg, sPO2 = 98% on room air. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation of the left lateral sternal border without edema or erythema over the area. There is no tenderness elsewhere or palpable crepitus. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and triamcinolone

questions.solution:
Acute-onset chest pain that is reproducible with palpation along the costochondral junction in a young patient who recently began a workout program is highly suggestive of costochondritis For young patients in whom a diagnosis of costochondritis is highly suspected, supportive care (e.g., rest, ice, and analgesia) without further evaluation is appropriate if cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and there are no identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease(CVD). Patients who are older than 35 years of age, have cardiopulmonary signs or symptoms, or have a history of or risk factors for CVD should undergo further evaluation (e.g., ECG, chest x-ray) to exclude cardiovascular causes of chest pain.

Costochondritis

Costochondritis is a chest wall pain caused by inflammation of the costal cartilages or the area where the ribs meet the sternum, known as sternal articulations. It is a benign cause of chest pain. Patients often present with the chief complaint of chest pain; therefore, other causes of chest pain must be excluded with history, physical exam, and/or diagnostic testing prior to a diagnosis of costochondritis.

History and Physical

History of recent exercise/exertion/chest wall trauma is usually present. Typically, if chest wall pain is due to costochondritis, the patient will give a history of the pain worsening with movement and certain positions. The pain will also typically be worse when the patient takes a deep breath. The pain quality is variable, but it may be described as a sharp or dull pain. Vital signs are also important. Patients with costochondritis should present with normal vital signs.

Evaluation.

There is not a test to diagnose costochondritis. It is a clinical diagnosis. A normal chest x-ray will be seen with costochondritis. A normal electrocardiogram will be seen with costochondritis

Treatment / Management

The treatment for costochondritis is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). Some consideration can be given to a course of naproxen or meloxicam because these are dosed twice daily and once daily, respectively. Other NSAIDs can also be used, including ibuprofen. The NSAID of choice is based on provider/patient preference. NSAIDs are contraindicated in acute and chronic kidney disease. It is also important to discuss with patients the risk of gastritis with chronic NSAID use. If patients have severe or refractory costochondritis, refer for outpatient follow-up. Physical therapy is a treatment option for refractory costochondritis. Refractory cases of costochondritis can be treated with injected intraarticular lidocaine and/or triamcinolone.

Differential Diagnosis

The differential diagnosis for costochondritis is rather long. Some of the diagnoses included are associated with major morbidity and mortality.

Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS) This diagnosis should be considered in any patient presenting with chest pain. If you feel the patient's history and physical are concerning for ACS, consider an ECG and troponin level to assist in ruling out ACS. The patient should also be on continuous cardiac monitoring while in the emergency department.

Pneumothorax Consider the patient population at risk for spontaneous pneumothorax. A chest x-ray and/or point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) can be used to assist in evaluating the possibility of pneumothorax.

Pneumonia If the patient is complaining of a productive cough and/or fever or is at high risk for pneumonia, consider this on your differential diagnosis. Pneumonia can cause chest pain in addition to the other symptoms we associate with the diagnosis. A chest x-ray, complete blood count (CBC), and a basic metabolic panel (BMP) can be helpful when considering this as a differential diagnosis. Vital signs are also important when considering this diagnosis.

Aortic Dissection This is a medical and possibly a surgical emergency. Consider a CTA to evaluate for aortic dissection if this is a concern based on the patient's history and physical exam.

Pulmonary Embolism Ask about pulmonary embolism (PE) risk factors, such as malignancy, recent travel, recent surgery, personal history of PE or deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and symptoms, such as shortness of breath. Tachycardia can also be a sign of PE. Consider using a clinical decision rule, such as PERC and Well's criteria when considering PE. A D-dimer and/or CTA can be helpful when evaluating for a PE if this is on your differential diagnosis. There may also be nonspecific ECG and POCUS changes seen.

Esophageal Perforation The healthcare professional must have a high clinical suspicion for this diagnosis, and it is often due to an iatrogenic cause, such as a recent endoscopy. This patient's pain should be severe and unrelenting, and typically, they present in shock with abnormal vital signs.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION A Measurement of the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) might be indicated in patients with suspected costochondritis if there are accompanying manifestations that suggest an underlying inflammatory or rheumatologic condition (e.g., morning stiffness, arthralgia, myalgias, chest wall swelling), which this patient does not have.

OPTION B Chest x-ray is indicated in patients with acute chest pain and features that suggest a rib fracture(e.g., history of trauma, localized chest wall tenderness), a pulmonary cause of chest pain(e.g., cough, abnormal respiratory findings on auscultation), or heart failure(e.g., crackles on auscultation, peripheral edema, history of heart failure or other cardiac condition). In this young, otherwise healthy patient with suspected costochondritis, a chest x-ray is not indicated.

OPTION D Intraarticular injection of lidocaine and/or triamcinolone can be used to treat refractory cases of costochondritis. However, these treatments are not appropriate first-line therapies for this condition.

OPTION E Consider a CTA to evaluate for aortic dissection if this is a concern based on the patient's history and physical exam but in this case, history is suggestive of Costochondritis

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE Acute-onset chest pain that is reproducible with palpation along the costochondral junction in a young patient who recently began a workout program is highly suggestive of costochondritis. For young patients in whom a diagnosis of costochondritis is highly suspected, supportive care (e.g., rest, ice, and analgesia) without further evaluation is appropriate if cardiopulmonary examination findings are normal and there are no identifiable risk factors for cardiovascular disease(CVD).

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the OPD with complaints of blurry vision, headache, and multiple episodes of nosebleeds over the last few weeks. During this time, she has also been itching a lot, especially after getting ready for work in the mornings. She has had an 8-kg weight loss and increasing fatigue during the past 6 months. Her pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 158/90 mm Hg and RR = 16/min. Physical examination shows no lesions or evidence of trauma in the nasal cavity. Her face, palms, nail beds, oral mucosa, and conjunctiva appear red. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. Her hemoglobin concentration is19 g/dL, hematocrit is 58%, platelets are 450,000/μL, and erythropoietin level is below normal. A peripheral blood smear shows RBC precursor cells. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has a highly elevated RBC mass (↑Hb and ↑Hct) and low EPO levels along with constitutional symptoms(weight loss, fatigue),hyperviscosity syndrome(triad of mucosal bleeding, neurological symptoms, and visual changes),pruritus(likely exacerbated by hot water when getting ready for work), and plethora. These are features of polycythemia vera. A mutation in the Janus kinase 2(JAK2)gene is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of polycythemia vera(PV) and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia(ET) and primary myelofibrosis(PMF). For the diagnosis of polycythemia vera to be established, all three major criteria or the minor criterion plus two major criteria must be fulfilled. The major criteria are evidence of increased RBCs(↑Hb, ↑Hct),bone marrow biopsy showing hyper cellularity with trilineage growth, and evidence of a mutation in theJAK2gene. The minor criterion is decreased EPO levels.

Polycythemia Vera

Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative disorder associated with a JAK2 kinase mutation that causes the neoplastic proliferation of the hematopoietic progenitor cells. It causes elevated red blood cell production along with secondary white blood cell and platelet production. Disease complications are associated with increased blood viscosity, including thromboses.

History and Physical

Symptoms are related to hyperviscosity and thrombosis, impairing oxygen delivery. Physical complaints can include fatigue, headache, dizziness, tinnitus, vision changes, insomnia, claudication, pruritus, gastritis, and early satiety. Aquagenic pruritus, which occurs during or after a hot shower, is a complaint in 40% of patients. The mechanism is likely from mast cell and basophil degranulation, causing a histamine surge.

Bleeding events can include epistaxis, gum bleeding, and gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. Thrombotic events can include deep venous thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), Budd-Chiari syndrome, splanchnic vein thrombosis, stroke, and arterial thrombosis. Early satiety occurs from impaired gastric filling due to splenomegaly.

GI discomfort and peptic ulcer disease are common, likely from increased histamine from basophils and increased viscosity in gastrointestinal blood supply.

On physical exam, patients can display plethora and flushing of the face and palms, conjunctival injection, and skin excoriation from pruritus. Splenomegaly and hepatomegaly are also often observed

Evaluation

World Health Organization (WHO) published revised guidelines for diagnosing PV in 2016. These criteria are composed of three major and one minor criterion. Diagnosis can be made if all 3 major or 2 major and minor criteria are met.

Major

  • Hg >16.5 g/dL or Hct >49% in men, Hg >16 g/dL or Hct >48% in women; or red blood cell mass >25% above mean normal predicted
  • Bone marrow biopsy showing hypercellularity for age with trilineage growth (pan myelosis) including prominent erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic proliferation with pleomorphic, mature megakaryocytes (differences in size)
  • JAK2 V617ForJAK2exon 12 mutation

Minor

Serum erythropoietin level below the reference range for normal

These criteria should only be applied for diagnosis after secondary causes of polycythemia have been ruled out.

Treatment / Management

There is no cure for polycythemia vera; goals of treatment are aimed at symptom relief and reducing the risk of disease complications, including thrombosis, bleeding, and hematologic transformation.

1. Patients under the age of 60 without a history of thrombotic events are considered low risk and treatment recommendations include:

  • Phlebotomy, target hematocrit to less than 45%
  • Daily low-dose aspirin, if no contraindications
  • Treat aspirin refractory symptoms
  • Optimizing cardiovascular (CV) health such as weight loss, exercise, tobacco cessation, blood pressure control.

2. Patients 60 years of age or older and/or have a history of thrombosis are considered high risk, and recommendations are the same as for low-risk patients with the addition of cytoreductive therapy (hydroxyurea, interferon, busulfan) and treating disease-specific complications

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION A Renal cell carcinoma(RCC) can cause paraneoplastic syndrome, in which increased EPO production results in an inappropriate absolute polycythemia. Individuals with RCC may present with findings similar to those seen in this patient, including elevated RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), elevated platelet count, weight loss, fatigue, hyperviscosity syndrome, pruritus exacerbated by presumably hot water, and plethora. However, this patient presents with low EPO levels, making paraneoplastic syndrome unlikely. Moreover, she lacks other typical features of RCC, including hematuria, flank pain, and a palpable flank mass.

OPTION B An EPO receptor mutation is a typical finding in individuals with primary familial and congenital polycythemia(PFCP). PFCP is a rare disorder that may manifest with findings similar to those seen in polycythemia vera, including highly elevated RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), low EPO levels, plethora, fatigue, headache, hypertension, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, a patient with PFCP would typically have a normal-sized spleen, earlier onset of symptoms, and a family history positive for this condition. Moreover, this patient lacks other typical findings of PFCP, such as a normal platelet count, which indicates that other hematopoietic cell lines are not involved (isolated erythrocytosis).

OPTION C Stress erythrocytosis(Gaisbock syndrome) is a form of secondary erythrocytosis characterized by an increase in RBC mass due to a decrease in plasma volume (relative polycythemia). The condition can manifest with typical findings of polycythemia vera, including a (relative) increase of RBC mass (↑Hb, ↑Hct), hypertension, plethora, neurological symptoms, and visual and auditory disturbances. However, this condition typically occurs in obese middle-aged men receiving diuretic treatment, which is not the case for this patient. Moreover, stress erythrocytosis would not explain this patient's splenomegaly, elevated platelet count, and low EPO levels.

OPTION E PAX5 mutations occur frequently in adult B-cell progenitoracute lymphoblastic leukemia.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE A mutation in the Janus kinase 2(JAK2)gene is an important etiological factor in a number of myeloproliferative neoplasms. The mutation is present in almost all cases of polycythemia vera(PV) and in ∼ 50% of patients with essential thrombocythemia(ET) and primary myelofibrosis(PMF).

questions.text: A 60-year old male is presented to the ER with severe chest pain and back pain tearing in character. The patient is hemodynamically unstable with BP 80/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 150/min. CECT is done and findings are given in the image below. Which of the following are the most likely diagnosis and investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The image given is the CT image of aortic dissection. Aortic dissection(AD) occurs when an injury to the innermost layer of the aorta allows blood to flow between the layers of the aortic wall, forcing the layers apart. Classification

Classification of aortic dissection

 

Percentage

60%

10–15%

25–30%

Type

DeBakey I

DeBakey II

DeBakey III

 

Stanford A (Proximal)

Stanford B (Distal)

 

Diagnosis

INVESTIGATION OF CHOICE

  • IF PATIENT IS STABLE = MRI
  • IF PATIENT IS UNSTABLE = TEE (TRANSESOPHAGEAL ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY)

Diagnostic algorithm of aortic dissection

Chest X-ray

Aortic dissection on CXR: Note is made of a wide aortic knob.

Computed tomography

Type A

Type B Aortic dissection

Tennis ball appearance of ascending aorta is the feature of Aortic dissection TYPE A

Type B aortic dissections involve transverse and/or descending aorta.

Treatment = Surgical Repair

Treatment =1. For uncomplicated/ stable distal lesions and intramural type B hematomas medical therapy is preferred.2. For complicated type B surgical correction is indicated.

MRI Magnetic resonance imaging(MRI) is also used for the detection and assessment of aortic dissection, with a sensitivity of 98% and a specificity of 98%. MRI examination of aorta produces three-dimensional reconstruction of aorta, allowing physician to determine location of intimal tear the involvement of branch vessels, and to locate any secondary tears. It is noninvasive test, does not require use of iodinated contrast material, quantitate the degree of aortic insufficiency and can detect.

Transesophageal echocardiogram(TEE) The transesophageal echocardiogram(TEE) is good test in diagnosis of aortic dissection, with a specificity up to 97% and sensitivity up to 98% . It has become preferred imaging modality for suspected aortic dissection. It is relatively noninvasive test, requiring individual to swallow echocardiography probe. It is especially good in evaluation of AI in setting of ascending aortic dissection and to determine whether Ostia (origins) of coronary arteries are involved.

Disadvantages of TEE include inability to visualize distal ascending aorta ( beginning of aortic arch), and descending abdominal aorta that lies below stomach. TEE may be technically difficult to perform in individuals with varices or esophageal strictures. Aortogram An aortogram involves the placement of a catheter in the aorta and injection of contrast material while taking X-rays of the aorta. The procedure is known as aortography. Previously thought to be diagnostic gold standard, has been supplanted by other, less-invasive imaging modalities.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION B Aortic aneurysm, aortography CT image given in the clinical vignette is of aortic dissection and not of aortic aneurysm. An aortogram involves the placement of a catheter in the aorta and injection of contrast material while taking X-rays of the aorta. aortography is the nmae of procedure. Aortography is not gold standard procedure in an aortic aneurysm.

OPTION C Aortic dissection, MRI CT image is of aortic dissection .since, the patient is hemodynamically unstable therefore TEE is the investigation of choice. If the patient would be hemodynamically stable, then MRI will be considered as the investigation of choice.

OPTION D Aortic aneurysm, CT scan

This is the CT image of an abdominal aortic aneurysm and a CT scan is the investigation of choice in abdominal aortic aneurysm. E

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

Aortic dissection(AD) occurs when an injury to aorta innermost layer allows blood to flow between the layers of the aortic wall, forcing the layers apart. INVESTIGATION OF CHOICE

IF PATIENT IS STABLE = MRI

IF PATIENT IS UNSTABLE = TEE (TRANSESOPHAGEAL ECHOCARDIOGRAPHY)

questions.text: A mother comes to your clinic with her 26 week old baby with the presentation of a generalized dry, red, itchy rash which started seven weeks ago. His mother has been applying a regular emollient diligently and using a bath emollient. She reports that her son is having trouble sleeping due to this. He is currently breastfed and his mother has an unrestricted diet. When his father kissed him, he developed a rash also.  He is the first baby of his parents; his mother had an asthma history and his father had shellfish allergy. There are no pets at home. The baby was born at term by normal vaginal delivery and is vaccinated to date. On examination, His height has reached a plateau over the past eight weeks and now rests on the 9th centile for his age. He is alert and happy, although he rubs his legs vigorously when undressed. He has generally dry skin, with widespread low-grade erythema and raised, poorly defined patches of active eczema and there are widespread excoriations and no clinical evidence of impetiginization. He has low-grade generalized lymphadenopathy. The rest of his examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The case scenario described above with a history of eczema, family history of bronchial asthma, and allergy to certain food items suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis.

  1.  
  • Pruritic, xerotic, exudative, or lichenified eruption on face, neck, upper trunk, wrists, and hands and in the antecubital and popliteal folds. Onset in childhood in most patients. Onset after age 30 is very uncommon.
  • The other diagnostic features are:
  1. a personal or family history of atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, atopic dermatitis),
  2. xerosis-ichthyosis,
  3. facial pallor with infraorbital darkening,
  4. elevated serum IgE,
  5. repeated skin infections.
  • Itching is a key clinical feature and may be severe and prolonged.
  • Ill-defined, scaly, red plaques affect the face, neck, and upper trunk. The flexural surfaces of elbows and knees are often involved.
  • In chronic cases, the skin is dry and lichenified.
  • In dark-skinned patients with severe disease, pigmentation may be lost in lichenified areas.
  • During acute flares, widespread redness with weeping, either diffusely or in discrete plaques, is common.
  • Corticosteroids, emollients form the mainstay of treatment.

The image below is showing atopic dermatitis on hand.

OTHER OPTIONS

OPTION B

Psoriasis presents with itchy scaly plaques over extensor aspects of extremities with nail pitting.

OPTION C Tinea corporis is characterized by scaly annular plaques with central clearing over the body.

OPTION D Pityriasis rosea is characterized by scaly eruption with “Christmas tree “ Pattern

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

The case scenario described above with a history of eczema, family history of bronchial asthma, and allergy to certain food items suggests the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis. It is a Pruritic, xerotic, exudative, or lichenified eruption on the face, neck, upper trunk, wrists, and hands and in the antecubital and popliteal folds. Onset in childhood in most patients. Onset after age 30 is very uncommon.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for an annual physical examination. He has had no recent illnesses but has had intermittent pain in his legs during his soccer games for the past 3 months. The patient had no trauma preceding the onset of leg pain, has no numbness or tingling, and is able to walk without a limp. He was born at 38 weeks gestation via a spontaneous vaginal delivery with no complications. The patient has met all developmental milestones, and all of his immunizations are up to date. His father was recently diagnosed with hypertension at age 55, but there is no other significant family history. Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 135/88 n1m Hg in the right upper extremity, pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, and pulse oximetry is 98°/o on room air. Weight and height are at the 25th and 50th percentiles, respectively, for age. Physical examination shows a well-appearing boy who has no dysmorphic features and who smiles and fully cooperates. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart rate and rhythm are normal. A 2/6 continuous murmur is heard over the left interscapular area. No swelling, erythema, or tenderness is present in the lower extremities. Further evaluation would most likely show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with right upper extremity hypertension, lower extremity claudication, and a heart murmur likely have aortic coarctation. The defect is usually congenital and located distal to the left subclavian. Although notoriously associated with Turner syndrome, aortic coarctation is most commonly sporadic and affects male patients.

Findings are caused by impaired perfusion distal to the coarctation, and the degree of narrowing determines the severity of symptoms. Neonates with severe coarctation are at risk for life-threatening heart failure (HF) and shock following patent ductus arteriosus closure. However, milder narrowing of the aorta is often asymptomatic and diagnosed later, such as during childhood. Inadequate lower extremity perfusion may cause leg pain during exercise (claudication), as in this patient. In addition, 4-extremity blood pressure measurement classically shows upper extremity hypertension with lower extremity hypotension. Weak/delayed distal pulses (brachiofemoral delay) are also characteristic. Cardiac examination may reveal a continuous murmur due to blood flow through collateral circulation, a systolic murmur at the left sternal border fron1 turbulent flow across the narrowed aorta, or no murmur if no other cardiac defects (eg, bicuspid aortic valve) are present.

Chest x-ray reveals characteristic rib notching from collateral vessels and a figure "3" sign at the site of aortic narrowing. An echocardiogram confirms the diagnosis

(Choice A) Digital clubbing is expected with cyanotic heart disease due to right-to-left shunting_ However, this patient's oxygen saturation is normal.

(Choice B) Patent ductus arteriosus closure in a newborn with severe coarctation can lead to HF, causing hepatomegaly due to hepatic congestion. However, coarctation presenting later in childhood, as in this case, is typically mild and rarely causes HF. Also, HF is unlikely in this patient with no other signs, such as dyspnea or pedal edema.

(Choice D) Parasternal heave occurs with right ventricular hypertrophy. In contrast, aortic coarctation causes left ventricular overload due to impaired emptying against increased aortic pressure.

(Choice E) Pulsus paradoxus is a large decline in blood pressure (>10 mn1 Hg) during inspiration that occurs with cardiac tamponade. The presentation typically includes chest pain, dyspnea, hypotension, jugular venous distension, and muffled heart sounds, findings not present in this patient.

Educational objective:

Aortic coarctation is a congenital narrowing of the aorta. Patients with mild narrowing may have claudication due to decreased blood flow distal to the aorta. Key findings include upper extremity hypertension, lower extremity hypotension, and weak/delayed distal pulses.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to chest pain and light-headedness for the past hour. He was clearing away debris in his backyard when he suddenly felt substernal chest pressure accompanied by cold sweats. The pain has been constant, radiates to the left jaw, and is not relieved by rest or the nitro-glycerine spray he received in the ambulance. The patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension. He smokes occasionally, especially on weekends, but does not use alcohol. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 60. On examination, the patient appears to be in mild distress. The extremities are cold. Temperature is 36.1 C (97 F), blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg, the pulse is 34/min, and respirations are 16/min. Oxygen saturation is 94°/o on 4 U/min nasal cannula oxygen. Lung auscultation reveals crackles at both lung bases. There are no heart murmurs. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a 3-mm ST-segment elevation in leads II, Ill, and AFV. Which of the following is most appropriate as part of initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed sinus bradycardia as a complication of acute inferior wall myocardial infarction (Ml). Inferior wall Ml typically results from blockage of the right coronary artery and may involve only the right ventricle or both the left and right ventricles. The sinoatrial node is supplied by the right coronary artery in 60% of patients; sinus bradycardia commonly occurs due to ischemia of the sinoatrial node and right ventricular wall triggering an increase in vagal tone.

Sinus bradycardia after an inferior wall Ml is usually transient and self-limited; however, severe bradycardia can occur and lead to cardiogenic shock (eg, hypotension, cold extremities, pulmonary edema). Anticholinergic therapy with intravenous atropine is the initial treatment of choice for patients with hemodynamically significant bradycardia due to inferior wall MI and typically results in increased cardiac output and improvement in symptoms.

(Choice B) Dobutamine is a beta-1 agonist that treats cardiogenic shock primarily through an increase in left ventricular contractility. This patient's cardiogenic shock is mostly due to inadequate heart rate rather than inadequate contractility and is better addressed with atropine.

(Choice C) Epinephrine is sometimes used for symptomatic bradycardia that does not respond to atropine; however, due to beta-1 and alpha-1 stimulation leading to a large increase in myocardial oxygen demand, epinephrine is typically contraindicated in patients with Ml. Temporary cardiac pacing is the treatment of choice in patients with Ml and sinus bradycardia that does not respond to atropine.

(Choice D) Although patients with right ventricular Ml are typically preload-dependent with clear lungs and should often be initially n1anaged as if they are hypovolemic, this patient's severe bradycardia has led to inadequate left ventricular cardiac output causing pulmonary edema ( evidenced by bibasilar crackles) and cardiogenic shock. The administration of normal saline without increasing heart rate will cause worsening pulmonary edema.

(Choice E) Nitroglycerin infusion causes decreased preload due to dilation of venous capacitance vessels and can be used to relieve pulmonary edema in some scenarios (eg, hypertensive emergency). However, it is contraindicated in patients with hypotension and/or preload-dependent right ventricular Ml.

Educational objective: Acute inferior wall myocardial infarction often causes sinus bradycardia due to an increase in vagal tone triggered by sinoatrial node and right ventricular wall ischemia. Intravenous atropine is the initial treatment of choice in patients with hemodynamically significant bradycardia (eg, pulmonary edema, hypotension) due to inferior wall myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 4-week-old male infant with Down's syndrome is brought by his parents to your office due to feeding difficulties. According to the mother, the infant becomes short of breath and his face turns blue during feeding, and when he cries. On chest auscultation, there is a harsh holosystolic murmur heard best over the lower left sternal border. There are no rates of wheezing over the lung fields.Which of the following is the most useful test for diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
This child most likely has an endocardial cushion defect, which is the most common congenital heart disease in children with Down's syndrome. Among the propositions given, echocardiography is the most useful test for diagnostic evaluation of the patient. Echocardiography has the advantage of identifying the defect and determining its position and size. Chest radiograph, EKG, and hyperoxia test can all help in narrowing the differential diagnosis and evaluate the extent of cardiac dan1age, but these cannot confirm the diagnosis.

(Choice A) A chest radiograph may show the degree of cardiomegaly and pulmonary marking.

(Choice B) An EKG evaluates the heart rate and rhythm, and it can determine if ischemia, atrial dilation, or ventricular hypertrophy is present.

(Choice C) The hyperoxia test measures the P02 levels in the preductal arterial blood with the neonate breathing roon1 air, and then 100% oxygen. This test allows for the differentiation between cyanotic heart disease and pulmonary disease.

(Choice E) Cardiac catheterization is more accurate than echocardiography for diagnostic evaluation, but this modality is reserved for cases in which the size of the shunt is uncertain, laboratory data and clinical findings are ambiguous, or when the pulmonary vascular disease is suspected.

Educational objective: Endocardial cushion defect is the most common congenital heart lesion in patients with Down's syndrome. ECG is the most useful test for diagnostic evaluation of this condition.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man comes to the office due to cough and mild dyspnea His symptoms began 10 days ago with nasal congestion and a sore throat, which improved spontaneously after a few days. However, the cough, productive of white sputum, has persisted. He has also had an episode of blood-streaked sputum. The patient has a history of hypertension and stable coronary artery disease. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack-year history The patient is a car salesman and has not traveled recently Temperature is 36.7 C (98 1 F}, his blood pressure is 110/72 mm Hg, and his respirations are 18/min. Lung examination shows scattered wheezes bilaterally. Chest x-ray demonstrates no parenchymal infiltrate or consolidation, but a 2-cm peripherally located nodule is present in the left lower lobe. No prior chest imaging is available.

Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN), which is defined by the following features • Rounded opacity

  •  
  • <3 cm in diameter (>3 cm is considered a "mass")
  • Surrounded by pulmonary parenchyma
  • No associated lymph node enlargement

The first step in evaluating an SPN is to compare previous x-rays or CT scans; a nodule with stable size and appearance over 2-3 years has a low risk for malignancy and requires no further workup If the SPN has changed in size or appearance from previous imaging or if no previous imaging is available, the next step is to obtain a CT scan of the chest.

CT scan has high sensitivity and may identify other SPNs that either are too small to detect on an x-ray or are located in areas obscured on an x-ray (eg, costophrenic angles). CT scan also allows for better characterization of the appearance of an SPN. An SPN that is partially solid (heterogeneous) or has spiculated (spikes radiating from the surface), rather than rounded, the surface is more likely to be malignant. In contrast, an SPN with a ground-glass appearance is less likely to be malignant

(Choices Band E) This patient's cough, initially accompanied by a sore throat and nasal congestion, is likely due to a resolving viral upper respiratory infection unrelated to the SPN. Antibiotics are not indicated and are unlikely to be helpful. Sputum analysis for acid-fast bacteria is also not indicated, as the active mycobacterial infection is unlikely in the absence of chronic symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss).

(Choice C) Reassurance and symptomatic treatment are appropriate for this patient's viral upper respiratory infection; however, the SPN may represent malignancy and needs to be further investigated.

(Choice D) Repeat chest x-ray in 2-3 months is unlikely to be helpful in evaluating this SPN, and it would allow time for a malignant SPN to further progress

Educational objective:

A solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN) is known as a round opacity <3 cm in diameter and surrounded by pulmonary parenchyma. Because an SPN can be malignant, its appearance should be compared to that on previous imaging. Patients with no previous imaging or an SPN that has grown or changed in appearance should undergo a CT scan of the chest for further investigation

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening asthma symptoms for 2-3 days She has shortness of breath, wheezing, and productive cough The patient describes thick sputum that was blood-tinged yesterday. She was diagnosed with asthma 12 years ago but says that it had not been this bad until last year For the past year the patient has had 2 hospitalizations for asthma exacerbations but has never been intubated. She completed a course of oral prednisone and azithromycin 2 months ago Current medications include a daily fluticasone inhaler and as-needed albuterol inhaler The patient reports no decrease in appetite or \¥eight loss and has not traveled outside of her home state of New Jersey in the past 2 years She works as a school teacher and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs The patient has no second-hand tobacco exposure and no known allergies. Her grandmother also has asthma. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 123/80 mm Hg, the pulse is 94/min, and respirations are 16/min. Pulse oximetry shows 95o/o on room air Pulmonary examination reveals scattered wheezes. Heart sounds are normal. clubbing, peripheral edema, or skin rashes. Complete blood count shows the following: Item 1 of 2


	
		
			
			Hemoglobin
			
			
			13.0 g/dL
			
		
		
			
			Platelets
			
			
			200,000/mm3
			
		
		
			
			Leucocytes
			
			
			11 ,500/mm3
			
		
		
			
			Neutrophils
			
			
			65%
			
		
		
			
			Lymphocytes
			
			
			22%
			
		
		
			
			Eosinophils
			
			
			10%
			
		
		
			
			Monocytes
			
			
			3%
			
		
	


Chest x-ray reveals patchy bilateral upper lobe infiltrates and prominent bronchial markings. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosing the cause of this patient's worsening symptoms?

choices.text: Asking the patient to demonstrate proper inhaler technique

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA} ABPA occurs when patients with either underlying asthma or cystic fibrosis become sensitized to Aspergil/us antigens, resulting in an intense lgE- and lgG-mediated immune response It should be suspected any ti1ne a patient with one of these preexisting conditions develops recurrent exacerbations with fever, malaise, cough with brownish mucoid sputum, wheezing, or symptoms of bronchial obstruction.

Current diagnostic criteria for ABPA include an elevated Aspergil/us-specific lgE with an elevated (eg, >417 IU/ml} total lgE, positive Aspergil/us-specific lgG, eosinophilia, and positive skin test reactivity for Aspergil/us Consequently, the initial evaluation for ABPA should include either skin testing for Aspergil/us or analysis of total and specific IgE concentrations. Chest radiography typically demonstrates upper lobe opacities, atelectasis due to mucus plugging, and signs of bronchiectasis such as bronchial wall thickening. In addition, CT imaging can be helpful to further identify specific radiographic abnormalities consistent with ABPA.

(Choice B) It is important to verify appropriate inhaler technique in any patient with poorly controlled asthma; however, improper technique alone would not explain this patient's new onset of symptoms, radiographic findings, or peripheral eosinophilia.

(Choice C) Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage can be very useful in identifying the underlying cause of pneumonia in immunocompromised patients or in those whose clinical course is atypical. It can also help identify lesions in patients who have frank hemoptysis (not blood-tinged sputum) or evidence of malignancy; however, it has no role in the evaluation of ABPA.

(Choice D) Pulmonary function testing may reveal an obstructive pattern or a mixed obstructive and restrictive pattern in patients with ABPA; however, this study does not add significant diagnostic information to the evaluation of suspected ABPA.

(Choice E) This patient lacks the significant risk factors (eg, immunosuppression, travel) and weight loss typically associated with pulmonary disease due to acid-fast bacteria (eg, tuberculosis, Mycobacterium avium complex infection, nocardiosis).

Educational objective:

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis should be suspected in patients with preexisting asthma or cystic fibrosis who develop recurrent episodes of fever, malaise, cough with brownish mucoid sputum, wheezing, or symptoms of bronchial obstruction. The initial evaluation should include either skin testing for Aspergillus or analysis of total and specific IgE concentrations.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a 6 months history of fatigue and worsening pruritus which is accompanied by yellowing of the skin. She has a past medical history of hypertension for which she is on amlodipine and vitamin supplements. On physical examination, she is noted to have hyperpigmented skin with many scratch excoriations. Her abdomen is soft and non-distended with moderate hepatomegaly. She denies smoking or drinking. A detailed lab examination revealed an increase in alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, and total cholesterol levels. She has also become positive for antimitochondrial antibodies and antinuclear antibodies. Abdominal ultrasound shows an enlarged liver. Which of the following disease is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the signs and symptoms it is clear that this is a case of primary biliary cholangitis which is also known as primary biliary cirrhosis. It is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts. The patient presents with progressive jaundice, pruritus, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (A, D, E, K). Laboratory findings include an increase in alkaline phosphatase, bilirubin, and cholesterol. They also present with positive antimitochondrial antibody titer. The most accurate diagnosis is made by liver biopsy. Treatment is usually with Ursodeoxycholic acid and cholestyramine.


Option A: Primary sclerosing cholangitis is characterized by progressive inflammation and fibrosis accompanied by strictures of extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts. It present with increased ALP, bilirubin, and positive P-ANCA antibodies.

Option C: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease is steatosis of hepatocytes that leads to liver injury. Its diagnosis is large of exclusion. Liver biopsy may show steatosis or steatohepatitis.

Option D: HBV infection and aflatoxins are the major risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma. Patients commonly present with Right Upper Quadrant tenderness, abdominal distention, and signs of chronic liver disease such as jaundice, easy bruisability, and coagulopathy. The examination may reveal tender enlargement of the liver. α-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are significantly elevated in these patients.


Option E: A state of iron overload in which hemosiderin accumulates in the liver, pancreas (islet cells), heart, adrenal glands, testes, and pituitary gland. Iron studies show an increase in serum iron, percent saturation of iron, and ferritin with decreased serum transferrin.

Learning Objective :

Primary biliary cholangitis is an autoimmune disease that presents with jaundice and pruritus in middle-aged women. It causes elevated alkaline phosphatase levels along with an increase in antimitochondrial antibodies and antinuclear antibodies titers.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for vomiting and abdominal pain which is accompanied by fatigue and weakness. He appears cachectic and thin and has yellow-tinged skin. His vitals are stable except for T-38.4 C. His past medical history is unremarkable. He is a smoker and alcoholic. On examination, he had right upper quadrant tenderness, hepatosplenomegaly, and a palpable fluid wave. A detailed lab investigation was done which revealed the following :

Alkaline phosphatase : 180 U/L, aspartate am inotransferase : 320 U/L ,alanine aminotransferase: 140 U/L ,Total bilirubin : 3.8 mg/dL and Direct bilirubin : 1.2 mg/dL.

which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the history and physical examination, it suggests the finding of alcoholic hepatitis. Chronic and excessive alcohol ingestion is a major cause of liver disease and is responsible for nearly 50% of the mortality from all cirrhosis. Although alcohol is considered a direct hepatotoxin, only between 10 and 20% of alcoholics will develop alcoholic hepatitis. Quantity and duration of alcohol intake are the most important risk factors involved in the development of alcoholic liver disease.
The transition between fatty liver and the development of alcoholic hepatitis is blurred. The hallmark of alcoholic hepatitis is hepatocyte injury characterized by ballooning degeneration, spotty necrosis, polymorphonuclear infiltrate, and fibrosis in the perivenular and perisinusoidal space of Disse. Mallory-Denk bodies are often present.

In alcoholic hepatitis and contrast to other causes of fatty liver, AST and ALT are usually elevated two- to sevenfold. They are rarely >400 IU, and the AST/ALT
the ratio is >1.


Option A: Hepatitis B virus infection presents with symptoms such as right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and fever. However, (AST/ALT) of ratio >2 :1 is more suggestive of another etiology.

Option B: Autoimmune hepatitis presents with abnormal hepatic function tests, hypergammaglobulinemia, and autoantibodies such as antinuclear antibody and anti-smooth muscle antibodies.


Option D: Choledocholithiasis with acute common bile duct (CBD) obstruction initially produces an acute increase in the level of liver transaminases (alanine and aspartate aminotransferases), followed within hours by a rising serum bilirubin level.


Option E: In nonalcoholic steatohepatitis aspartate aminotransferase, (AST), alanine aminotransferase (ALT), and alkaline phosphatase levels are mildly elevated. But in alcoholic hepatitis, it is abruptly increased.


Objective learning :

Alcoholic hepatitis is caused by chronic alcohol abuse. The lab findings reveal AST: ALT ratio >2: 1.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented to the emergency department with the chief complaint of generalized weakness, abdominal pain, nausea, and palpitations. He has a past medical history of hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and end-stage renal disease for which he is on dialysis for the past 1yr. He admits that he is not compliant with his medications. He is a smoker and an occasional drinker. On further questioning, he told that he missed two of his dialysis appointments. Upon physical examination he has decreased motor strength in both his upper and lower extremities, intact cranial nerves, and decreased bowel sounds. Lab investigations are ordered and ECG was taken. Which of the following will most likely be found on electrocardiography?

choices.text: ST-segment elevation in leads lead I ,II ,III and IV
Progressive PR prolongation, followed by a 'drop' in QRS
inverted T wave in lead III, S wave in lead I and Q wave in lead III
Shortened QT interval and hyper acute T-waves

questions.solution:
By clinical evidence and medical history, it is evident that this patient has hyperkalemia secondary to End-stage renal disease. Chronic kidney disease and end-stage kidney disease are very common causes of hyperkalemia, due to the associated deficit or absence of functioning nephrons.

Hyperkalemia is more common in oliguric acute kidney injury; distal tubular flow rate and Na + delivery are less limiting factors in non-oliguric patients. Hyperkalemia is a medical emergency due to its effects on the heart. Cardiac arrhythmias associated with hyperkalemia include sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular
rhythms, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, and asystole.

Mild increases in extracellular K + affect the repolarization phase of the cardiac action potential, resulting in changes in T-wave morphology.

Electrocardiographic manifestations of hyperkalemia should be considered a medical emergency and treated urgently. Hemodialysis is the most effective and reliable method to reduce plasma K + concentration.

Choice A: ST-segment elevation in leads lead I, II, III, and IV is the feature of anteroseptal MI.

Choice B: Progressive PR prolongation, followed by a 'drop' in QRS is seen in Mobitz type I second-degree AV heart block.

Choice C: Inverted T wave in lead III, S wave in lead I, and Q wave in lead III are seen in pulmonary embolism.

Objective learning :

Hyperkalemia causes changes in T wave morphology and appears as hyperacute T waves.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to you for a routine physical examination. He says that he is experiencing extreme weakness, weight loss, frequent urination, decrease in appetite, and also has not had a bowel movement in the past 5 days. He feels totally uncomfortable. On examination, he complains of abdominal pain. His temperature is (37.4°C), blood pressure is 130/88 mmHg, the pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 18/min. During the course of the examination, you also noted that he is having difficulty remembering. His cranial nerve exam is unremarkable and his gait is stable. Urinalysis is within normal limits. Which of the following tests is most likely to be done in the next step?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient has the signs and symptoms of hypercalcemia. It can result in fatigue, depression, mental confusion, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, constipation, reversible renal tubular defects, increased urine output, a short QT interval in the electrocardiogram, and, in some patients, cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypercalcemia can be a manifestation of a serious illness such as malignancy or can be detected coincidentally by laboratory testing in a patient with no obvious illness. Whenever hypercalcemia is confirmed, a definitive diagnosis must be established.

Choice A: potassium level is to know the condition of hyper or hypokalemia. In this, there are no signs and symptoms related to potassium abnormality.

Choice B: Phosphate level could be used in the diagnosis of hypophosphatemia .It occurs in refeeding syndrome or hyperparathyroidism which presents with weakness, muscle/bone pain, confusion, and possibly rhabdomyolysis.

Choice D: TSH level could reveal a diagnosis of hypothyroidism which would present with depression, fatigue, weight gain, and constipation. This patient presents with weight loss and it does not fit with the other symptoms of the patient.

Objective learning :

Hypercalcemia can present with confusion, abdominal pain, constipation, and profuse urination. Whenever hypercalcemia is confirmed, a definitive diagnosis must be established.

questions.text: A 40-Year-old pregnant woman comes to the office for a prenatal visit at 20 weeks gestation. The fetal sex chromosomes are XX but the transabdominal ultrasound shows male external genitalia. If High BP, decreased potassium, decreased cortisol are findings likely to be seen in the infant after birth. what will be your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital adrenal hyperplasia(CAH) encompasses a group of autosomal recessive defects in the enzymes that are responsible for cortisol, aldosterone, and, in very rare cases, androgen synthesis. All forms of CAH are characterized by low levels of cortisol, high levels of ACTH, and adrenal hyperplasia. The exact clinical manifestations depend on the enzyme defect. The most common form of CAH is caused by a deficiency of 21 β-hydroxylase and manifests with hypotension, ambiguous genitalia, virilization(in the female genotype), and/or precocious puberty(in both males and females). All newborn infants in the US are screened for21β-hydroxylase deficiency by measuring17-hydroxyprogesterone in a blood sample obtained from a heel prick. CAH treatment involves lifelong glucocorticoid and fludrocortisone replacement therapy. Certain rare forms of CAH (e.g.,11β-hydroxylaseand17α-hydroxylase deficiencies) manifest with symptoms of mineralocorticoid excess (e.g., hypertension) and therefore require spironolactone (aldosterone receptor inhibitor) in addition to glucocorticoid replacement.

INCORRECT ANSWERS

OPTION B) High BP, decreased potassium, decreased cortisol in a newborn- hypertension with hypokalemia, and decreased cortisol levels can be seen in 11-beta-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition also results in virilization of infants with 46, XX genotype due to adrenal overproduction of androgens, which is seen here. However,21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is approximately ten times more common than 11-beta-hydroxylase, being responsible for > 90% of cases of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Therefore,21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency is much more likely in this patient.

OPTION C) Hypertension with hypokalemia and increased cortisol levels can be seen in Cushing syndrome. Cushing syndrome appearing in infancy is almost always caused by McCune-Albright syndrome( A genetic syndrome caused by a mosaic mutation in G-protein signaling and subsequent continuous stimulation of endocrine functions. Typical features include precocious puberty, café-au-lait spots, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and endocrine abnormalities (e.g., Cushing syndrome, acromegaly, thyrotoxicosis), which is more common among females. McCune-Albright syndrome is not, however, associated with female pseudohermaphroditism. Other causes of pediatric Cushing syndrome, such as primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease, may result in virilization, but the onset of virilization typically occurs in late childhood.

OPTION D) During infancy, causes of hypotension with hyperkalemia and normal cortisol levels include aldosterone synthase deficiency and type 1 pseudohypoaldosteronism. However, neither of these conditions is associated with pseudohermaphroditism.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE-

Prenatal virilization is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, which is most commonly caused by21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency

questions.text: David, a 22 year old young man, who works as a mechanic and struggling with financial issues. He had recently moved to the southern part of states. One day he visited the primary care hospital with the difficulty of itching eyes. Also mentioned that after he moved, he experienced watering and itching of eyes, that made him unable to focus and not give proper attention to his work. He has previous medical history of asthma and his ongoing medications contain fluticasone, albuterol, whey protein supplements and fish oil. During his physical examination, his blood pressure is 102/67 mmHg , respiratory rate 16/min, pulse 62/min and oxygen saturation on room air is 98.5%. During his eye examination , there is bilateral finding noticed as illustrated in the image given below. While remaining physical and cardiopulmonary examination is found to be normal. What is the most probable diagnosis in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is manifested with watery and itching in both the eyes. As there is no any other exposures or symptoms ,this is mostly suggesting a case of allergic conjunctivitis

Allergic conjunctivitis happens if an individual is exposed to an antigen, this activates mast cells which degranulates . The symptoms that patient mostly present with are hyperemia, bilateral watery eyes and pruritis. To prevent from allergic conjunctivitis it is better to avoid from allergens and the best medications are non-sedating anti-histamines like fexofenadine or loratadine.

Illustration A: Illustrate the physical exam findings of tearing and hyperemia, commonly seen in allergic conjunctivitis

(Choice A) In case of bacterial conjunctivitis the patient manifest with pain as well as purulent discharge from the eye,whereas in case of allergic conjunctivitis it presents with hyperemia and watering of the both the eyes.

(Choice B) Patients with viral conjunctivitis presents similar to allergic conjunctivitis as both of them manifest with pruritis, hyperemia and bilateral watery eyes. Although, in this clinical scenario the patient's had previous medical history of atopy and he recently moved to a new place. Also there was no other physical examination findings and lack of systemic manifestations. So,the diagnosis is points out to be allergic conjunctivitis. There is also a possibilty of viral conjunctivitis and it must be included in differential diagnosis.

(Choice C) The patient with corneal abrasion usually manifest with pain in the eye with or without ocular disturbance. In the given scenario the patient’s occupation is mechanic, that put him in at risk for corneal abrasion. Although, the patient presents with symptoms of bilateral allergy. This suggest the diagnosis likely to be allergic conjunctivitis.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE

The symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis is hyperemia, bilateral watery eyes and pruritis .Also if there is any history of atopy or allergic, the most probable diagnosis is Allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: You are posted as an Internal med resident and a 36-year-old woman presents to you with a chief complaint of joint pain in her hands. She stated that the pain is worse in the morning but is present throughout the day which is not relieved by ibuprofen. She recently noted that her right 5th finger began to swell and is painful. She also complains of changes in her nails, which have become brittle in recent times. She has a history of smoking and drinking. Her past medical history is unremarkable except for her lower back pain which is well controlled by NSAIDs. Her temperature is 37.2°C, pressure is 130/80 mmHg, the pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 17/min. On examination, the distal interphalangeal joints of the right hand are tender to palpation. The Achilles tendons are tender bilaterally. Additionally, a rash on the right elbow with red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales is identified. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Psoriatic arthritis( PsA). It refers to an inflammatory musculoskeletal disease that has both autoimmune and autoinflammatory features characteristically occurring in individuals with psoriasis. PsA synovium is characterized by lining layer hyperplasia; diffuse infiltration with T cells, B cells, macrophages, and NK receptor-expressing cells, with upregulation of leukocyte homing receptors; and neutrophil proliferation with angiogenesis.

Wright and Moll described five patterns in psoriatic arthritis: (1) arthritis of the DIP joints; (2) asymmetric oligoarthritis; (3) symmetric polyarthritis similar to RA; (4) axial involvement (spine and sacroiliac joints); and (5) arthritis mutilans .

Arthropathy confined to the DIP joints occurs in about 5% of cases. Accompanying nail changes in the affected digits are almost always present. patterns of nail involvement are identified as pitting, horizontal ridging, onycholysis, yellowish discoloration of the nail margins, dystrophic hyperkeratosis, and combinations of these findings.

Diagnosis can be challenging when arthritis precedes psoriasis. Patients should disrobe for the physical examination, and psoriasiform lesions should be sought in the scalp, ears, umbilicus, and gluteal folds in addition to more accessible sites; the finger and toenails should also be carefully examined. A history of trauma to an affected joint preceding the onset of arthritis may occur more frequently in PsA than in other types of arthritis, perhaps reflecting the Koebner phenomenon in which psoriatic skin lesions arise at sites of skin trauma.

Radiography can be helpful in all of these cases and in distinguishing between psoriatic spondylitis and idiopathic . Characteristics of peripheral PsA include DIP involvement, including the classic “pencil-in-cup” deformity; marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation (“whiskering”); small-joint ankylosis; osteolysis of phalangeal and metacarpal bone, with telescoping of digits. The anti-IL-17A monoclonal antibody secukinumab is effective in treating both psoriasis and Psoriatic arthritis.

INCORRECT OPTIONS:

OPTION B: Ankylosing spondylitis may share features with psoriatic arthritis (PA). sacroiliitis in Achilles' tendons and ankylosing spondylitis, also may be observed in PA. The presence of the rash of psoriasis and nail changes makes a diagnosis of PA more likely.

OPTION C: In Osteoarthritis, other large joints will also be involved with DIP. Additionally, nail pitting, silver scaling plaques, and dactylitis make a diagnosis of PA more likely.

OPTION D: Gout usually presents with swollen 1st metatarsal, intense pain, symmetric joint involvement, and cutaneous findings such as tophi. Inflammation and redness are present in the affected joints. As gout progresses joint movement will disabled.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE : Psoriatic arthritis classically presents with arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints, enthesitis, nail pitting, and salmon-colored plaques with silver scaling.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to your clinic complaining of general body malaise and a facial rash which appeared two weeks ago when she participated in a welfare marathon. She used some topicals, but no improvement is seen. She denies pain or pruritus and denies any changes in lotions or soaps. The patient has a history of diabetes and hypertension. she was recently prescribed a new medication by her primary care physician. The patient does not have any habit of smoking or drinking. She works as a clerk in a college. The patient’s temperature is 37.1°C, blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, the pulse is 86/min, and respirations are 17/min. On physical exam, an oral ulcer, and mild joint stiffness and swelling of the patient’s hands and knees are noted. You feel that her current symptoms are drug-related. Which of the following could be the medication causing her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Based on the symptoms and the history of drug exposure it is evident that this patient has drug-induced lupus. In drug-induced lupus symptoms such as fever, malaise, arthritis or intense arthralgias/myalgias, serositis, and rash is seen. Anti-histone antibodies are very sensitive to drug-induced lupus.

The most frequent drugs which cause drug-induced lupus are the antiarrhythmics procainamide, disopyramide, and propafenone; the anti-hypertensive hydralazine; several angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and beta-blockers; the antithyroid propylthiouracil; the antipsychotics chlorpromazine and lithium; the anticonvulsants carbamazepine and phenytoin; the antibiotics isoniazid, minocycline, and nitrofurantoin (Macrodantin); the antirheumatic sulfasalazine; the diuretic hydrochlorothiazide; the antihyperlipidemic lovastatin and simvastatin

Choice A: Doxycycline can cause photosensitivity. Other adverse effects are diarrhea, difficulty swallowing, esophageal ulcer, esophagitis, facial redness, headache, and hives.

Choice C: Chronic use of amiodarone causes Blue man syndrome and photosensitivity rarely .other side effects include hypothyroidism, peripheral neuropathy, pulmonary fibrosis, hepatotoxicity, and ocular symptoms.

Choice D: Methotrexate can cause photosensitivity and Other GI symptoms as well which include glossitis, enteritis, and mouth/gut ulceration.

Objective learning: Drug-induced lupus is an autoimmune response following exposure to certain medications, which induces the production of autoantibodies. Anti-histone antibodies are typically found in drug-induced lupus.

questions.text: 20-year-old swimmer who has been in excellent health and takes no chronic medications, for new-onset severe fatigue and left upper abdominal pain. She was treated 2 days ago in hospital for presumed typhoid with cefotaxime. She also had past h/o typhoid in 2 yrs back. On physical examination her heart rate of 120 bpm and a palpable spleen. Stool is negative for heme. Lab investigations shows hemoglobin of 5 g/dL with normal TLC and platelets. Peripheral blood smear reveals an excess of spherocytes. All of the following can cause similar type of this condition except:
questions.solution:
• Patient is having autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) due to development of warm immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies due to cefotaxime exposure
  • Warm antibody hemolytic anemia- most common form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA).
  • Autoantibodies generally react at temperatures > 37° C.
  • Most of the autoantibodies are IgG.
  • Hemolysis occurs primarily in the spleen.
  • The autoantibodies may occur:
  1. Spontaneous
  2. SLE, lymphoma,CLL
  3. Drugs- alpha -methyldopa, high-dose penicillin, cephalosporins

questions.text: Which of the following is a low risk germ cell malignancy ?

High risk of malignancy

  • Partial androgen insensitivity (with scrotal testis)

questions.text: Which of the following values is not correct about vitamin D status?
questions.solution: Explanation Vitamin D status based on serum levels of 25 OHD severe deficiency.<10 ng/mL(<25nmol/L) Vit D deficiency. 10-20 ng/mL (25-50 nmol/L) Vit D sufficiency. >20ng/mL (>50nmol/L) Risk for toxicity >100 ng/mL (>250 nmol/L) Different opinions for defining minimum threshold for optimal 25OHD levels; 30ng/dL or 50 nmol/L is suggested by others for sufficiency.

questions.text: Patient with history of herpes simplex virus infection presented with fever, uneasiness and arthralgia which is accompanied by skin lesion on palms and back of the hands and feet, as shown in the given image. what could be the likely diagnosis for the given presentation?
questions.solution:
The typical target lesion(also called iris lesion) of erythema multiforme has a sharp margin, regular round shape and three concentric colour zones: The centre is dusky or dark red with a blister or crust. Next ring is a paler pink and is raised due to oedema (fluid swelling) The outermost ring is bright red.

  • Iris or target lesions = Erythema multiformie
  • Bulla spread sign and Nikolsky’s sign = Pemphigus vulgaris.
  • Auspitz sign = Plaque Psoriasis.
  • Darrier’s sign = Urticaria pigmentosa.
  • White dermographism = Atopic dermatitis.
  • Dimple sign = Dermatofibroma

questions.text: Patient presented with bullae formation over skin. Nikolsy sign and Bullae Spread sign were present. Histopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis for the given condition?
questions.solution:
Histopathology of pemphigus vulgaris

  • Earliest changes -intercellular edema + disappearance of intercellular bridges in the lowermost epidermis.
  • Loss of coherence between epidermal cells (acantholysis) → formation of clefts → bullae in the suprabasal zone.
  • Basal cells remain attached to the dermis, producing a “tombstone” appearance.
  • Acantholytic cells are present in the bulla cavity.
  • Scanty perivascular inflammatory infiltrate composed of lymphocytes, histiocytes, and occasional eosinophils, neutrophils, and plasma cells is present

questions.text: A pregnant female complains of sudden onset of multiple generalized vesiculobullous lesions almost all over the body associated with pain and mild fever. She has B/L knee joint pain without any redness or swelling of joints. On examination the lesions are found to have pustular tips with surrounding red hue (see the following picture). Which of the following is the most appropriate drug to be used in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis is Pustular psoriasis of pregnancy called Impetigo Herpetiformis

When generalized - k/a Von Zumbusch disease (whole body involved)

  • Impact on fetal outcome --> placental insufficiency--> fetal abnormalities.
  • Systemic steroids - DOC .
  • Systemic steroids (pregnancy B category) > Cyclosporine (pregnancy C category)

⇒Localized to palms and soles, or the disease may be generalized. Regardless of the extent of disease, the skin is erythematous, with pustules and variable scale.

⇒Localized to palms and soles, it is easily confused with eczema.

⇒Local irritants, pregnancy, medications, infections, and systemic glucocorticoid withdrawal can precipitate this form of psoriasis.

  • Oral retinoids are the treatment of choice in non-pregnant patients.

Indications of Systemic steroids in Psoriasis

  1. Impetigo Herpetiformis
  2. Acute erythrodermic psoriasis
  3. Acute generalized pustular psoriasis
  4. Unstable Psoriasis
  5. Severe cases of Psoriatic arthritis

questions.text: Agoraphobia is commonly associated with : -
questions.solution:
Agoraphobia:

  • An irrational fear of open spaces or places where reaching a secure or safe base is difficult
  • Commonest phobia encountered in clinical practice
  • More common in women than men and onset in early adulthood
  • Panic disorder is commonly associated with agoraphobia
  • Can cause significant dysfunctionality
  • The individuals suffering from agoraphobia might become overly dependent on their phobic companion(s) – handful of people whom they trust.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Agoras roam in open spaces . Agoras are mostly men. Agoras are old. Opposite is found in agoraphobia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of paradoxical sleep is:
questions.solution:
In paradoxical sleep or REM sleep, the EEG shows increased activity, similar to awake state.

REM sleep has -
  • Rapid eye movements
  • Generalized loss of muscle tone
  • Increased rate of metabolism in brain
  • Increased HR,BP and PR associated with spontaneous penile erection
  • Dreams can be recalled in this phase

Note

Idiopathic REM sleep behavior disorder is commonly associated with later appearance of neurodegenerative disorders such as synucleinopathies (Parkinson’s disease or so-called Parkinson-plus syndromes, including multiple system atrophy or major or minor neurocognitive disorder with Lewy bodies).

HOW TO REMEMBER : dREaMs are REMembered in REM sleep. Also, sleep paralysis is parasomnia in REM stage of sleep because of decreased tone in this stage.

questions.text: Among the following, which is the most common eating disorder?
questions.solution:
Most common eating disorder: Binge eating disorder > Bulimia Nervosa > Anorexia Nervosa

Binge eating disorder

  • It is the most common eating disorder
  • Females > Males
  • Person is over weight
  • Binge eating is present but no compensation
  • Impulsive & extroverted personality styles are linked to this disorder
  • Treatment: CBT + SSRI

HOW TO REMEMBER: Now-a-days Binge watching web series and binge eating is a common phenomenon and everyone is aware of the raising obesity rates globally.

questions.text: All of the following are the negative symptoms of Schizophrenia except?
questions.solution:
Anhedonia - lack of pleasure in a previously pleasurable activity

Ambivalence-simultaneous and contradictory attitudes or feelings towards an object/person

Negative symptoms in Schizophrenia are (Anderson's 7A's):

  • Apathy - Lack of concern
  • Avolition - Loss of drive for goal directed activities
  • Asociality - Lack of social interaction
  • Affective flattening or blunting
  • Alogia - Lack of speech output
  • Anhedonia- Lack of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities.
  • Attention deficit - inability to pay attention

The more the negative symptoms in an individual with Schizophrenia, the worse is the prognosis.

negative symptoms can also be seen in bipolar disorder, major depressive disorder and OCD.

HOW TO REMEMBER : NOPqrSTUV ( U when turned looks like C ); negative starts with N and mnemonic starts with N; this mnemonic code does have a "qr".

  • aPathy - Lack of concern
  • aVolition - Loss of drive for goal directed activities
  • aSociality - Lack of social interaction
  • affeCtive flattening or blunting
  • alOgia - Lack of speech output
  • aNhedonia- Lack of pleasure in previously pleasurable activities.
  • aTtention deficit - inability to pay attention

questions.text: In a clinical trial study, for antibiotic prophylaxis, the minor wound infections of the patients were categorized based on their appearance. The grading system used in the trail, was ‘Southampton wound grading system’. Which of the following belong to the grade II of the Southampton wound grading system ?
questions.solution:
Minor wound infections discharges, pus or infected serous fluid but are not associated with excessive discomfort, systemic signs or delay in return home. The difference between major and minor and the definition of surgical site infection is important in clinical trials of antibiotic prophylaxis. There are scoring systems for the severity of the wound infection.

SOUTHAMPTON WOUND GRADING SYSTEM

Grade

Appearance

0

Normal healing

I

Normal healing with mild bruising or erythema

I a

Some bruising

I b

Considerable bruising

I c

Mild erythema

II

Erythema + other signs of inflammation

II a

At one point

II b

Around sutures

II c

Along wound

II d

Around wound

III

Clear or hemoserous discharge

III a

At one point only (≤ 2cm)

III b

Along wound (> 2cm)

III c

Large volume

III d

Prolonged (> 3 days)

Major complication

 

IV

Pus

IV a

At one point only (≤ 2cm)

IV b

Along wound

V

Deep or severe wound infection with or without tissue breakdown; hematoma requiring aspiration

 

Choice A- pus. When pus is seen the infection is under the grade IV.

Choice B- some bruising. This is seen in grade Ia.

Choice C- mild erythema is seen in grade Ic.

Learning objective According to the Southampton wound grading system, normal healing - grade 0; normal healing with mild bruising or erythema - grade I; erythema + signs of inflammation - grade II; clear or haemoserous discharge - grade III; pus - grade IV; and deep or severe wound infection - grade V.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy was brought to your clinic for wetting his pants in day time. The parents claim that, he has been like this from the beginning. Upon a examining his genital system, the urethral opening was seen more proximal and ventral when comparing to a normal person. Among which of the following, circumcision is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
In hypospadias the urethra opens proximally and ventrally. Most commonly, the opening is just proximal to the glans but it can open on the penile shaft or onto the perineum. It is attributed to failure of complete urethral tubularisation in the fetus. The foreskin is deficient ventrally and there is variable degree of chordee (a ventral curvature of the penis most apparent on erection). Glanular hypospadias needs correction fro cosmetic reasons but more proximal anomalies interfere with micturition and erection. A distal hypospadias is usually repaired before 2 years of age in one or two stages. Surgery aims to achieve a terminal urethral meatus so that the boy can stand to micturate with a normal stream, a straight erection and a penis that looks normal. Ritual circumcision is contraindicated in infants with hyposapdias because the foreskin is often required for the reconstriction. The medical indications for circumcision are:

  • Phimosis (choice A) - this term is often wrongly applied to describe a normal, non-retractile foreskin. True phimosis is seen as a whitish scarring of the foreskin and is rare before 5 years of age. It is caused by the localised skin disease balanitisxeroticaobliterans (BXO), which also affects the glans penis and can cause urethral meatalstenosis
  • Recurrent balanoposthitis (choice B) - a single episode of inflammation of the foreskin, sometimes with a purulent discharge, is not uncommon and usually resolves spontaneously; antibiotics are sometimes needed. Recurrent attacks are unusual but may be an indication for circumcision
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection (choice D) - Circumcision is occasionally justified in boys with an abnormal upper urinary tract anomaly and recurrent urinary infection. It may also help boys with spina bifida who need to perform clean intermittent urethral catheterization.

Learning objective The medical indication for circumcision are phimosis, recurrent balanoposthitis and recurrent urinary tract infection. Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias.

questions.text: A 78 year old woman is brought to the emergency department due to 2 weeks of progressive confusion, however, for the past week, she has been more confused and sleeping most of the time. Her daughter tells that she fell in washroom few weeks ago . She has also developed a mild headache. The patient has had no fever, vomiting, or urinary symptoms. Her other medical problems include hypertension and osteoarthritis. Blood pressure is 140 /76 mm Hg and pulse is 86 /min and regular. She is somnolent but arousable. The patient gives several inaccurate answers but is able to follow simple instructions. Muscle strength is 4/5 on the right side and 3/5 on the left. Plantar reflex is upgoing on the left. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with a history of falls has most likely developed a chronic subdural hematoma (SDH) due to traumatic head injury. SDH occurs when shearing forces tear the bridging veins, causing them to slowly bleed into the subdural space as shown in the image. Symptoms of SDH develop gradually as they occur secondary to the rupture of low-pressure vessels. Acute SDH typically produces symptoms 1 -2 days after onset, whereas chronic SDH presents insidiously, weeks after the initial injury. Clinical manifestations of chronic SDH often include headache, somnolence, and confusion. Patients may also have focal neurologic deficits like contralateral hemiparesis due to compression of the underlying cerebral cortex. Non-contrast head CT usually shows a crescent-shaped hypodensity that crosses the suture lines as shown in the image.

 

Grade

Description

0/5

No muscle movement

1/5

Visible muscle movement, but no movement at the joint

2/5

Movement at the joint, but not against gravity

3/5

Movement against gravity, but not against gravity

4/5

Movement against resistance, but less than normal

5/5

Normal Strength

 

 

Incorrect Options

Option B; Infarction of the internal capsule typically occurs due to lacunar stroke and can result in acute contralateral hemiparesis due to corticospinal tract injury in the posterior limb. However, lacunar infarcts typically lack impaired consciousness or cortical signs (eg, aphasia, neglect)

Option C; Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy can be caused by infection, toxins, or metabolic derangements like electrolytes disturbance, uremia, hyperammonemia.

Option D; Normal-pressure hydrocephalus typically presents with progressive gait difficulties (ataxia), cognitive disturbances, and urinary incontinence. Brain imaging reveals ventricular enlargement that is out of proportion to sulci enlargement

Educational objective

SDH occurs when shearing forces tear the bridging veins, causing them to slowly bleed into the subdural space. Non-contrast head CT usually shows a crescent-shaped hypodensity that crosses the suture lines.

questions.text: A 42-year-old garbage collector came in for a consultation. The main complaints of the patient is an ulcerating, blue pigmented nodule around 1.5 cm in diameter over the left lateral surface to his nose. An excision biopsy was done, and it revealed ovoid cells in nose with a single ‘pallisading’ layer. The patient was refferred to a plastic surgeon for grafting. Which of the following grafts should be used?
questions.solution:
This is a case of basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma is the, most frequent cutaneous cancer of nose and, is characterized by its local spreading, and exceptionally rare tendency to metastasizes.there is a significant advantage,seen in surgery compared to other treatments, surgical excision ensures the highest chance of cure .
