Excision defects of the nose can be covered with either a local flap and a full-thickness dermis graft, in resurfacing such defects following removal of basal cell carcinomas, the technique of composite-skin grafting, which involves the harvesting of composite-skin grafts, including the Epidermis, Dermis, and superficial layers of the subcutaneous tissue.

Incorrect Options :

Option A- Split thickness skin graft (of varying thickness). These are used to cover all wound sizes, are of limited durability, and will contract. They may be used to provide valuable temporary wound closure before better cosmetic secondary correction after rehabilitation.

Option B- Full-thickness skin graft. Used for smaller areas of skin, replacement that doesnt contract skin is required. (such as fingers, eyelids, facial parts)

Option D - Thiersch graft. The split-thickness skin graft is otherwise known as Thiersch graft.

questions.text: In a motor vehicle accident, a 23 year old male patient sustained an open bone fracture. After the appropriate treatment, he was sent home. Few weeks later, the patient developed erythema and supraregional vesiculation at the injured site along with fever and chills. (+) serosanguineous noted. Later the patient came to consultation with this presentation (image below). Which of the following is the working diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given case is consistent with the diagnosis of necrotising fasciitis. Necrotising fasciitis results from synergistic, polymicrobial infection; most commonly a streptococcal species (Group A β-haemolytic) in combination with Staphylococcus, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas, Proteus, Bacteroides or Clostridia. 80% have history of previous trauma/infection and over 60% commence in lower extremities. Predisposing conditions include : diabetes mellitus, smoking, penetrating trauma, pressure sores, immunosuppression, intravenous drug abuse, perineal infection (perianal abscess, Bartholin’s cyst), and skin damage/infection (abrasions, bites, boils). Classical clinical stages include: edema stretching beyond visible skin erythema, a woody hard texture to the subcutaneous tissues, an inability to distinguish fascial planes and muscle groups on palpation, disproportionate pain in relation to the affected area, with associated skin vesicles and soft tissue crepitus. Lymphangitis tends to be absent. Early on, patients may be febrile and tachycardia with a very rapid progression to septic shock. Management should commence with urgent fluid resuscitation, monitoring of haemodynamic status and administration of high-dose, intravenous broad spectrum, antibiotics. This is surgical emergency and the diseased area should be debrided as soon as possible until viable, healthy, bleeding tissue is reached. Early surgical review and further debridement is advisable, together with the use of vacuum assisted dressings. Early skin grafting in selected cases may minimise protein and fluid losses. Mortality between 30%-50% can be expected, even with prompt with operative intervention.

Incorrect Options :

Option A- impetigo. It a superficial infection of the skin with staphylococci, streptococci or both. It is highly infectious characterized by blisters that rupture and coalesce to form a honey - coloured crust and usually affects children.

Option B- erysipelas. It is a sharply demarcated streptococcal infection of the superficial lymphatics, usually associated with broken skin on the face. The affected area is erythematous and edematous.

Option C- cellulitis. This is a bacterial infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissue that is more generalized than erysipelas. It is usually associated with broken skin or pre-existing ulceration. It is characterized by an expanding area of erythematous, edematous tissue tissue that is painful in association with fever, malaise and leucocytosis.

Learning objective:

Necrotising fasciitis is a surgical emergency with polymicrobial synergistic infection which can rapidly progress to septic shock. Urgent resuscitation along with antibiotics and surgical debridement should be done.

questions.text: An elderly patient presents with the mass of 3 cm behind his left ear. The biopsy report of the mass is positive for staining of cytokeratins 1 and 10. The nearest lymphnodes were palpable and of around 2cm in diameter on the same side as of the lesion. (-) distant metastasis noted. What is the TNM classification of the tumor ?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with squamous cell carcinoma. The primary tumor size is more than 2 cm which corresponds to T2; the nodes on the ipsilateral side is palpable and is less than 3 cm which corresponds to N1. There is no distant metastasis which is denotes by M0.

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a malignant tumour of keratinising cells of the epidermis or its appendages. It arises from the stratum basalis of the epidermis and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10. SCC is the second most common from of skin cancer. It is strongly related to cummulative sun exposure and damage. It is more common in men than women. SCC is also associated with chronic inflammation and immunosuppression. Ionising radiation causes SCC, as do chemical carcinogens(arsenicals, tar) and infection with HPV 5 and 16. macroscopically the appearance of SCC may vary from smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous to ulcerating lesions. All ulcerate eventually as they grow. The ulcers have a characteristic everted edge and are surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin. Microscopically there are irregular masses of squamous epithelium which are noted to proliferate and invade the dermis from the basal layer. The tumour stains positive for cytokeratins 1 and 10. SCC can be graded histologically according to Border’s grading, which describes the proportion of dedifferentiated cells in the tumor. There are several independent prognostic variables fro SCC: depth; surface size; histological grade; microscopic invasion. The overall metastasis is 2% for SCC with a local recurrence rate of 20%. SCC is a hetergeneous tumor with a malignant potential that varies between subtypes. Surgical excision is the only means of providing accurate information on histology and clearance. The margins for primary excision should be tailored to surface size in the first instance.

TNM classification and staging:

Size

Nodes

Mets

TX Primary tumor cannot be assessed

Nx Nodal involvement cannot be assessed

M0No metastatic disease

T0No evidence of primary tumor

N0 No regional nodes

M1 Metastatic disease present

Tis In situ (confined to full thickness epidermal) disease

N1 Spread to ipsilateral nearby node that is < 3cm diameter

 

T1Primary < 2cm

N2a Spread to ipsilateral nearby node that is 3-6cm diameter

 

T2Primary > 2cm

N2b Spread to >1 ipsilateral nearby nodes,but none > 6cm diameter

 

T3Primary invasion of a facial bone

N2c Spread to contralateral node(s), but none are > 6cm diameter

 

T4Invasion of muscle, base of skull or other bones

N3Spread to any node > 6cm diameter

 

Incorrect Options :

Option A and B- the size of the primary tumor id denoted incorrectly.

Choice C- the distant metastasis is denoted incorrectly

Learning objective

Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) is a malignant tumour of keratinising cells of the epidermis or its appendages. It arises from the stratum basalis of the epidermis and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10.Squamous cell carcinoma can be graded histologically according to Border’s grading, which describes the proportion of dedifferentiated cells in the tumor. In TNM classification T denotes the tumor size, N denotes the size of the node involved, M indicates metastasis.

questions.text: A 62 -year-old man comes to the emergency department with substernal chest pain, severe shortness of breath, and diaphoresis that began suddenly 50 minutes ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and was not relieved with antacids . The patient has vomited twice since the pain started. Electrocardiogram shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. His medical problems include peptic ulcer disease, for which he takes omeprazole. Blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 90/min. Sublingual nitroglycerin and aspirin are administered and within minutes the patient reports resolution of pain. Which of the following most likely accounts for the improvement in his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Nitrates are excellent antianginal drugs and are used frequently to relieve chest pain in patients with stable angina pectoris and acute coronary syndrome . Nitrates are primarily vasodilators and dilate veins, arterioles, and coronary arteries by relaxing vascular smooth muscle cells. Although nitrates act as venodilators and coronary vasodilators, their primary anti-ischemic effects are due to systemic vasodilation rather than coronary vasodilation.

Systemic venodilation lowers preload and left ventricular end-diastolic volume and reduces myocardial oxygen demand by reducing wall stress. Nitrates also cause arterial and arteriolar vasodilation( to a lesser degree) and can decrease systemic vascular resistance and blood pressure. The fall in systemic blood pressure reduces wall stress, which leads to further decrease in myocardial oxygen demand.

(Choice A and D ) Systemic venodilation caused by nitrates leads to a decrease, not an increase, in preload. Systemic arterial dilation also causes a decrease in afterload, which occurs to a much lesser degree than a decrease in preload. (Choice B) Nitrates have no direct effect on cardiac chronotropy or inotropy (contractility) and left ventricular ejection fraction. They can indirectly cause reflex tachycardia in patients with a significant fall in blood pressure.

Educational objective: The primary anti ischemic and anti anginal effects of nitrates are due to systemic vasodilation rather than coronary vasodilation. Systemic venodilation lowers preload and left ventricular end-diastolic volume and reduces myocardial oxygen demand by reducing wall stress.

questions.text: A 62 -year-old man comes to the emergency department with substernal chest pain, severe shortness of breath, and diaphoresis that began suddenly 50 minutes ago. The pain radiates to his left arm and does not remit with sublingual nitroglycerin The patient has vomited twice since the pain started. Electrocardiogram shows ST elevations in the anterior leads. On physical examination, the patient's temperature is 36.9 C , blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 32/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on 4 L/min oxygen by nasal canula. Cardiac examination shows an S3. Lung examination shows basilar crackles that extend halfway up the lung fields bilaterally. He is given 325 mg of aspirin, 600 mg of clopidogrel, and 80 mg of atorvastatin. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has ischemic heart failure secondary to an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI) causing acute pulmonary edema also known as flash pulmonary edema . A loop diuretic such as furosemide is the drug of choice in this setting. Furosemide rapidly relieves pulmonary edema by decreasing the cardiac preload, thereby decreasing pulmonary capillary pressure. Furosemide also causes venodilation, which further decreases the preload. Hewever, diuretics should be given carefully in this setting as many of these patients may be normo- or hypo-volemic, and aggressive diuresis may lead to hypotension and acute kidney injury. Ultimately emergency revascularization (percutaneous coronary angioplasty or thrombolysis) is needed for definitive management of ST-elevation MI. Percutaneous coronary angioplasty with in 90 minutes is preferred.

(Choice A) Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker used in the management of hypertension and supraventricular arrhythmias. It is a second-line drug for management of angina pain . Hewever, it is not indicated for acute MI or CHF.

(Choice B) Digoxin is relatively contraindicated in acute MI as it may increase myocardial oxygen demand.

(Choice D) Intravenous fluids would likely worsen this patient's pulmonary edema. (Choice E) Although beta blockers such as metaprolol improve mortality in acute MI, they are contraindicated in the presence ef pulmonary edema (acute decompensated heart failure).

Learning objective :Ischemic heart failure secondary to an acute anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI) can lead to acute pulmonary edema . A loop diuretic such as furosemide is the drug of choice to relieve acute pulmonary edema.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man undergoes coronary artery bypass graft for severe coronary artery disease. He is extubated on the second postoperative day. On the third postoperative day he complains of dyspnea and worsening retrosternal pain despite continuous analgesia with morphine. His temperature is 38.6° C , blood pressure is 112/52 mm Hg, pulse is 125/min and irregularly irregular and respirations are 28/min. Examination shows normal heart sounds. A small amount of cloudy fluid is present in the sternal wound drain. His ECG shows atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. An x-ray film of the chest shows widening of the mediastinum. Echocardiography reveals a small amount of pericardial fluid. Laboratory studies show

Hemoglobin 8.9 mg/L

WBC Count 16,300/mm3

Which of the following will this patient most likely require?
questions.solution:
This patient presents has likely developed acute mediastinitis, a possible complication of cardiac surgery that is usually due to intraoperative wound contamination. Patients typically present post operatively (usually within 14 days) with fever, tachycardia, chest pain, leukocytosis, and sternal wound drainage or purulent discharge. Chest x-ray usually shows a widened mediastinum in non-postoperative mediastinitis, but this can also be seen in postoperative mediastinitis after cardiac surgery. The diagnosis is usually clinically made and confirmed during surgery when pus is noted in the mediastinum. Postoperative mediastinitis requires drainage, surgical debridement with immediate closure, and prolonged antibiotic therapy . Acute mediastinitis has a mortality rate of 10%-50%, even with appropriate treatment.

(Choice A) Atrial fibrillation commonly occurs within a few days after CABG and is usually self-limited, with resolution in <24 hours. Rate control with beta-blockers or amiodarone is best. Since this patient requires immediate surgery , anticoagulation should not be given.

(Choice B) Antibiotics alone do not appropriately treat mediastinitis

(Choice C) Nonsteroidal antinflammatory agents have limited efficacy in treating mediastinitis .

Learning objective : . Postoperative mediastinitis requires drainage, surgical debridement with immediate closure, and prolonged antibiotic therapy .

questions.text: One the leading South Indian actress who underwent a rib resection recently, got involved in a road traffic accident and had a strong impact onto her lower back. Upon presenting to the emergency room, she was well, complained of lower back pain only. She left the hospital against medical advice. After 24 hours, she developed a bluish discoloration over her flank area on the same side of the pain, she had earlier. It is an abdominal emergency. Among which of the following, this discoloration is denoted as ?
questions.solution:
Scars, abdominal distension, visible peristalsis or abdominal masses, dilated veins, pulsation or abdominal wall swelling suggestive of hernia should all be carefully sought. Grey turner sign- skin discoloration of the flanks due to retroperitoneal hemorrhage in severe acute pancreatitis and leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is an abdominal emergency.

Incorrect options

Option A- Cullen sign. Discoloration around the umbilicus may indicate severe acute pancreatitis, ruptured ectopic pregnancy or trauma to the liver. In these situations the blood tracks to the umbilicus along the ligamentum teres.

Option C- Krymov sign. Tenderness of the right inguinal canal on introduction of a finger through the external opening in the area of the posterior abdominal wall.

Option D- Mcburney sign. Pain on abdominal palpation caused by applying pressure of one finger located between an 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 based on a straight line drawn from the anterior spinous process of the ilium to the umbilicus

Learning objective

Grey turner sign- skin discoloration of the flanks due to retroperitoneal hemorrhage in severe acute pancreatitis and leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is an abdominal emergency.

questions.text: A 62 year old female patient experienced intermittent abdominal fullness with gradual aggravation for 2 months. She also had loss of appetite. She visited a local clinic, where upper gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed a duodenal ulcer. She was referred to other big facility, suspecting for progressive ileus. She presented with vomiting and absence of passage of flatus and feces for three days. The patient had no history of systemic diseases and had not undergone any surgery. Abdominal examination reveled distension and mild epigastric tenderness. No palpable lump noted. A CT was done (given below). Which among the following will be the working diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
When tissue is trapped inside a hernia it is in a confined space. The narrow neck acts as a constriction ring impeding venous return and increasing pressure within the hernia. Resulting tension leads to pain and tenderness. It the hernia contains bowel then it may become ‘obstructed’ partially or totally. If the pressure rises sufficiently , arterial blood is not able to enter the hernia and the contents become ischemic and may infarct. The hernia is said to have strangulated. The wall of the bowel perforates, releasing infected, toxic bowel content into the tissues and ultimately back into the peritoneal cavity. The risk of strangulation is highest in hernias that have a small neck of rigid tissue, leading first to irreducibility an don to strangulation. The term incarcerated is not clearly defined and used to imply a hernia that is irreducible and developing towards strangulation.

In special circumstance (Richter’s hernia) only part of the bowel wall enters the hernia. It may be small or difficult or even impossible to detect clinically. Bowel obstruction may not be present but the bowel wall may still become necrotic and perforate with life threatening consequences.

The marked structure shown is the hernial sac lateral to the pubic tubercle.

Incorrect options

Option B - Litter’s hernia. There is a presence of the Meckle’s diverticulum in the hernial sac.

Option C- Amyand’s hernia. The hernial sac contains the appendix.

Option D- Pantaloon’s hernia. It is defined as ipsilateral concurrent direct and indirect inguinal hernia.

Learning objective: Richter's hernia is the protrusion and/orstrangulationof part of the intestine's antimesenteric border through a rigid small defect in the abdominal wall. This hernia is difficult to diagnose because the signs and symptoms of development are innocuous.

questions.text: A twenty year old male patient was diagnosed with acute appendicitis and underwent an open appendectomy via Rockey-Davis incision. After few months, the patient had a slow progressively growing erythematous lump at the incisional site. He complains of pain while doing valsalva maneuver. Later the patient developed, vomiting and constipation along with fever. Which of the following diagnostic methods, you will use to support your diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
This is a case of incisional hernia. These arise a defect in the musculofascial layers of the abdominal wall in the region of postoperative scar. Thus they may appear anywhere on the abdominal surface. Factors predisposing to their development are patient factors ( obesity, general poor healing to malnutrition, immunosuppression or steroid therapy, chronic cough, cancer ), wound factors (poor quality tissues, wound infection) and surgical factors (inappropriate suture material, incorrect suture placement). An incisional hernia usually starts as disruption of the musculofascial layers of a wound in the early postoperative period. Often they may pass unnoticed if the overlying skin wound has healed securely.

For most hernias, no specific investigation is required, the diagnosis being made on clinical examination. However, the patient may have symptoms suggesting a hernia, but no hernia is found or have swelling suggestive of hernia but with clinical uncertainty. It is important to be certain that any symptoms described are due to a hernia and not to coexisting pathology.

Computed tomography is helpful in complex incisional hernia, determining the number and size of muscle defects, identifying the content, giving some indication of presence of adhesions and excluding other intra abdominal pathology such as ascites, occult malignancy and portal hypertension.

Incorrect options

Option A- X-ray. A plain radio-graph of the abdomen is of little value, although a hiatus or hernia and diaphragmatic hernia may be seen on chest radio-graph.

Option B- Ultrasonography. An ultrasound scan may be helpful in cases of irreducible hernia, where the differential diagnosis includes a mass or fluid collection, or when the nature of the hernia content is in doubt. Ultrasonography is very useful in the early postoperative period when a hematoma or seroma may develop, and be difficult to distinguish from an early recurrance. Ultrasonography is non invasive and low cost but operator dependent.

Option D - contrast barium imaging . Contrast barium radiology is occasionally useful in the absence of CT. Contrast may also be injected directly into the peritoneum, a herniagram, to identify an occult sac, especially in occult inguinal hernia. MRI can help in the diagnosis of sportsman groin where pain is the presenting feature and the surgeon needs to distinguish an occult hernia from an orthopedic injury.

Learning objective : Computed tomography is helpful in complex incisional hernia, determining the number and size of muscle defects, identifying the content, giving some indication of presence of adhesions and excluding other intra abdominal pathology such as ascites, occult malignancy and portal hypertension.

questions.text: A young weight lifting aspirant was making his way through the higher leagues in weight lifting contest, through his vigorous training sessions. He is eyeing for the gold medal in the upcoming Olympics. He underwent constant training to achieve his goal. Initially he had symptoms of regurgitation and heart burn occasionally. But he ignored them and still pursued his training sessions. During a training session, he increased the weights, where after lifting, he felt a severe chest pain radiating to the back. After few minutes he developed dyspnea, that is when he was brought to the emergency bay. ECG was normal. Chest X-ray reveal air in the mediastinum. At this time, what will be the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
The case given in the question stem is Barotrauma perforation of the esophagus. It is also denoted as spontaneous perforation.It happens when a person vomits against a closed glottis. The pressure applied on oesophagus increases rapidly, and the oesophagus bursts at its weakest point in the lower third, sending a stream of material into the mediastinum and often the pleural cavity as well. The condition was first identified by Boerhaave. Boerhaave’s syndrome is the most serious type of perforation because of the large volume of material that is released under pressure. This causes rapid chemical irritation in mediastinum and pleura, causes infection if untreated. Barotrauma is also been described in relation to other pressure factors when the patient strains against a closed glottis (e.g. defecation, labour, weight-lifting)

The clinical history is usually of severe pain in the chest or upper abdomen after a meal or a bout of drinking. Associated shortness of breath is common. Many cases are misdiagnosed as myocardial infarction, perforated peptic ulcer or pancreatitis if the pain is confined to the upper abdomen. There may be a surprising amount of rigidity on examination of upper abdomen, even in absence of any peritoneal contamination.

The diagnosis can usually be suspected from history and associated clinical features. A chest radiograph is often confirmatory with air in the mediastinum, pleura or peritoneum. Pleural effusion occurs rapidly either as a result of free communication with the pleural space or as a reaction to adjacent inflammation in the mediastinum. A contrast swallow or CT isn always required to guide management.

Incorrect options :

Option B- pathological perforation. Free perforation of ulcers or tumours of the oesophagus into the pleural space is rare. Erosion into adjacent structure with fistula formation is more common. Aerodigestive fistula is most common and usually encountered in primary malignant disease of oesophagus or bronchus.

Option C- instrumental perforation. Instrumentation is the most common cause of perforation. Modern instrumentation is remarkably safe, but perforation remains a risk. Perforation related to diagnostic upper GI endoscopy is unusual with an estimated frequency of about 1:4000 examinations. Perforation can occur in pharynx or esophagus, usually at sites of pathology or when the endoscope is passed blindly.

Option D-Mallory Weiss syndrome. Forceful vomiting produce a mucosal tear at the cardia rather than a full perforation. The mechanism of injury is different. In Boerhaave’s syndrome, vomiting occurs against a closed glottis and pressure builts in oesophagus. In Mallory–Weiss syndrome, vigorous vomiting produces a vertical split in the gastric mucosa, immediately below the squamocolumnar junction at the cardia in 90% of cases. In only 10% is the tear in the oesophagus. The condition presents with haematemesis.

Learning objective

Perforation of the oesophagus is usually iatrogenic (at therapeutic endoscopy) or due to ‘barotrauma’ (spontaneous perforation). Barotrauma has also been described in relation to other pressure events when the patient strains against a closed glottis (e.g. defecation, labour, weight-lifting). The diagnosis can usually be suspected from history and associated clinical features. A chest radiograph is often confirmatory with air in the mediastinum, pleura or peritoneum.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male driver is brought to the ER after a motor vehicle accident in a comatose state. At accident spot, his blood pressure is 50/30 mm Hg and heart rate is 150/min. On examination, chest is clear on auscultation. A large bruise is seen is seen on abdominal wall. Abdomen is mildly distended. Bowel sounds are decreased. Neck veins are collapsed .After infusion of two liters of intravenous fluids, his blood pressure is 80/40 mmHg. FAST shows blood in the peritoneal cavity but no obvious solid organ injury. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient's history of motor vehicle accident, abdominal wall bruise, distended abdomen, and decreased bowel sounds is due to blunt abdominal trauma. Furthermore, collapsed neck veins and hypotension indicate hypovolemic shock. In a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected blunt abdominal trauma, the appropriate management involves cervical spine immobilization, intravenous hydration and FAST (Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma). If ultrasound shows blood in the peritoneal cavity of a hemodynamically unstable patient, then urgent laparotomy with surgical repair is indicated

(option A) Ultrasound is not reliable in identifying solid organ injury. (option A) A hemodynamically stable patient with intraperitoneal blood identified on ultrasound should undergo a CT scan of the abdomen with contrast. A CT scan allows the amount of intraperitoneal blood to be quantified and can often identify the site of injury. Further decision of conservative or surgical management will be based on CT findings.

(Option C) X-ray abdomen and pelvis would be useful for identifying pelvic, rib, or vertebral fractures. However, this patient is hemodynamically unstable with confirmed bleeding in the peritoneal cavity. The first priority in this patient is to control the source of bleeding and treat shock by performing laparotomy repairing the cause of bleeding.

(Option D) The use of laparoscopy in cases of blunt abdominal trauma is controversial and hemodynamic instability is an absolute contraindication to laparoscopy . (Option E )Diagnostic peritoneal lavage should be performed in any hemodynamically unstable patient with an equivocal or poor quality sonogram.

Bottom line:

Blunt abdominal trauma presenting with hemodynamic instability, fluid resuscitation should be initiated, followed by ultrasound examination. If ultrasound reveals intraperitoneal blood, the patient should then undergo urgent laparotomy for surgical repair.

questions.text: A 58 -year-old man undergoes a partial hepatectomy . The surgery is complicated by excessive bleeding . The patient receives packed red blood cell transfusion during the surgery as well as intravenous normal saline. He is transferred to the surgical intensive care unit for close monitoring and is successfuly extubated. Twelve hours later, his oxygen saturation started decreasing . The patient has received multiple doses of morphine for pain control since the surgery. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 F), blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 28/min. The patient's pulse oximetry shows 88% on 4 L nasal cannula oxygen. Examination reveals bilateral basal crackles. The abdomen is mildly distended and tender, and bowel sounds are decreased. There is no rebound tenderness or rigidity. Pulmonary artery catheter readings show a cardiac index of 2 L/min/m2 (normal: 2.8-4.2) and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 20 mm Hg (normal: 6-15). Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely in cardiogenic shock due to an acute myocardial infarction (MI). Perioperative MI is common in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Intraoperative hemorhage requiring blood transfusion increases the risk likely due to reduced oxygen delivery to the myocardium. Patients with perioperative MI often lack chest pain, possibly due to receipt of postoperative pain control (eg, morphine). Significant infarction of the left ventricle leads to impaired contractility and a decrease in left ventricular stroke volume. Cardiac index (CI), which is a measure of cardiac output (stroke volume x heart rate) adjusted per body surface area, is low . The increased pressure in the left ventricle is transmitted back to the left atrium and the lungs. Therefore, pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) which estimates left atrial pressure, is elevated. Patients experience dyspnea and hypoxemia due to pulmonary edema, and lung examination reveals bilateral crackles. Decreased cardiac output leads to hypotension, for which the body attempts to compensate by peripheral vasoconstriction and increased systemic vascular resistance.

(Choice A) Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) refers to the development of fever, hypotension, and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema within 6 hours of blood product administration. Because left ventricular function is typically normal, PAC reveals normal or high Cl and normal or low PCWP.

(Choice B) Hypotension due to adrenal crisis is caused by distributive shock and intravascular volume depletion. PAC reveals normal or high Cl and normal or low PCWP.

(Choice D) Obstructive shock due to pulmonary embolism may lead to a decrease in Cl due to decreased delivery of blood through the pulmonary circulation (decreased left ventricular preload). PCWP is generally normal or low.

Educational objective: Perioperative MI is common in patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. Pulmonary Artery Catheter reveals low Cardiac lndex and high Pulmonary Capillary Wedge Pressure.

questions.text: A 73 -year-old man having some exertional shortness of breath for the past few months , is brought to the emergency department after he passed out during an early morning jog. The patient felt lightheaded while jogging and sat down on the curb to prevent a fall. He wnot confused after the episode and did not have bowel or bladder incontinence. The patient has hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide but is healthy otherwise. He has a 20-pack-year smoking history and occasionally drinks wine. His blood pressure 142/90 mm Hg, pulse 30/min, and respirations are 16/min. Carotid pulse is delayed. S2 is diminished and S4 is present. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heared in the right second intercostal space. On neurological examinatin, no focal findings and there are no head traumal signs. An electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm with left ventricular hypertrophy.Cardiac enzymes are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is classical presentat?on of aortic stenosis (AS) . Clinical features of AS include Exertional symptoms - chest pain, dyspnea, dizziness, and syncope ; Delayed and diminished carotid pulse (pulsus parvus et tardus) ; Single and soft S2, audible S4 ; Harsh ejection (Crescendo decrescendo) systolic murmur in second right intercostal space with radiation to carotids. A transthoracic echocardiogram should be obtained in all patients with syncope due to suspected structural heart disease (aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, left ventricular dysfunction, or cardiac tamponade) to confirm diagnosis and plan definitive management. Patents with symptomatic, severe AS should be reffered for aortic valve replacement.

(Choice A) 24-hour electrocardiographic monitoring (Holter monitoring) is useful for the detecton of arrhythmias as a cause of dizziness and/or syncope.

(Choice B) There are no specific neurological symptoms in this patient .

(Choice D) Echocardiogram is recommended prior to exercise testing to assess for organic heart disease (cardiomyopathy or valvular heart disease). Exercise stress testing is contraindicated in patients with symptomatic severe AS.

Educational objective : A transthoracic echocardiogram should be obtained in all patients with syncope due to suspected structural heart disease to confirm diagnosis and plan definitive management.

questions.text: A 48 -year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle accident . The patient is awake and oriented but in distress due to pain in the right lower extremity and groin. Blood pressure is 122/86 mm Hg, pulse is 84/min, and respirations are 16/min. Abrasions and bruises are observed over the posterior and left lateral chest wall. Chest auscultation reveals clear lung fields and no cardiac murmurs. The abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Bruising is visible over the right groin and thigh . Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are palpable. Bedside ultrasound examination reveals no pericardial or free abdominal fluid. Two large-bore intravenous catheters and a Foley catheter are placed. Thirty minutes after arrival, the patient reports difficulty breathing and lightheadedness. Doctor on duty measues blood pressure and it is now 80/50 mm Hg and heart rate is 120/min and regular. Immediate examination shows erythematous rash and wheals over the chest and abdomen. The patient is a hospital house keeper in the same hospital. Which of these is cause of this patient's hemodynamic deterioration?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely in anaphylactic shock due to a latex allergy . Gloves and Foley catheters contain latex. Latex can lead to a spectrum of lgE-mediated type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, including isolated urticarial skin rash , rhinoconjunctivitis, and anaphylaxis. Reaction typically occurs in individuals with previous or repeated exposure (occupational exposure is common in hospital housekeepers) that results in sensitization by the development of lgE antibodies to latex antigens.

Anaphylaxis is a systemic, life-threatening disorder occur by some mediators / triggers,released by mast cells and basophils activated via allergic (IgE-mediated) or nonallergic (non-IgE-mediated) mechanisms. It evolves rapidly, multisystem process involving the integumentary, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and cardiovascular systems. Vasodilation leads to decreased peripheral resistance and leakage of intravascular fluid resulting in hypotension, tachycardia, and poor organ perfusion. Bronchoconstriction leads to wheezing and dyspnea.

Anaphylaxis is a clinical diagnosis, but plasma tryptase and urinary histamine levels are often elevated, allowing diagnostic confirmation. Initial treatment is with rapid administration of intramuscular epinephrine.

(Choice A )Massive bleeding into the thigh can lead to hypovolemic shock and chest trauma can lead to cardiac tamponade resuting in cardiogenic shock. The presence of an urticarial rash and also the initial stable presentation makes these diagnoses less likely .

(Choice C)Rapid development of hypotension and absence of a known infection make early sepsis less likely

(Choice D)Fat embolism can occur following a long-bone fracture and classicaly presents with dyspnea, neurological impairments and a petechial rash. However, the clinical manifestations of fat embolism do not occur until at least 12-24 hours foll owing injury.

Educational objective :

Anaphylaxis is a systemic, life-threatening disorder triggered by mediators released by mast cells and basophils activated via allergic (IgE-mediated) or nonallergic (non-IgE-mediated) mechanisms. It is a rapidly evolving, multisystem process involving the integumentary, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, and cardiovascular systems. Initial treatment is with rapid administration of intramuscular epinephrine.

questions.text: An 85-year-old ventilator-dependent male was endotracheally intubated 10 days ago. He remains unresponsive and is not a candidate for early extubation. The intensive care unit (ICU) attending elects to perform tracheostomy at the bedside. During the procedure, copious dark blood is encountered. This is most likely due to transection of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• The anterior jugular vein can cross the mid-line overlying the proximal trachea. Midline cervical dissection without adequate visualization can injure the vein and require open surgical repair.
  • The other veins do not cross the midline and are not generally at risk in tracheostomy
  • Tracheostomy is the most common surgical procedure for critically ill patients who require extended mechanical ventilation.
  • Open and percutaneous dilatation tracheostomy (PDT) can be safely performed at the head of the bed in the intensive care unit
  • Indications for tracheostomy in critically ill patients:
    • Presence of pathological conditions, prediction of prolonged mechanical intubation, inability to protect the airways or both
    • High-risk airway and airway edema after surgery and maxillofacial trauma
    • High-risk airway due to cervical immobilization for fracture fixation
    • Need for airway surgery due to inability to intubate the patient
  • The time of tracheostomy is controversial.
  • An early tracheostomy (48 hours) is preferred over a delayed tracheostomy (14-16 days) PDT is often used for elective tracheostomy in critically ill adult patients
  • Perioperative complications of percutaneous tracheotomy:
    • Peristomal bleeding due to anterior jugular injury r-veins or thyroid isthmus
    • Injury to the trachea or esophagus, or both, by cutting the posterior wall of the trachea
    • Extraluminal placement, creating an incorrect tract during tracheal cannula placement Loss of airway

questions.text: A 43-year-old teacher underwent left parotidectomy. Upon awakening from surgery, paralysis of the left lower lip was observed. This complication was most likely due to injury of which of the following:
questions.solution:
• Isolated persistent weakness of the lower lip may occur due to division of platysma muscle.
  • Injury to the parotid duct can lead to a parotid fistula.

The lesion of the buccal branch leads to paralysis of the buccinator muscle. Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve leads to ipsilateral facial palsy.

The treatment of choice for benign parotid tumors such as pleomorphic adenoma is superficial parotidectomy (surgical excision with the margin of normal tissue). The facial nerve must be preserved during the procedure The facial nerve exits the skull through the stylomastoid foreman. It enters the parotid gland at a distance of about 1 cm or less and then divides into two branches

  • A larger temporofacial branch that forms the temporal nerve and the zygomatic nerve
  • A smaller cervicofacial branch from which the N . buccalis emerge, marginal mandibularis and cervical

vertebrae Innervation of the facial nerve

  • Innervation of the zygomatic branch orbicularis oculi
  • Innervation of the temporal branch Auricularis anterior, auricularis superior, frontalis, orbicularis oculi, corrugator superciliii
  • Upper and lower buccal innervation of the buccal nerve
  • The margin of the lower jaw innervates the muscles of the lower lip and chin
  • Platysma neck inserts The main methods of locating the trunk of the facial nerve can be divided into antegrade and retrograde
  • Conley pointer lower part of the cartilage canal. The facial nerve is 1 cm deep and below this point
  • Upper edge of the posterior digastric abdomen
  • Squamotympanic fissure
  • Styloid process (the nerve is superficial) 
  • Mastoid process
  • The retrograde technique is based on the identification of one of the nerve branches, which is then proximal is followed until the main strain is identified Complications of parotid surgery
  • Frey syndrome
  • Facial numbness
  • Facial paralysis
  • Lobe necrosis
  • Fistula (parotid) 
  • Temporary weakness of the facial nerve

Sialocele

  • Infection The facial paralysis is the most important complication in parotid surgery.The paralysis of the temporal facial nerve can occur by 5% to 10% of patients and is due to the manipulation of the nerve during operation, and the function returns gradually for a few months

questions.text: In laparoscopic appendectomy, when a large bowel injury was caused during trochar placement.Which class of surgical wounds are obtained?
questions.solution:
1. Clean wounds - no part of the gastrointestinal, respiratory, or genitourinary tract is entered(eg.breast Sx, herniorrhaphy).
  2. Clean contaminated wounds - systems areentered, but it does not have the evidence of active infection or gross spillage(eg.electivecholecystectomy).
  3. Contaminated wounds- open accidental wounds which has an early injury, by which bacteria enter into sterile area of body .Examples involve invading abdominal trauma, large tissue injury and enterotomy at the time of bowel obstruction.
  4. Dirty wounds - traumatic wounds with delay in treatment that cause necrosis with presence of purulent material and has highrisk of contamination.Eg- perforated diverticulitis and necrotizing soft tissue infections.

Section: 362

questions.text: All of the following are the components of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), except:
questions.solution:
Infection refers to the presence of microorganisms in host tissue or the bloodstream.

The typical findings of calor, rubor, and dolor in areas such as the skin or subcutaneous tissue are common at the site of infection.

In normal individuals with intact host defenses, a majority of infections are related to these local presentations, hence, systemic presentations such as increased temperature, increased white blood cell (WBC) count, tachycardia, or tachypnea. These systemic presentations constitute the systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

Section : 362

questions.text: After various medical and physical examinations conducted, you have been selected for the post of Medical Officer in Paramilitary forces. As  part of training, you underwent rigorous physical training. Within few days of training, there developed a pain over right foot while running which diminishes on rest. X ray of right foot was taken shown below. What will be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
MARCH FRACTURE:

  • It is a ‘Fatigue’ fracture of second or third metatarsal neck, resulting from long continued or often repeated stress, particularly from prolonged walking or running in those not accustomed to it. Thus, it may occur in army recruits freshly committed to marching – hence the term ‘March fracture’. The fracture heals spontaneously, so treatment is purely symptomatic.

Above image shows fatigue fracture of 2nd metatarsal

  • Radiograph helps in the diagnosis and the treatment is rest, NSAIDs, splints, elastic crepe bandage application, etc. This is an important cause of chronic midfoot pain and it requires prompt identification and treatment.
  • In the given case, X ray was negative for metatarsal fracture, in such cases MRI is the modality of choice.

questions.text: A 12 year old boys presents to ER with H/O fall associated with right upper arm pain, no significant past history noted. A radiograph for the following was done and is given below. which among the following is not a treatment modality of the given pathology:
questions.solution:
The given Radiograph has characteristic Fallen leaf sign which points toward Unicameral bone cyst.

Unicameral Bone Cyst:

  • True Cyst
  • Most common in the proximal humerus and femur.
  • The lesions are most active during skeletal growth and usually heal spontaneously at maturity.
  • Asymptomatic

Radiographs:

  • Centrally located, purely lytic lesion with a well-marginated outline.
  • Thinned cortical fragment fractures and falls into the base of the lesion confirming its empty cystic nature.
  • Fallen fragment sign is pathognomonic of a unicameral bone cyst, bone fragment, may also hinge around and move with fluid called as trap door sign.
  • Unicameral bone cysts are classified as
    • Active: when they are within 1 cm of the physis
    • Latent: when they are closer to the diaphysis.

Rx:

  • Small, asymptomatic lesions in the upper extremities can be treated with observation with serial plain radiographs.
  • Larger lesions (lesions at risk for pathological fracture), symptomatic lesions, and lesions in the lower extremities usually are treated with :
  • Curettage (with or without bone grafting or internal fixation)
  • Aspiration and injection (steroids, bone marrow aspirate, demineralized bone matrix, or sclerosant).

Figures: (A) Unicameral or simple bone cyst (B) Fallen fragment (leaf) sign

questions.text: The given radiograph signifies a malignant tumor which occurs most commonly in metaphysis, causes Hyperglycemia. It has the best prognosis among all the other malignant tumors. It's also Radio and chemo resistant. Identify the commonest site of occurrence of the given tumor ?
questions.solution:
The given case outright points towards CHONDROSARCOMA

  • They can occur in any location however, Most are located in a proximal location such as:
     
    • Proximal femur(most common)
    • proximal humerus
    • pelvis

They occur in bones derived from enchondral ossification.

Usually metaphyseal and central i.e. arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification(described as punctate, comma, popcorn calcification).

  • It occurs over a broad age range:
    • Peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma,and
    • Between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma.

Treatment: Wide local excision / radical exicision

questions.text: A 42 year old male with frequent attacks of joint pain, underwent an X-ray showing soft tissue swelling as shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Tophi appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges -Martel’s or G’ sign.

GOUT:-

  • Sometimes only feature is acute pain and tenderness. hyperuricemia is not diagnostic and is often seen in normal middle aged men.
  • During acute attack X-rays show only soft tissue swelling.
  • Chronic gout may result in joint space narrowing and secondary OA.

questions.text: In this picture of mask ventilation little finger is used for?
questions.solution:
There are several methods for holding the mask to open the airway and a tight seal. The picture shown here is One handed technique. The thumb and index finger on the left hand placed on the mask body to push downward to hold the mask to the face and prevent leaks. Remaining three fingers placed on the mandible or the inferior part of the mask. Finger pressure should be placed on the bony mandible and not on the soft tissues supporting the base of the tongue, which may obstruct the airway. The little finger is placed under the angle of the mandible and used to thrust the jaw anteriorly which pulls the tongue forward to prevent obstruction of the upper airway. This is the most important maneuver to allow ventilation to the patient.

Other methods for holding the mask are Two handed method, Claw hand technique, Esmarch-Heiberg maneuver.

questions.text: A 45 year old male who was a known case of alcoholic liver disease admitted with both bone fracture right forearm, posted for open reduction and internal fixation with plating under brachial plexus block using local anesthetics. The drug which do not need dose reduction in this patient would be-
questions.solution:
Severe liver disease may slow the clearance of amino amide local anesthetics and significant drug levels may therefore accumulate. So dose reduction is necessary in hepatic dysfunction.

Amide local anesthetics undergo varying rates of metabolism by microsomal enzymes located primarily in the liver. The initial step is conversion of amide based to amino carboxylic acid under cyclic aniline derivative. Complete metabolism involves hydroxylation of the aniline moiety and N-dealkylation of the amino carboxylic acid

Ester local anesthetics undergo hydrolysis by cholinesterase enzyme principally in the plasma and to a lesser extent in the liver. The exception to hydrolysis of ester local anesthetics in the plasma is cocaine which undergoes significant metabolism in the liver(hepatic carboxylesterase and partially excreted unexchanged in the urine).

Aminoesters

  • Cocaine
  • Procaine
  • Chloroprocaine
  • Benzocaine
  • Tetracaine

Aminoamides

  • Lidocaine
  • Mepivacaine
  • Bupivacaine
  • Levobupivacaine
  • Ropivacaine
  • Prilocaine
  • Dibucaine

questions.text: A 40 year old female who was a case of seizure disorder posted for total thyroidectomy under general anesthesia. She had shivering in the perioperative period which was treated with Inj. Pethidine 25 mg IM. This postoperative shivering should be treated promptly because it is associated with-

choices.text: Decreased heart rate and blood pressure

questions.solution:
Postoperative shivering

  • Postoperative shivering is usually but not always associated with hypothermia. Its incidence may be as high as 66% in general anaesthesia. Although thermoregulatory mechanisms explain shivering in hypothermic patients, different mechanisms have been proposed to explain shivering in normothermic patients. Brain and spinal cord do not recover simultaneously from general anaesthesia. More rapid recovery of spinal cord function results in uninhibited spinal reflexes manifests as clonic activity.
  • Risk factors -Young age, endoprosthetic surgery, core hypothermia
  • Postoperative shivering can greatly increase oxygen consumption, catecholamine release, cardiac output, heart rate and blood pressure, and intracerebral and intraocular pressure.
  • Many drugs, notably meperidine, clonidine, and tramadol, clonidine, ketamine, ondansetron can be used to reduce postoperative shivering once it starts. Of those meperidine 12.5-25 mg iv most commonly used in adults. prevention of hypothermia and intraoperative dexmeditomedine infusion are prophylactic measures.

questions.text: Role of egg lecithin in propofol formulation is?
questions.solution:
Propofol is a substituted isopropylphenol (2,6 diisopropylphenol)

Constituents of propofol(1% solution)

  • 10% Soyabean oil (as oil phase)
  • 2.25% Glycerol
  • 1.2% Purified egg phosphatide(egg lecithin-as emulsifying agent)
  • Disodium edetate 0.005% with sodium hydroxide (as preservative to adjust the pH to 7 to 8.5)
  • Sodium metabisulfite 0.25mg/ml (as preservative to adjust the pH to 4.5 to 6.4)

questions.text: A 65 old male presents to emergency with pain in the flank, hypotension and pulsatile abdominal mass and the following image is obtained on CECT, Most Likely Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ruptured Abdominal aortic aneurysm (RAAA)

  1. Ruptured AAA presents with a classical triad of pain in the flank or back, hypotension and a pulsatile abdominal mass; however, only about half have the full triad. Tachycardia develops. Shock may occur.
  2. The patient will complain of the pain and may feel cold, sweaty and faint on standing.
  3. The following symptoms are listed with approximate frequency of presentation
  • Abdominal pain (60%)
  • Back pain (70%)
  • Syncope (30%)
  • Vomiting (20%).

Primary signs of abdominal aorta aneurysm rupture-

Periaortic stranding

Retroperitoneal Hematoma

Extravasated night of iv contrast

Secondary signs of AAA rupture

High attenuating crescent

Focal discontinuity of intimate calcification

Draped aorta

questions.text: Identify the structure in the given chest X – ray:
Investigation of choice for the disease associated with the given image?
questions.solution:
Points to remember:

1. Light bulb appearance on MRI abdomen → Pheochromocytoma

2. Light bulb appearance on MRI liver (T2W) → Hemangioma

3. Light bulb appearance on MRI brain (DW-MRI) → Acute infarct

4. Light bulb appearance on shoulder radiograph→ Posterior dislocation

The given MRI image shows a hepatic hemangioma - light bulb appearance on MRI abdomen

Points to remember:

→ IOC for Adrenal Pheochromocytoma → MRI

→ For extra-abdominal Pheochromocytoma → DOPA PET > MIBG > MRI

questions.text: A 55 year old man underwent Orthopedic surgery 3 weeks back and now complains of calf pain and swelling . The physician suspecting DVT. Which of the following is the IOC for DVT ?
questions.solution:
• Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a blood clot that develops within a deep vein in the body, usually in the leg.
  • Investigation of choice for DVT is Doppler USG
  • Doppler USG:
    • Shows absent color fill due to absence of blood flow in the vein
    • Shows lack of compressibility of vein - ability to completely flatten a vein with compression is the most useful way to be certain that a clot is not present: ABSENT WINKING SIGN.

​​​​​​​

Figure: Ultrasound gray scale image showing thrombus in the left popliteal vein

questions.text: An obese primigravida delivers a baby at term by normal vaginal delivery. She is a case of gestational diabetes mellitus diagnosed at 24 weeks by a glucose tolerance test. The baby is taken to NICU for evaluation. Which of the following is the most likely complication that could be seen in this infant?
questions.solution:
Neonatal complications in the infant of diabetic mother ·

Congenital abnormalities: Fetal malformations are not seen with GDM as their risk is directly related to glycemic control in the first trimester, the higher the HbA1c, the higher the risk of malformations.

Hypoglycemia: excessive prenatal transplacental glucose à fetal hyperinsulinemiaàhypoglycaemia

Macrosomia and traumatic delivery: fetal hyperinsulinemia stimulates excessive somatic growth

Hypocalcemia: failure to increase PTH (parathormone) synthesis after birth

Hypomagnesemia

Polycythemia: elevated erythropoietin from relative intrauterine hypoxia

Hyperbilirubinemia: liver immaturity and breakdown of excessive neonatal RBCs

Hyperviscosity syndrome

Apnea and bradycardia

Hyaline membrane disease: delayed pulmonary surfactant production

Incorrect options

Option A; The most common type of heart defect in a newborn is a ventricular septal defect. A ventricular septal defect is a birth defect of the heart in which there is a hole in the wall (septum) that is separating the two lower chambers of the heart. This wall is also called the ventricular septum.

Option B; Neonatal hyperglycemia is one of the most common metabolic abnormalities encountered in preterm and critically ill newborns. Although the definition can be varied, a blood glucose concentration greater than 125 mg/dL or a plasma or serum glucose concentration greater than 150 mg/dL often is referred to as hyperglycemic.

Option D; A birth weight of fewer than 5 pounds, 8 ounces can be diagnosed as low birth weight. Babies weighing less than 3 pounds, 4 ounces at birth can be considered as very low birth weight.

Educational Objective;

The most common type of heart defect in a newborn is a ventricular septal defect. This is a heart defect due to the abnormal connection between the lower chambers of the heart.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida presents at 24 weeks of pregnancy for a routine antenatal visit. On examination her BP is 144/ 96 mmHg, PR is 88/min, systemic and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Her previous BP records have been normal. Investigations are as follows CBC : Hb: 9.8 gm%, TLC 8400/cumm. platelet count 200,000/mL Se. Bil : 0.6 mg/dL, s.creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, 24 hour urine protein is 320 mg/day. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of pre-eclampsia characterized by a blood pressure of >140/90 mmHg with proteinuria in excess of 300 mg/24 hours, developing first time after 20 weeks.

Preeclampsia: BP 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks of gestation, and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).

In preeclampsia multi-organ involvement like thrombocytopenia, renal dysfunction, liver dysfunction, pulmonary edema can also be seen.

Excess protein in the urine, severe headache, decreased urine output, visual abnormalities, epigastric or right upper quadrant pain are the warning signs.

Incorrect options

Option A; BP >140/90 mm Hg before pregnancy or diagnosed before 20 weeks of gestation, or hypertension first diagnosed after 20 weeks of gestation and persistent after 12 weeks postpartum.

Option C; In a pregnant female with preeclampsia, convulsion that is not attributed to any other causes is termed eclampsia. Preeclampsia + seizures. Seizures may occur before, during, or after labor.

Option D; BP 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks and proteinuria is not present. BP returns to normal within 12 weeks after delivery.

Educational Objective;

Pre-eclampsia is defined as a BP 140/90 mm Hg or greater for the first time during pregnancy, after 20 weeks of gestation and proteinuria is present (300 mg in 24 h or 1+ protein or greater on dipstick).

questions.text: A 24-year-old presents to the antenatal clinic with a history of amenorrhea of 2 months and a positive pregnancy test. She is now married for 1 year and this is her first pregnancy, she has had multiple sexual partners prior to marriage and has never used contraception. On routine antenatal testing, she is found to be HIV positive. She is currently asymptomatic and wishes to continue the pregnancy. Reports for HIV viral load and CD4 counts are awaited. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Start ART and advice follow up
Start ART if HIV viral loads >1000 copies/mL
Refer ART till end of first trimester

questions.solution:
HIV detected in pregnancy should be managed with ART (anti-retroviral therapy) at the time of detection irrespective of counts or stage of disease and is not an indication for termination of pregnancy as proper treatment and follow-up can greatly reduce maternal morbidity and perinatal transmission.

Risk factors for HIV

  • Intercourse with infected persons
  • IV drug abuse
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Unprotected intercourse
  • History of STDs

Presentation of HIV in pregnancy

  • Asymptomatic: detected on routine antenatal testing. All antenatal women are offered HIV testing with an opt-out approach.
  • Nonspecific symptoms : fever, dyspnea, weight loss
  • History of opportunistic infections
  • History of other STDs: vaginal discharge, genital ulcers

Antenatal management

  • Partner testing and treatment, advice barrier contraception
  • Anti-retroviral therapy : to be initiated irrespective of viral load
  • Screening for opportunistic infections

 

Investigations

  • Viral load: initial visit and 2-4 weeks after initiation of ART, monthly till the viral load is suppressed, then at 34-36 weeks to determine the mode of delivery · CD4 counts: initial visit and 3 monthly
  • Standard prenatal tests: blood counts, bacteriuria screening, BUN, creatinine, liver functions and follow up after initiation of ART
  • HSV, CMV, toxoplasma, hepatitis B and C
  • Chest X-ray and tuberculosis screening
  • Evaluation for the need of pneumococcal, hepatitis A, B, Tdap, and influenza vaccines
  • Antenatal USG
  • Mode of delivery: cesarean section is advised if viral load >1000 copies/ mL or in case of any obstetric indication. For all other cases, vaginal delivery may be done

Incorrect options

Option A; HIV is not an indication for termination of pregnancy as proper treatment and follow-up can greatly reduce maternal morbidity and perinatal transmission.

Option C; HIV detected in pregnancy should be managed with ART (antiretroviral therapy) at the time of detection irrespective of counts or stage of disease

Option D; ART should be continued throughout and after pregnancy to hold off symptoms and complications. ART should be started in all HIV patients regardless of counts and stage of the disease.

Option E; HIV detected in pregnancy should be managed with ART (anti-retroviral therapy) at the time of detection irrespective of counts or stage of the disease. ART should be continued throughout and after pregnancy to hold off symptoms and complications.

Educational Objective;

HIV detected in pregnancy should be managed with ART (anti-retroviral therapy) at the time of detection irrespective of counts or stage of disease and is not an indication for termination of pregnancy as proper treatment and follow-up can greatly reduce maternal morbidity and perinatal transmission.

questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravida has conceived after ovulation induction and presents for routine antenatal evaluation. She has no complaints at present and she is 12 weeks gestation from her date of last menstrual period. Her doctor advises her for an aneuploidy screening test, considering her advanced age of conception. She has no past or family history of aneuploidies. Which of the following is the most appropriate test(s) to be prescribed at this stage?

choices.text: Dual marker + ultrasound for nuchal translucency
Quadruple marker + ultrasound for nasal bone

questions.solution:
Dual marker along with ultrasound for nuchal translucency is a first-trimester screening test for aneuploidies (Downs’s syndrome and other trisomies). Chorionic villous sampling is also done at this gestation, but it is a diagnostic test.

Screening tests for aneuploidies FIRST TRIMESTER:11-13 weeks: DUAL MARKER + Nuchal Translucency (80% sensitive)

 

PAPP-A

Free B HCG

DUAL MARKER

Decreases

Increases

 

SECOND TRIMESTER: TRIPLE/ QUADRUPLE MARKERS (16-18 weeks)

 

Free B HCG

AFP

Unconjugated estriol

Inhibin A

TRIPLE MARKER

Increases

Decreases

Decreases

  

QUADRUPLE MARKER (80% sensitive)

Increases

Decreases

Decreases

Increases

 

INTEGRATED SCREENING: First + second-trimester screen: 94-96% sensitivity: BEST for screening Ultrasound level II or detailed anomaly scan to look for soft tissue markers to be done at 18-22 weeks

Diagnostic tests

Chorionic villus sampling - done at First trimester(10-13th weeks)

Amniocentesis - done at second trimester(16-18th weeks)

Percutaneous umbilical blood sampling (cordocentesis) - done after 18 weeks.

Incorrect options

Option A; Chorionic villus sampling is a diagnostic test done in the First trimester(10-13th weeks). In this test biopsy specimen of the chorionic villus is taken and tested for chromosomal abnormalities usually with FISH or PCR.

Option C; Quadruple markers are done in the second trimester around 16 - 18 weeks. In the case given gestational age of the patient is 12 weeks in which we usually do dual marker and nuchal translucency.

Option D; Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test done in the second trimester(16-18th weeks). In this procedure sample of amniotic fluid is taken and tested for genetic or chromosomal conditions.

Educational Objective;

Screening for downs syndrome can be done by serum markers in the first trimester ( Dual marker: PAPP-A and bHCG) and second trimester( Triple marker with bHCG, AFP, uE3 or Quadruple with Inhibin added), USG in the First trimester (for Nuchal translucency and nasal bone detection) & second trimester (anomaly scan)

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the physician preconceptionally for advice. She is a known epileptic on anticonvulsant therapy with phenytoin for 10 years. She has been well controlled on therapy and her last seizure was 8 years ago. She and her partner have been using contraceptive pills for the past two years but have now stopped using them. She has no other significant medical history and has regular menses. Examinations show BP 122/78 mmHg, PR 105/min, the systemic and abdominal examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate pre conceptional counseling for this patient?

choices.text: Should not attempt a pregnancy and opt for adoption or surrogacy instead as epilepsy causes fetal malformations
Increase the dose of phenytoin due to high risk of seizures in pregnancy
Stop anticonvulsant therapy and plan a pregnancy
Folate supplementation and consider switching to levetiracitam

questions.solution:
Anticonvulsants like phenytoin and phenobarbitone are folate antagonists and are known to cause neural tube defects in the fetus, thus folate supplementation with 4 mg/day must be done.

EPILEPSY IN PREGNANCY

Anticonvulsant therapy

  • The lowest dose of monotherapy is the goal. Multidrug therapy increases the risk of malformations. It is preferable to increase the dose if needed then add another drug
  • AED (Antiepileptic Drugs): phenytoin, phenobarbital, and sodium valproate are known teratogens with known fetal malformation risk. A consideration to switching to lamotrigine and levetiracetam should be made which have the lowest risk of malformation. Most antiepileptics are safe with breastfeeding

Pregnancy-related risks

  • Increased seizure rates: up to 20-30%. This has two important causes:
  1. Lower seizure threshold
  2. Subtherapeutic anticonvulsant levels
  • Fetal malformations: more likely due to anticonvulsant than epilepsy itself

Pregnancy complications

  • spontaneous abortions
  • APH and PPH
  • hypertensive disorders
  • preterm birth
  • IUGR
  • cesarean delivery

 

Incorrect options

Option A; Women with epilepsy can become pregnant. The major pregnancy-related risk of epilepsy is the chances of increased seizure rates. So seizure control is very important which can be attained by effective medication.

Option B; Anticonvulsants like phenytoin and phenobarbitone are folate antagonists and are known to cause neural tube defects in the fetus. A consideration to switching to lamotrigine and levetiracetam should be made which have the lowest risk of malformation.

Option C; Anticonvulsants should be continued throughout pregnancy. If the patient is phenytoin, phenobarbital, or sodium valproate a consideration to switching to lamotrigine and levetiracetam should be made which have the lowest risk of malformation.

Educational objective;

Antiepileptic drugs like phenytoin are folate antagonists, folate supplementation with 4 mg/day should be started, most congenital malformations are due to these drugs rather than epilepsy. Lowest dose monotherapy should be the goal and safer anticonvulsants like levetiracetam and lamotrigine must be used after consultation with the neurologist.

questions.text: A 32-year-old P2L2 woman presents with painful and engorged right breast for 5 days. She delivered a healthy male newborn 2 weeks ago by cesarean section. The pain stays through most of the day and subsides minimally and transiently with analgesics. She has no past history of any serious illness. On examination, PR is 108/min BP is 122/76 mmHg, temp is 100.4’F, the right breast is enlarged, tender, and appears warmer than surrounding skin and the left breast. the nipple of the right breast shows cracks and is everted. The left breast, areola, and nipple appear healthy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Acute puerperal mastitis: Occurs due to overproduction of milk or insufficient drainage. The stagnant milk in the breasts is then infected by organisms from the baby’s nasopharynx Most common organism- Staphylococcus aureus (especially MRSA). Other organisms include coagulase-negative Staphylococcus and Streptococcus viridans.

The most common source of the infection is the baby's nasopharynx.

Symptoms and signs

  • Fever with chills, myalgia, malaise
  • Engorged and tender breast
  • Mostly unilateral

Approximately 10 percent of women with mastitis develop an abscess that requires incision and drainage.

Treatment: Continue breastfeeding or breast milk expression, Antibiotics: Dicloxacillin, 500 mg orally four times daily, maybe started empirically. Erythromycin is given to women who are penicillin hypersensitive.

Incorrect options

Option A; Galactocele is a retention cyst containing milk due to an obstruction of a lactiferous duct. It presents as a firm mass and is often subareolar in position. There are no signs of inflammation such as tenderness, warmth, or fever.

Option C; Breast engorgement is bilateral tender breasts due to increased milk production or inadequate drainage, however, signs of inflammation such as warmth over skin and fever are much lesser compared to mastitis. Engorgement. If left untreated may develop into mastitis which may in turn progress to a breast abscess.

Option D; Malignancy presents as a lump in unilateral breast with signs of malignancy such as fixed irregular mass, ulceration, induration, dimpling, nipple retraction, axillary lymphadenopathy.

Educational Objective;

Mastitis occurs due to overproduction of milk or insufficient drainage such that the stagnant milk in the breasts gets infected by organisms from the baby’s nasopharynx causing signs of inflammation such as fever with chills, myalgia, malaise, engorged and tender breast and is mostly unilateral.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents to the physician for routine postpartum evaluation. She had an LSCS 1 week back done for prolonged leaking with nonprogress of labor. She had postpartum hemorrhage which was managed by oxytocin and methyl ergometrine. She presently has some constipation which is relieved with lactulose syrup. She has mild lower abdominal pain which increases with suckling by the baby. There is no fever. She is breastfeeding her newborn well. She is still having vaginal bleeding and is soaking 2 to 3 pads every day. Examination shows PR of 78/min, BP of 122/76 mmHg, abdominal examination shows an incision with interrupted sutures, which are now cut, there is also a firm globular mobile, non-tender pelvic mass measuring 14 weeks size. Vaginal examination shows bleeding not associated with foul smell and episiotomy is healthy. Her breasts are enlarged and show milk discharge bilaterally. CBC shows Hb 11.2 gm%, TLC 10,500/cumm, platelets 1.7 lakh/cumm. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The presence of a firm globular abdominal mass arising from the pelvis is suggestive of a well-contracted uterus in a postpartum case. At 1 week, the uterus is still an abdominal organ and becomes pelvic by 2 weeks. Vaginal bleeding and enlarged lactating breasts are also normal signs of the puerperium.

Signs and symptoms of normal puerperium

  • Afterpains: pains due to intermittent uterine contractions, more pronounced in multipara and increases during breastfeeding due to release of oxytocin
  • Lochia: sloughing of decidual tissue results in a vaginal discharge of variable quantity. The discharge contains erythrocytes, shredded decidua, epithelial cells, and bacteria. For the first few days after delivery, this is mainly blood—lochia rubra. After 3 or 4 days, lochia becomes progressively pale in color—lochia serosa. After approximately the 10th day, because of an admixture of leukocytes and reduced fluid content, lochia assumes a white or yellow-white color—lochia alba. The average duration of lochial discharge ranges from 24 to 36 days
  • Lactational changes in breasts: breasts become enlarged, engorged with milk supply as it increases and starts to eject milk.
  • Uterine involution: Normal rate of involution of uterus post delivery: 1-2 cm/ day.

Size of the uterus:

1. immediately after delivery: just below the umbilicus

2. Uterus become pelvic organ in 10-14 days

3. Uterus comes to normal size in 4-6 weeks

Incorrect options

Option A; Retained products at one week would present as accelerated bleeding or signs of infections such as foul-smelling lochia and subinvolution. In the given case there is no evidence for retained products.

Option B; Serum prolactin levels are not indicated as changes in the breast are normal for the process of lactogenesis. Serum prolactin levels are normally high in the postpartum.

Option C; High vaginal swab is indicated when there are signs of infection such as foul-smelling liquor, fever, or raised TLC. In the given case we do not require a high vaginal swab.

Educational Objective;

The normal rate of involution of uterus post delivery: 1-2 cm/ day. The uterus becomes pelvic organ by 2 weeks and returns to normal size by 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea for 4 months. She is presently nursing her 4-month-old baby which was delivered by a cesarean section done for breech presentation and pre-eclampsia at full-term pregnancy. There was some postpartum hemorrhage which was managed conservatively and did not require a blood transfusion. She is exclusively breastfeeding since then, around 6-8 times in the day and 2 feeds at night. Her only medication is a calcium supplement. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Examination reveals stable vitals and unremarkable organ systems, breasts are enlarged and lactating and no mass is felt per abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of her amenorrhea?

choices.text: Absence of GnRH secretion due to pituitary apoplexy

questions.solution:
This is a case of lactational amenorrhea which occurs in women who are lactating due to prolactin-induced inhibition of GnRH at hypothalamus level, which in turn does not stimulate the pituitary to make LH or FSH, thus preventing ovulation. It is also an effective method of contraception in women who are exclusively breastfeeding.

Lactational Amenorrhea

The physiological basis of anovulation and amenorrhea is due to elevated levels of serum prolactin associated with suckling.

Suckling suppresses the normal pattern of pulsatile release of GnRH and hence LH and prevents the normal growth of follicles.

With the cessation of breastfeeding the pulsatile pattern of LH returns to normal, sensitivity to estrogen negative feedback declines, and follicle growth can continue and ovulation will occur.

Incorrect options

Option B; Pituitary apoplexy or Sheehan’s syndrome occurs due to massive obstetric hemorrhage leading to pituitary infarction. It presents with amenorrhea associated with failed lactation.

Option C; Asherman syndrome is an acquired condition of the uterus. Asherman syndrome presents after uterine curettage or any form of uterine trauma and there is no such history in this case.

Option D; GnRH stimulates the pituitary gland to secrete luteinizing hormone and Follicle-stimulating hormone. Stimulation of GnRH does not cause amenorrhea.

Educational Objective;

Lactational amenorrhea occurs in women who are lactating, due to prolactin-induced inhibition of GnRH at hypothalamus level, which in turn does not stimulate the pituitary to make LH or FSH, thus preventing ovulation

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents at term with labor pains. Her pains started 8 hours back and have been slowly increasing in duration and intensity and each pain is associated with tightening of the abdomen. Her antenatal records show no high-risk factor and an ultrasound a week ago shows a single live fetus corresponding to 38 weeks gestation, fundal placenta, adequate liquor, and cephalic presentation. On examination uterine contractions are felt 3 in every 10 minutes, lasting 40-50 seconds, fetal heart rate is good. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is fully dilated and the fetal head is felt at 0 stations. On the fetal head, anterior fontanelle and supra-orbital ridge are felt. Membranes are present and the pelvis appears average, gynaecoid. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Palpation of supraorbital ridges and anterior fontanelle on a fetal head is suggestive of brow presentation. There is no mechanism for normal delivery in brow presentation as the engaging diameter is mento-vertical (14 cm) which cannot pass through any diameter of the pelvis.

BROW PRESENTATION: The diameter of engagement is MentoVertical which is 14 cms and such malposition of the head occurs due to failure of flexion of head such that it stays in a deflexed head/ military position. Supraorbital ridges and anterior fontanelle is palpable vaginally and the occiput is felt at a higher station than the sinciput. There is no mechanism of labor and delivery is done by cesarean section. Causes of brow presentation can be anencephaly(most common cause), intrauterine death, multiparty, or prematurity.

Incorrect options

Option A; Oxytocin is used to induce labor and is used to produce strong uterine contractions. In this case, the patient is in labor and already has strong contraction so oxytocin is not used.

Option B; Artificial rupture of the membrane is to rupture the amniotic sac intentionally. It is usually done to induce labor but in this case, the patient is already having active contractions.

Option D; In the case of brow presentation (mento vertical)There is no mechanism of labor and delivery is done by cesarean section.

Educational Objective;

Brow presentation occurs due to incomplete flexion or extension of fetal head such that it remains in a deflexed position and the engaging diameter (Mentovertical 14 cm) is too big to negotiate the pelvis and hence delivery is by cesarean section.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents at 39 weeks of pregnancy for antenatal evaluation. She is a diabetic on insulin, is hypothyroid, taking thyroxine supplementation, and is short-statured.
