Her sugars presently are uncontrolled and so she is admitted for induction of labor, as the bishops are favorable and pelvis appears adequate. She goes into labor after a single dose of misoprostol and is thereafter augmented with oxytocin. Labour progresses smoothly till the second stage with adequate contractions, however, there is the arrest of descent of fetal head in the second stage. An emergency LSCS is performed and a live male baby weighing 4200 gms is delivered. Which of the following in the patient’s history is a risk factor for such presentation?
questions.solution:
This is a case of a macrosomic baby (>4000gms) that went into the arrest of descent in the second stage of labor due to cephalopelvic disproportion. Diabetes in pregnancy is an important risk factor for macrosomia.

Criteria for Macrosomia: If the fetal parameters on the growth chart are beyond the 90th percentile for normal or the fetal weight is more than 4000 gms

Risk factors for macrosomia include

  • maternal obesity maternal diabetes or GDM
  • previous large baby
  • grand multiparity
  • prolonged pregnancy

Incorrect options

Option A; Primiparity is not a risk factor for macrosomia but grand multiparity is considered as a risk factor for macrosomia.

Option B; Short stature is not associated with an increase in baby size. An average baby of 2.75 to 3.25 Kgs in a short stature woman might be too large for that mother but definitely not a Macrocosmic baby by itself.

Option D; Hypothyroidism is not associated with macrosomia. It is rather associated with low birth weight babies, preterm delivery, perinatal morbidity, neonatal hyperthyroidism

Educational Objective;

The arrest of descent of the second stage of labor can occur due to cephalopelvic disproportion which can in turn result from fetal macrosomia even in an average-sized pelvis. Diabetes is a known risk factor for macrosomia.

questions.text: A 29-year-old primigravida presents at 38 weeks + 4 days for routine evaluation. All her antenatal records so far are normal and she is taking her daily iron and calcium supplements regularly. On examination, however, her BP is 150/100 mmHg and the obstetrician plans to terminate the pregnancy. Fetal heart tracing is reactive. A vaginal examination reveals no cervical dilatation, posterior cervix with a medium consistency, a cervical length of 3cm, and vertex at a station of -3. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This is a case requiring induction of labour with a non-favorable cervix (Bishop’s score). A cervical ripening agent should be used here followed by augmentation of labour. Dinoprostone gel is a safe and effective cervical ripening agent. Bishop's score is a quantifiable method used to predict labor induction outcomes. A Bishop score of 4 or less identifies an unfavorable cervix and maybe an indication for cervical ripening. Bishop score before inducing labor>=8 conveys a high likelihood for successful induction.

Score

0

1

2

3

Dilation (in cm)

Closed

1-2

3-4

5

Length (in cm)

>4

3-4

1-2

0

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

-

Position

Posterior

Midline

Anterior

-

Head: station

-3

-2

-1,0

+1,+2

 

‘Effacement’ of the cervix is now replaced by ‘Length’ of the cervix from the original bishop score In the given situation, the score is 2 (one point each for length and consistency, zero for all other parameters), which indicates the use of cervical ripening agents. Cervical ripening agents

Agent

Route/ dose

PGE2 (dinprostone gel)

Cervical 0.5 mg, repeat in 6 hours, max 3 doses, posterior fornix 10 mg

PGE1 (misoprostol)

Vaginal 25 mcg, repeat 3-6 hourlyOral 50-100 mcg, repeat 3-6 hourly

Transcervical foleys catheter

Fill to 80 mL, insert transcervical with traction

Hygroscopic dilators

Laminaria tent, transcervical

 

Prostaglandins like PGE2 and PGE1 along with cervical ripening also cause myometrial contractions and thus, induction of labour. These can, however, be associated with hyperstimulation and tachysystole, and thus a watch on uterine contractions and fetal heart rate is warranted.

Incorrect options

Option A; Unfavourable bishops are not an indication for LSCS in pre-eclampsia unless an emergency arises such as fetal distress.

Option C; Oxytocin does not cause effective induction in unfavorable bishop score so oxytocin is most likely not be used in this case.

Option D; Methylergometrine can cause sudden and strong uterine contractions and are agents for the management of atonic PPH but are not used for induction of labour/ cervical ripening as they can cause uterine rupture.

Educational objective;

A poor bishop score or an unfavorable cervix is an indication for use of cervical ripening agents such as PGE1, PGE2, foleys transcervical catheter, or hygroscopic dilators, the first two being used more commonly.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl is brought to the physician's office by her mother due to complaints of indigestion and diffuse lower abdominal pain for the past 4 months. She feels tired and nauseated most of the time but has not been vomiting. The pain is limited to the lower abdomen and does not increase or decrease with activity. She has normal bladder and bowel habits with a slight increase in the frequency of urination, There has been no weight loss over the period. She consumes a healthy and balanced diet mainly composed of fruits vegetables and meat. She plays for her volleyball team from school and is good at athletics. She has not yet had her first menstrual period. Her father has a history of hypertension and diabetes controlled on medications. On examination she is 5’5’’ tall, weighs 120 lb, BP is 126/78 mmHg, PR 82/min. chest and CVS are unremarkable. Breasts are tanner stage 5 and are tender to touch. A mobile mass is felt in the lower abdomen with its not limit not reachable. Which of the following is the next most appropriate investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has primary amenorrhea at 15 years of age with symptoms of early pregnancy such as nausea, indigestion, fatigue, increased frequency of urination, and diffuse lower abdominal pain. An abdominal mass with an unreachable lower limit is suggestive of a pelvic mass most likely to be an intrauterine pregnancy in this case. A urine pregnancy test or a serum b HCG is likely to provide a diagnosis.

Signs presumptive of pregnancy include

  • Amenorrhea
  • Morning sickness, nausea, vomiting
  • Increased Urination
  • Breast tenderness
  • Increased skin pigmentation
  • Skin striae

The patient may also present with diffuse abdominal pain, cramps, and fatigue. Pregnancy can be detected by detecting b HCG in serum or urine. A serum b HCG rise is detectable by various techniques earlier than in urine, usually as early as 6-9 days after fertilization while urine b HCG is detectable mostly after the date of the missed period or 14 days after fertilization.

Incorrect options

Option A; Hypothyroidism may cause amenorrhea but symptoms of nausea, increased urination, and abdominal mass are more suggestive of pregnancy.

Option B; An ultrasound pelvis would also confirm an intrauterine pregnancy but the first step for diagnosis is the detection of beta HCG.

Option C; Increased frequency may be a symptom of a urinary tract infection and can also cause nausea, lower abdominal pain, but does not explain abdominal mass and amenorrhea.

Educational Objective;

Pregnancy is an important cause of secondary amenorrhea but should also be suspected and ruled out in all cases of primary amenorrhea whether or not a sexual history may be elicited.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal clinic for her first visit at 7 weeks of pregnancy. She has no complaints of pain or spotting per vaginum. She occasionally has nausea but no vomiting. She is able to take her routine diet and is taking folic acid medication. Her ultrasound is suggestive of a gestational sac in the uterus, with a mean sac diameter measuring 30 mm with no yolk sac or fetal pole. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Very early pregnancy requiring follow up

questions.solution:
This is a case of anembryonic non-viable pregnancy (blighted ovum) as the mean sac diameter is greater than 25 mm and there is no yolk sac or fetal pole. A blighted ovum is a fertilized egg that implants but do not develop. In a blighted ovum, a gestational sac forms and grows; however, the embryo does not develop. So blighted ovum is also known as Anembryonic pregnancy. The most common causes are chromosomal anomalies

Blighted Ovum: Criteria Mean sac diameter ≥25 mm No yolk sac/ Embryo seen Avascular Villi Non Viable Pregnancy

Incorrect options

Option A; Ultrasound features in a normal pregnancy appear in the order: gestational sac, yolk sac, fetal pole, and lastly cardiac activity. After the appearance of a gestational sac, one can wait for 2 weeks or sac diameter to reach 25 mm (whichever is earlier) for the yolk sac/ fetal node to appear, before calling it anembryonic. In this case, since the sac diameter is already >25mm, we can call it anembryonic, and follow up is not appropriate Diagnosis of a non-viable pregnancy G-sac ≥ 25 mm size with no Yolk sac or fetal pole CRL ≥ 7 mm with no cardiac activity G-sac is seen but fetal pole or cardiac activity are not seen even after 2 weeks G-sac and yolk sac are seen but fetal pole or cardiac activity are not seen even after 11 days Yolk sac ≥ 7 mm and no fetal pole or cardiac activity seen.

Option C; In an ectopic pregnancy, implantation occurs outside the uterine cavity. It is extrauterine pregnancy that may happen in the Fallopian tube, abdomen, etc. Ectopic gestation is unlikely as there is no adnexal mass or sac.

Option D; Pseudocyesis is the appearance of symptoms of pregnancy in the absence of pregnancy, however in this case there is objective evidence of pregnancy in the form of a gestational sac.

Educational Objective;

The absence of yolk sac or fetal node even after 2 weeks of evidence of a gestational sac or after the sac size crosses 25 mm is called an anembryonic pregnancy or blighted ovum.

questions.text: A 30 year old P1L1 presents to the physician with complains of amenorrhea since her delivery 10 months back and gradual decrease in her breast size. Her menstrual cycles were regular prior to pregnancy. Her pregnancy was spontaneously conceived with a normal antenatal course and vaginal delivery, however she had severe postpartum bleeding which was managed with drugs and multiple blood transfusions. Postpartum, she used formula feed for her baby as the milk never came in. She never resumed her periods and is now also noticing a diminishing breast size. Her urine pregnancy test is negative and pelvic examination is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of lactation failure, amenorrhea and secondary amenorrhea following massive haemorrhage is suggestive of Sheehan’s syndrome.

Pathology

  • Postpartum pituitary gland necrosis causing hypopituitarism
  • Ischaemic necrosis of pituitary due to massive blood loss and hypovolemic shock

Presentation : symptoms of decreased anterior pituitary hormones and less commonly posterior pituitary hormones

  • History of massive obstetric haemorrhage
  • Lactational failure
  • Secondary amenorrhea
  • Loss of pubic and axillary hair
  • Breast atrophy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Hypopigmentation
  • Asthenia and weakness
  • Dry skin
  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Cognitive dysfunction
  • Hypotension, shock, hyponatremia

Investigations

  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones : growth hormone, prolactin, gonadotropins, ACTH, TSH
  • Decreased levels of posterior pituitary hormones (less common) : ADH, MSH
  • MRI pituitary : infarction of pituitary gland

Management

Hormone replacement therapy for pituitary hormones

Incorrect options

Option A;Asherman's syndrome is not an innate condition that refers to have scar tissue in the uterus or in the cervix. This scar tissue will be making the walls of these organs to stick together and reduce the size of the uterus.

Option B; Lactational amenorrhea which is also called postpartum infertility, is the temporary postnatal infertility that will be occurring when a woman is amenorrheic and fully breastfeeding.

Option D;A pituitary adenoma will increase the release of growth hormone in a child which can cause a condition of gigantism. A tumor that suppresses the release of growth hormone can cause the slowing or stopping of a child's growth. The thyroid-stimulating hormone will be playing a role in regulating growth, body temperature, and heart rate.

Educational Objective: Sheehan’s syndrome follows massive obstetric hemorrhage, causing pituitary infarction. It presents variably with symptoms of pituitary hormone deficiency. The most common symptoms are failure of lactation and amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl is brought to the physician by her mother as she has not attained menarche yet. She is not sexually active. Her vitals are stable, height is 150 cms and BMI is 24 kg/m2. Specific examination reveals breast development and presence of pubic and axillary hair, however her vagina appears blind. An ultrasound reveals absent uterus and cervix and a right ovarian simple cyst. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characters ( by estrogen secreted from a normal ovary) and absence of Mullerian duct derivatives like uterus, cervix and vagina. This is suggestive of Mullerian agenesis/ MRKH (Mullerian Rokitansky Kuster-Hauser syndrome). The presence of ovarian cyst is incidental, as ovaries are functional and there may be functional cysts seen.

Primary amenorrhea is defined as absence of menstruation by 13 years in the absence of secondary sexual characteristics or by 15 years in the presence of secondary sexual characteristics.

MRKH (Mullerian agenesis/ Mayer Rokitansky Kuster hauser syndrome)

  • A female genotype (46 XX) with absence of development of mullerian structures such as vagina, cervix, uterus and fallopian tubes
  • Ovary is functioning normally, thus estrogen production is present, hence external sexual characters are feminine with normal breast development, female habitus and pubic and axillary hair.
  • Associated anomalies : renal anomalies, skeletal anomalies, hearing defects
  • Management : to be reared as a female. Vaginoplasty may be done prior to onset of sexual activity An important differential is Androgen insensitivity syndrome
 

MRKH

Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Genotype

XX

XY

Gonad

Ovaries

Testes

Breast development

Normal

Normal

Pubic and axillary hair

Normal

Absent (insensitivity to testosterone)

Vagina

Shallow and blind

Shallow and blind

Uterus

Absent

Absent

Vulva

Normal

Normal

Sr Androgen levels

20-80 ng/dl

200-800 ng/dl

 

Evaluation of primary amenorrhea

(Incorrect options ) : all other options are ruled out as all of them have a normal vagina and uterus. The only other option with absent uterus is androgen insensitivity syndrome (differential already explained)

Educational objective : MRKH or Mullerian agenesis is a normal female(genotype and appearance) with absence of Mullerian duct derivatives : vagina, uterus, cervix and fallopian tubes. Ovarian function is normal.

questions.text: A couple with infertility of 2 years duration, presents to the infertility clinic for evaluation. The woman , 26 years of age, has a history of delayed cycles, coming every 35-45 days, lasting 4-5 days, with no dysmenorrhea. She has no history of thyroid disease. On examination, her BMI is 24 kg/m2, BP is 110/68 mmHg, systemic examination is unremarkable. An ultrasound does not show any significant pathology. A hysterosalpingography done shows bilateral patent tubes. Which of the following is the next best test for evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with infertility has been evaluated for tubal patency and gross pelvic pathology, both of which have been ruled out. The next step is to determine whether this patient is ovulating or not and a semen analysis of the partner. Out of the given options, progesterone levels on day 21 can establish status of ovulation Tests for ovulation : progesterone is secreted by corpus luteum that is formed after ovulation. All these tests, detect progesterone and its effects on various end organs since presence of progesterone suggests that ovulation has taken place. Other tests detect direct evidence of ovulation by demonstrating follicle rupture.

  1. Serum progesterone :a blood test done at D21 or 7 days before expected menses. A value of ≥ 3 ng suggests ovulatory cycle
  2. Endometrial biopsy : demonstrate secretory changes in endometrium after ovulation. The first change observed is subnuclear vacuolation followed by secretory changes in endometrial glands and stromal edema.
  3. TVS - to see follicular rupture on serial monitoring
  4. Urinary LH kit : detects rise in urinary LH prior to ovulation
  5. Diagnostic Laparoscopy : shows follicular fluid in pouch of douglas, presence of corpus luteum
  6. Cervix mucus changes: estrogen in proliferative phase makes cervical mucus copious and stretchable, such that it can be stretched up to 10 cm between two fingers. This effect known as spinnbarkeit, is lost after ovulation due to progesterone, which makes the mucous tack. Another change observed is ferning observed under a microscope in the proliferative phase under estrogen effect, which is also lost after ovulation, under progesterone effect.
  7. Basal body temperature : increases after ovulation by 0.5º F, due to progesterone
  8. Vaginal cytology : vaginal smear microscopy for calculating ratio of parabasal, intermediate and superficial cells. Under effect of progesterone, there is an increase in the number of intermediate cells.

Educational objective : basic infertility evaluation includes testing for tubal patency, testing for ovulation and husband semen analysis. Tests for ovulation include levels of progesterone in the premenstrual phase (day 21), its effects on end organs (endometrium, cervical mucous, vagina and basal body temperature) as well as direct evidence of ovulation (serial ultrasound, laparoscopy).

questions.text: A 27 year old woman, P2L2, presents to her physician for contraceptive advice. Her cycles are regular with normal flow. She is a non smoker, vegetarian and has no significant past medical history. The doctor prescribes her a pack of combined oral contraceptive pills, the woman does not desire any future pregnancies and wishes to know whether the pills can be used for long term. Which of the following is a long term complication that she may have?
questions.solution:
Combined oral contraceptives contain estrogen and progesterone in low doses and are excellent contraceptive choice as they have a very small failure rate when used correctly. All options given are actually non-contraceptive benefits of these pills except for hepatoma.

Non-contraceptive benefits Regulation of menstrual cycle Reduction in dysmenorrhea (40%), menorrhagia (50%) Premenstrual tension syndrome & Mittelschmerz’s syndrome Protection against iron deficiency anemia

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Endometriosis
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Hirsutism & acne
  • Functional ovarian cysts
  • Benign breast disease
  • Osteopenia & postmenopausal osteopathic fractures
  • Autoimmune disorders of thyroid
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Endometrial cancer (50%)
  • Epithelial ovarian tumors (50%)
  • Colorectal

 

Side effects and Complications

  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Breakthrough bleeding
  • Breast heaviness and tenderness
  • Vaginal discharge
  • Headache and migraine
  • Chloasma
  • Weight gain
  • Psychosexual : depression, loss of libido
  • Thromboembolism
  • Breast cancer
  • Cervical cancer
  • Benign liver tumors

Educational objective : amongst tumors, oral contraceptives are preventive for endometrial cancer, ovarian cysts, ovarian cancer and benign breast disease and risk factor for breast cancer, benign liver tumors and cervical cancer.

questions.text: A 32 year old female presents to the infertility clinic for evaluation. She has been married for 4 years and has not used any contraception since but has still not been able to conceive. She has regular menstrual cycles lasting 4 days, occurring every 28-30 days with normal flow. However she complains of lower abdominal cramps starting 2 days prior to her periods and subsiding by the second or third day of her periods and also complains of pain during intercourse. Her husband is a non smoker non alcoholic with no coital dysfunction or significant medical history. On bimanual examination uterus appears normal in size with posterior forniceal tenderness. Her initial pelvic scan shows no significant pelvic pathology and hormonal profile is normal. Which of the following is the most likely working diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient here has primary infertility with regular cycles accompanied with congestive dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. In the absence of obvious pelvic pathology visible on USG, the most likely cause of infertility here is endometriosis.

Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterus, the most common site being the ovaries followed by pelvic peritoneum. The symptoms include pain such as abdominal pain, chronic pelvic pain, spasmodic dysmenorrhea, dyschezia and dyspareunia. Other symptoms include infertility and menstrual abnormalities.

Examination usually reveals a normal size uterus, which may be fixed and retroverted with tenderness in fornices. Diagnosis is made by laparoscopy by direct visualization of dark brown endometriotic implants. Chocolate cysts may be seen in the ovary on USG and CA 125 (non specific) may be mildly raised in some cases.

(Incorrect Option A) Anovulation is accompanied by delayed cycles due to lack of adequate progesterone in secretory phase to cause a timely withdrawal. Most common cause of anovulation is PCOS. Hormonal profile would also be disturbed depending upon cause of anovulation

(Incorrect Option B) Fibroid uterus are common in this age group, however are more likely to present with menstrual disturbances like menorrhagia or polymenorrhea. A normal USG here also rules out uterine fibroid.

(Incorrect Option D) Pelvic congestion syndrome can also presents with congestive dysmenorrhea, however is a much rarer cause of infertility. Usual presentation is a chronic type of pelvic pain and is more common in multiparous women.

Educational objective : Endometriosis is the most important cause of infertility to be ruled out in young patients of infertility presenting with dysmenorrhea, pelvic pain and dyspareunia in the setting of regular cycles and absence of obvious pelvic pathology.

questions.text: A 26 year old female presents to the infertility clinic for inability to conceive for the past 2 years. She is nulliparous, married for 3 years and has not been using contraception for the past two years. Her menstrual cycles are delayed, coming at intervals of 40-50 days, lasting 5 days with average flow and not associated with any dysmenorrhea. She has been taking treatment for acne since a year and has no other significant past history. Her husband is a non-smoker, healthy male of 28 years age, with no significant past history. On examination, her BMI is 30 kg/m2, BP is 120/70mmHg, chest, CVS , abdomen and pelvic examination are unremarkable. USG suggests B/L ovaries with multiple small cysts. Which of the following drugs is used in next line of management of this patient ?
questions.solution:
This is a case of primary infertility due to anovulation secondary to PCOS (delayed cycles, features of hyperandrogenism, polycystic ovarian morphology on USG). The first line of treatment is ovulation induction which can be achieved by ovulation inducing drugs like clomiphene citrate or letrozole.

Drugs for inducing ovulation in PCOS

  • Clomiphene citrate : antiestrogenic. Reduces negative feedback inhibition on hypothalamus, induces release of LH and FSH, induces folliculogenesis and ovulation. Starting dose is 25 mg once a day, usually from day 2 to day 6 of cycle and increased in subsequent cycles. · Letrozole : it is an aromatase inhibitor that decreases estrogen production. This reduces negative feedback on hypothalamus and pituitary to increase release of LH and FSH inducing folliculogenesis and ovulation. Starting dose is 2.5 mg for 5 days. This has a lesser chance of multiple pregnancy and ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome compared to clomiphene.
  • Metformin : reduces insulin resistance by sensitizing insulin receptors, used as an adjunct to clomiphene for ovulation induction
  • Inj. FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone)
  • Inj. HMG (Human Menopausal Gonadotropin
  • Inj. HCG
  • GnRH agonists and antagonists

Other therapies used in PCOD (for cycle regularization and hyperandrogenism)

  • Irregular periods/Amenorrhea Rx
    • Combined OC pills
    • Progesterone ( For 10 days - from 14th day/ mid cycle)
  • Hirsutism Rx
    • Anti Androgens spironolactone, finasteride:
    • OC pills containing progesterone with anti androgenic action: cyproterone, drosperinone
    • Cosmetic Rx for excessive facial hair
  • Diet, weight loss, regular exercise : prevention of metabolic complications of PCOS

Educational Objective ; anovulation is the basic cause of infertility in patients of PCOD. Management is done by using ovulation inducing drugs like clomiphene citrate, letrozole and metformin. Other drugs used for ovulation induction are inj. FSH, HMG, HCG, GnRH agonists and antagonists.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with seizures. She reports that the patient has previously had seizures a few times per year since he was 12 months of age. His birth history shows, he was a term infant born to a 28 year old mother with no preexisting medical problems. Labor and delivery was notable for a tight nuchal cord. The infant was delivered vaginally. The infant had no respiratory distress and fed adequately overnight. Early in the morning on the second day of life, she has a 30 seconds seizure. He is taken to the nursery and oxygen is administered. An IV is started and a loading dose of phenobarbital is given. She is then transferred to the NICU. On physical exam, No dysmorphic features are evident. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Heart rate is regular without murmurs. Abdomen is with normal umbilicus, no masses, no hepatosplenomegaly and normal genitalia. Extremities are well perfused with good pulses. The patient’s past medical history is otherwise notable for intellectual disability. He rolled over at 14 months of age and walked at 24 months of age. The patient’s mother denies any family history of epilepsy or other neurologic diseases. The patient is in the 3rd percentile for height and the 15th percentile for weight. The patient has strabismus and an ataxic gait accompanied by flapping of the hands. He responds intermittently to questions with one-word answers. This patient is most likely to have which of the following genetic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with a happy demeanor, ataxic gait, hand flapping, intellectual disability, delayed motor milestones, short stature, and seizures, which suggests a diagnosis of Angelman syndrome. Angelman syndrome may be caused by paternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15, in which both copies of the chromosome are inherited from the father.

Angelman syndrome is caused by absence of the maternal chromosome 15q11-13, which can be caused by paternal uniparentaldisomy, chromosomal deletions, or imprinting center defects.

Angelman syndrome (AS) is characterized by severe developmental delay or intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, gait ataxia and/or tremulousness of the limbs, and a unique behavior with an inappropriate happy demeanor that includes frequent laughing, smiling, and excitability. Microcephaly and seizures are also common.. A majority of affected patients also present with seizures.

Incorrect Answers:

Answer 1:The most common features of Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome include macrosomia (large body size),macroglossia(large tongue), abdominal wall defects, an increased risk for childhood tumors, kidney abnormalities,hypoglycemia(low blood sugar) in the newborn period, and unusual ear creases or pits.

Answer 2: A chromosomal macrodeletion on chromosome 5 causes cri-du-chat syndrome. The clinical symptoms of cri du chat syndrome usually include a high-pitched cat-like cry, mental retardation, delayed development, distinctive facial features, small head size (microcephaly), widely-spacedeyes(hypertelorism),low birth weightand weakmuscle tone(hypotonia) in infancy.

Answer 3: Maternal uniparental disomy of chromosome 15 causes Prader-Willi syndrome.The most common symptoms of Prader-Willi syndrome are behavioural problems, intellectual disability and short stature.

LEARNING OBJECTIVES

Angelman syndrome (AS) is characterized by severe developmental delay or intellectual disability, severe speech impairment, gait ataxia and/or tremulousness of the limbs, and a unique behavior with an inappropriate happy demeanor that includes frequent laughing, smiling, and excitability. Microcephaly and seizures are also common. A majority of affected patients also present with seizures.

questions.text: Lakshmi is a 2 year old child brought to the pediatricians office by her parents who noted her to be pale. Past medical History showed no fever, nausea, emesis, bone pain or other complaints. Her physical examination is significant for pallor, tachycardia, and a systolic ejection murmur, but there was no signs of organomegaly. A complete blood count (CBC) was ordered which showed the following results: hemoglobin of 4 g/dL, normal indices for age, a WBC count of 6.5/μL, and a platelet count of 750,000/μL. Her reticulocyte count is 0%. Coombs test was negative. Peripheral blood smear showed no blast forms and no fragments. Red blood cell (RBC) adenosine deaminase levels are normal. A bone marrow shows decreased erythroid precursors. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child's clinical and laboratory results indicate a diagnosis of transient erythroblastopenia of childhood (TEC), which is the most common acquired RBC aplasia in children. This condition is usually diagnosed between the ages of 1 to 3 years and some affected children have a history of a recent viral infection; But, no specific virus has been indicated as the etiology (parvovirus B19 is usually specifically excluded).Physical findings are minimal including pallor and tachycardia. Laboratory studies show a profound anemia and reticulocytopenia with a marked reduction in erythrocyte precursors in the marrow. RBC adenosine deaminase (ADA) levels are normal. This condition lasts for several months, and may require 1 or 2 transfusions, but ultimately is self-limited. Steroids are not of much help.

CHOICE A : Iron deficiency causes a microscopic hypochromic anemia.

CHOICE C: Pearson marrow-pancreas is another form of congenital hypoplastic anemia, which includes poor growth, pancreatic fibrosis with insulin-dependent diabetes, and muscle and nerve involvement. Early death is usual.

CHOICE D: Alternative diagnoses include Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA), but this condition is congenital and usually exhibit in infancy; RBC ADA levels are usually elevated. In addition, about half of patients with DBA have congenital anomalies which includes short stature, cranial abnormalities, and upper extremity abnormalities.

EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVE:

This child's clinical and laboratory results indicate a diagnosis of transient erythroblastopenia of childhood (TEC), which is the most common acquired RBC aplasia in children. This condition is usually diagnosed between the ages of 1 to 3 years and some affected children have a history of a recent viral infection

questions.text: If one parent is normal and the other is a carrier and the child is also affected in an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder, what could be the possible reason for this?
questions.solution:
If one parent is normal for an autosomal recessive disorder and the other is carrier → No child should be affected.

But there is exception to this rule when there is uniparental disomy (UPD) where a person recieves 2 copies of a chromosome from one parent and no copy from the other parent.

Examples:

In Prader-Willi syndrome → maternal UPD of chromosome 15 (missing the paternal chromosome 15).

In Angelman syndrome → paternal UPD of chromosome 15 (missing the maternal chromosome 15).

In genomic imprinting → Phenotypic gene expression depends on the parent of origin of the chromosomes

Imprinting disorders may arise from UPD, deletions or duplications, epigenetic modification of gene like methylation of DNA, or point mutations in a specific gene.

Whether the genetic material is expressed or not depends on the sex of the parent from whom it was derived.

Example: Prader-Willi syndrome and Angelman syndrome. These syndromes are usually associated with deletion of the same
region in the proximal long arm of chromosome 15. A deletion on the paternally derived chromosome causes Prader-Willi syndrome, in which the maternally derived copy is still intact but some of the imprinted genes within this region normally remain silent. In contrast, a maternal deletion of the same region causes Angelman syndrome, leaving intact the paternal copy that has genes that are also normally silent.

Germline Mosaicism (gonadal mosaicism):

Occurs due to mutations that occur after the formation of zygote.

Affects only the cells destined to form gonads

Suspected when more than 1 children are affected with an AD disease but the parents are phenotypically normal.

Penetrance:

Refers to the proportion of people with a particular genetic change who exhibit signs and symptoms of a genetic disorder.

If some people with the mutation do not develop features of the disorder, the condition is said to have reduced (or incomplete) penetrance.

questions.text: Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by a loss of function of specific genes on chromosome 15. In newborns, symptoms include weak muscles, poor feeding, and slow development. Beginning in childhood, those affected become constantly hungry, which often leads to obesity and type 2 diabetes. Mild to moderate intellectual impairment and behavioral problems. Which of the following hormones are raised in this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Prader-Willi syndrome:

Due to silencing of paternal copy of UBE 3A gene on chr 15

C/F- obesity- ↑ Ghrelin

Short stature

Intellectual disability

Hypotonia

Hypogonadism

questions.text: A 1.5-year-old child was brought to the OPD by her mother after she began to notice that the child is not able to digest any of the dairy products she fed him with. She noticed that the symptoms usually begin from 30 minutes to two hours after eating or drinking foods that contain lactose. Common signs and symptoms include Diarrhea, vomiting. All are seen in lactose intolerance EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Lactose intolerance:

Due to Brush-border lactase enzyme deficiency

Reducing substances positive in stools

Explosive stools

Acidic stools

Perianal excoriation

questions.text: After the massive tsunami, lakhs of people were left homeless and had many injuries while saving themselves or others. After few days when the scenario was quite better than before, stranded people were moved to safer places and immediately sent to hospitals on the basis of triage. Mass vaccination for communicable diseases was carried out to provide herd immunity. Which vaccine given was not effective in providing herd immunity?
questions.solution:
Herd Immunity:

Reduction of infection/disease in unimmunized segment as a result of immunizing a proportion of population.

It is d/t reduced carriage of the causative microorganism by the vaccinated cohort

Thus, seen only with vaccines against those diseases where humans are the only source

An effective vaccine is prerequisite for good herd effect. e.g. conjugated pneumococcal vaccine

Tetanus & BCG vaccines have no herd effect. So, mass vaccination is ineffective.

questions.text: Areola and papilla forming secondary mound in adolescent girls is classified under which stage of sexual maturity rating (SMR)?
questions.solution:
SMR 1 - Prepubertal; no terminal hair

SMR 2 - Appearance of breast bud; Sparse straight hair along the labia

SMR 3 - Generalized breast enlargement (extending beyond the areola); Pigmented pubic hair, coarse, begin to curl

SMR 4 - Nipple and areola form secondary mound over the breast; Hair increase in amount, spread over entire mons

SMR 5 - Mature adult type breast; nipple projects and areola recedes; Adult type pubic hair in triangle-shaped area spreading overto medial thighs

questions.text: A three day-old term infant born at home, breast-fed exclusively, presented with lethargy, bulging fontanel, and bright red blood from rectum. What is the most likely etiology of his disease?
questions.solution:
Vit K deficiency is associated with hemorrhagic disease of newborn which has manifested in this baby as Intracranial hemorrhage (bulging fontanel) and GI bleed (blood per rectum).

Moreover, home delivery (Vit K may not have been given at birth) and exclusive breastfeeding (Vit K is deficient in breast milk) clearly point to Vit K deficiency as etiology.

Calcium deficiency: Tetany, rickets, and osteoporosis

Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency anemia is associated with impaired performance in mental and physical functions including physical coordination and capacity, cognitive abilities, and social and emotional development

Fluoride deficiency - Dental caries, osteoporosis

questions.text: A 17 yrs old boy presented with sudden onset of severe throbbing pain in his right ear following an upper respiratory tract infection. He also gives a history of bloodstained discharge couple of hours later along with hearing impairment in the affected ear. Following is the otoscopy findings of the patient. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Bullous myringitis (BM) is an acute inflammatory condition affecting the tympanic membrane (TM) characterized by the presence of bullae or vesicles on the surface of the TM. The bullae may be single or multiple, may affect segment or the whole of the TM and may even spread onto the adjacent ear canal.Diagnosis of this condition is clinical. Typically, patients present with sudden-onset severe otalgia, usually unilateral and often in association with an upper respiratory tract infection.

Otoscopy reveals bullae on the TM. Rupture of the bulla may be associated with scanty serosanguinous otorrhoea, which is usuallyshort-lived due to the absence of a TM perforation.

questions.text: Most common cause of Lower motor neuron facial palsy is
questions.solution:
BELL’S PALSY:

  • Sixty to seventy-five per cent of facial paralysis is due to Bell palsy.
  • It is defined as idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis orparesis of acute onset.
  • Both sexes are affected with equal frequency
  • Any age group may be affected though incidence rises with increasing age.
  • A positive family history is present in 6–8% of patients.

Risk of Bell palsy is more in diabetics (angiopathy) & pregnant women (retention of fluid).

questions.text: 45 years old chronic smoker came to your clinic with complaints of hoarseness and foreign body sensation in the larynx. Laryngoscopy revealed the features depicted in the below image. Which of the following sites will be the most common site of distant metastasis?
questions.solution:
• Most common site of locoregional metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is Lymph nodes.
  • Most common site of distant metastasis from laryngeal carcinoma is Lung.
  • Most common site of laryngeal carcinoma is Glottic carcinoma.
  • Most common type of laryngeal carcinoma is Squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown below & its application.

choices.text: Indirect laryngoscopy, differentiate malignant from benign lesion
Laryngeal videostroboscopy, gives additional information about the vibratory pattern of the vocal fold mucosa
Vocobronchoscopy, identifying mobility of vocal cord

questions.solution: Video Stroboscopy : A stroboscope is a device which emits light in pulses, the frequency of which can be set by the examiner. If frequency of pulses is same at which vocal cords are moving, the latter appear stationary giving more time to study the cord. If frequency of pulses is more or less than that of vocal cord movements, the cords are seen in slow motion. Stroboscopes are synchronized with rigid or fibre optic endoscopes and the vocal cord movements can be recorded on video (video stroboscopy). Stroboscopy has been found very useful in diagnosis of laryngeal paralysis, completeness of glottis closure during phonation, very small early laryngeal cancer, vocal cord scarring, laryngeal cyst versus polyp and sulcus vocalis.

questions.text: 10 years old boy came to your clinic with severe throat pain. On examination, you diagnosed it as Tonsillitis. You planned for a Tonsillectomy procedure and during that procedure, the patient developed bleeding intraoperatively. Which of the following is the source of bleeding in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The most common site of haemorrhage during tonsillectomy is venous from the external palatine vein i.e. the paratonsillar vein.

MORBIDITIES ASSOCIATED WITH TONSILLECTOMY-

Pain
Significant morbidity is associated with tonsillectomy.
Post-tonsillectomy sore throat is normal for at least 1 week

Bleeding
Bleeding after tonsillectomy can be primary (within 24 hours after the operation) or secondary (after 24 hours until 2 weeks).

The most likely explanation for secondary bleeding is infection with Streptococcus in the granulating tonsil bed. Treatment depends on the severity and potential cause of the bleed. Antibiotics are advised for secondary bleeding. Severe primary or secondary bleeds need to be controlled in the theatre.

Infection
The first symptoms of post-tonsillectomy infection are fever and halitosis. Treatment should be administered according to the severity

Peri-operative complications
If the mouth is opened too widely during the tonsillectomy operation, the patient may experience temporomandibular joint dysfunction. Dissection beyond pharyngeal musculature can lead to injury to the glossopharyngeal nerve and rarely the carotid sheath. Non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (Grisel syndrome) can occur secondary to any inflammatory process in the neck.

questions.text: A 75 year old retired police officer came to your OPD with a history of odynophagia and dysphagia. When you examined him, you noticed that there is a unilateral bulging of the posterior pharyngeal wall. Xray reveals the below-depicted image. The space involved in this condition is?
questions.solution:
• The above mentioned clinical condition is Retropharyngeal abscess
  • It is due to infection of the retropharyngeal lymph node
  • X-ray neck - shows a widening of prevertebral shadow
  • Rx-Incision & Drainage + antibiotics
  • The retropharyngeal space is divided by a midline fibrous raphe into two spaces known as the space of Gillette.
  • PARAPHARYNGEAL SPACE-
    • It is an inverted pyramid-shaped space, extending from the petrous temporal bone superiorly to the level of the hyoid.
    • The space is bounded by the superior constrictor muscle medially and the pterygoid muscles, the parotid salivary gland, and the mandible laterally.
    • The styloid process and its attachments pass-through space, dividing it into pre-styloid and post-styloid compartments
  • RETROPHARYNGEAL SPACE-
    • Between the two parapharyngeal spaces is the retropharyngeal space which is continuous with both.
    • The superior limit of the retropharyngeal space is the skull base and it is continuous inferiorly with the posterior mediastinum, down to the level of the carina.
    • The anterior boundary in the neck is the buccopharyngeal fascia which encases the pharyngeal constrictors, the posterior limit is the alar fascial component of the prevertebral fascia.
    • The only contents of this space are the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which typically regress by adulthood but can represent a route of metastatic nodal spread from the midline or posterior tumors of the pharynx.
  • PERITONSILLAR SPACE-
    • The potential space between the palatine tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle is known as the peritonsillar
      space.

The condensation of the pharyngobasillar which forms the tonsillar capsule may be breached by bacterial infections of the tonsil, resulting in abscess formation in the peritonsillar space, also known as quinsy. Untreated peritonsillar infections may spread to involve the parapharyngeal space.

questions.text: A patient developed bilateral nasal obstruction and fever with chills after septal surgery. On anterior rhinoscopy a smooth fluctuant swelling is noted on both sides of septum. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Smooth fluctuant swelling, History of fever with chills – Points towards Septal abscess

SEPTAL ABSCESS:

ETIOLOGY:

  • Mostly, it results from secondary infection of septal haematoma.
  • Follows furuncle of the nose or upper lip.
  • May also follow acute infection such as typhoid or measles.

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • Severe bilateral nasal obstruction with pain and tenderness over bridge of nose.
  • Patient may also complain of fever with chills and frontal headache.
  • Skin over the nose may be red and swollen.
  • Internal examination of nose reveals smooth bilateral swelling of nasal septum
  • Fluctuation can be elicited in this swelling.
  • Septal mucosa is often congested. Submandibular lymph nodes may also be enlarged and tender.

TREATMENT:

  • Systemic antibiotic therapy

Drainage of abscess

questions.text: Which of the following is the sign for pink reflex through tympanic membrane seen in active otosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ø Option A: Schwartz sign: In Otosclerosis reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through tympanic membrane.This is indicative of active focus with increased vascularity. Usually seen in pregnancy.

Ø Option B: Schwabach’s Test: It is typical test to depict sensorineural hearing loss in a patient

Ø Option C: Lyre’s sign: Splaying of ICA &ECA seen in Carotid body tumor neck on angiogram

Ø Option D: Chvostek’s sign: Tapping over distribution of facial nerve causes twitch-Hypocalcemia

questions.text: A 12 year old boy is brought to the clinic due to eye redness and discharge. He had a sore throat for 7 days and right eye redness for 2 days.Yesterday his father used a moisture to open the his both crusted eyelids and then left eye also became red. The boy has no eye pain, visual changes or itching. No one in his family has similar symptoms. Temperature is 37.4 °C. Physical examination reveals mild infection and granular appearance of the tarsal conjunctiva with ptosis, and clear mucus discharge in both eyes, mild rhinorrhea and pharyngeal erythema. The most appropriate management of this patient is.
questions.solution:
This patient is having typical features of Viral conjunctivitis( pink eye), most commonly caused by adenovirus. Mostly seen in the late summer season, it last for several days and are self limited. Some cases can develop a secondary bacterial infection (bacterial superinfection) with more severe pain and grossly purulent exudate.

 

Conjunctivitis treatment

Bacterial Conjunctivitis

  • Erythromycin ointment
  • Polymyxin-trimethorpim drops
  • Azithromycin drops
  • Preferred agent in contact lens wearers: fluoroquinolone drops

Viral Conjunctivitis
  • Warm or cold compresses
  • +/- Antihistamine/decongestant drops

Allergic Conjunctivitis

  • Over – the – counter antihistamine/decongestant drops for intermittent symptoms
  • Mast cell stabilizer/antistamine drops for frequent episodes

 

 

Incorrect options

Option a: Oral valacyclovir is recommended for treatment of herpes simplex keratitis. Itis an antiviral drug. It has the ability to slow down the process of growth and spread of the herpes virus for helping the body to fight against the infection. Valacyclovir is used to treat infections which are caused by herpes viruses, including genital herpes, cold sores, and shingles mainly in adults.

Option b: Erythromycin ophthalmic ointments are recommended for treatment of purulent bacterial conjunctivitis.

Option c: Olopatadine eyedrops are recommended for the treatment of allergic conjunctivitis. This medication is anantihistamine which is used for treating the itching and redness in the eyes caused by the allergies. This medication cannot be recommended for the treatment of eye irritation which is caused due to wearing of contact lenses.

Educational objective:

Viral conjunctivitis is the most common cause of conjunctivitis in school aged children. Presentation includes eye redness and mild watery or mucus discharge, associated with upper respiratory tract symptoms.

questions.text: A 84 year old woman was referred from a tertiary ophthalmology centre with complaint of double vision. Her past medical history include hypertension and Alzheimer's disease. She is not a diabetic. On neurological assessment, she was alert but not orientated to time and place due to her dementia. Upon examination, Light into her right eye causes constriction of her pupil, but not the left pupil. Light shone in her left eye causes construction of only her right pupil. There was no cutaneous lesion on her face in the distribution of the V1 dermatome. Which of the following additional examination findings is likely seen in this patient ?

choices.text: Inability to close the left eye
Visual loss in the left eye

questions.solution:
This patient's lesion most likely involves her left CN III.

The pupillary response to light is a pure reflex with an entirely subcortical pathway. Light shone into the right eye produces a direct response in the right eye and a consensual response in the left eye. The optic nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex, the oculomotor nerve is responsible for the efferent limb. The intensity of the response in each eye is proportionate to the light-carrying ability of the directly stimulated optic nerve.

Incorrect Options :

Option a: Lesion involving the left CN VII, result in inability to close the left eye.

Option b: Absence of corneal reflex, result from lesions involving afferent limb of CN V1/ efferent limb of CN VII.

Option c: The left CNII is functional, as it produced a consensual response in the right eye.

Educational objective:

The pupillary light reflex is assessed by shining light in an eye and observing the direct response, and in the opposite eye for the consensual response. The optic nerve is responsible for the afferent limb of this reflex, the oculomotor nerve is responsible for the efferent limb.

questions.text:
20-year-old male presented with a chief complaint of a 3-4 day history of right eyelid swelling, pain, and redness.The patient denied any trauma, discharge, or change in vision, and reported no systemic symptoms or other complaints.

On examination, the lower eyelid of the right eye was erythematous and swollen, as well as warm and tender to palpation. There is no conjunctival infection. Visual acuity is normal and the left eye appears unremarkable. The initial management of these patients current condition is.
questions.solution:
This patient has an external hordeolum(stye), an acute staphylococcal abscess of a lash follicle and its associated gland of Zeis. It presents as an erythematous, tender nodule at the lid margin. Within a few days, a minute pustule may appear at the lid margin, which will then rupture with discharge of pus and relief of pain. Warm compresses are advised to accelerate this process.

Incorrect Options :

Option b: Topical ganciclovir is used in the treatment of Viral keratitis, infection of cornea due to herpes simplex or varicella zoster virus. Patients have corneal vesicles opacification and/ or dendritic ulcers

Option c: For patients with a persistent hordeolum or a large chalazion, an additional management of incision and curettage is done.

Option d: Erythromycin ointment is used for treatment of bacterial conjunctivitis and in prevention of ophthalmia neonatorum.

Educational objective:

External hordeolum(stye), is acute staphylococcal abscess of a lash follicle and its associated gland of Zeis. Warm compresses are advised, to accelerate discharge of pus and relief of pain.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man presents to your OPD as he noticed his vision progressively worsening throughout the years. He finds mild blurring while reading or looking at his watch. He now has to put items at an arm length in order to see the image clearer. He denies any trouble seeing objects at far distances. He has no history of eye problems. Which of the following is most likely abnormal?
questions.solution:
The loss of accommodation that comes with aging to all people is called presbyopia. The loss of elasticity in the lens prohibits accommodation of the lens, that is required to focus on near objects. The poor near vision can be easily improved with reading glasses.

Incorrect Options :

Option a: Disease located in the peripheral retina is usually secondary to diabetes, and leads to proliferative or non-proliferative retinopathy.

Option c: Age - related macular degeneration is associated with central visual field loss in patients over the age of 50.

Option d: A non-sperical cornea leads to astigmatism, which presents with blurry vision both at near and distance.

Educational objective:

Presbyopia results from decrease in lens elasticity that leads to difficulty with near vision. The individuals presence with a tendency to hold items at an arm length to see the it clearly.

questions.text: A 65 year old man presents to the primary care physician complaining of bilateral visual difficulty. Over the past one year he has felt increasingly depressed and anxious regarding his progressive localised loss of vision.On physical examination, his vital signs are within normal limits and he appears generally well. Neurological examination shows a subtle resting tremor and increased tonicity. An ophthalmologic examination is significant for small yellow retinal lesions clustered in the macula. Which of the following can be expected on visual field examination?
questions.solution:
Macula is yellowish spot, approximately 1.5 mm in diameter located near the centre of the retina. Histologically comprises of densely packed cones, few overlying cells and no blood vessels. The visual acuity in the macula and fovea is greater than in any other area of the retina.

Scotoma refers to any visual defect resulting in a discreet area of altered vision surrounded by zones of normal vision. It occurs due to pathologic process that involve parts of the retina or optic nerve.

This patient is likely to have macular degeneration. This disorder is frequently seen in >50 years old, and is the most common cause of blindness in US. Macular degeneration is characterized by progressive loss of central vision due to; Dry MD (deposition of fatty tissue behind the retina), Wet MD(neovascularization of the retina).

Option a: Binasal hemianopsia is due to pressure on lateral area of the optic chiasm, resulting in loss of vision in the nasal fields of both eyes.

Option b: Homonyms hemianopsia is due to transaction of the contralateral optic tract, the fibres linking the optic chiasm to the lateral geniculate body, resulting in loss of vision in the same side of the visual field in both eyes

Option d: Arcuate scotoma is due to damage to a particular region of the optic nerve head, resulting in arcuate shape of the nerve fibre pattern visual field.

Educational objective Scotoma is a visual field defect surrounded by a relatively unimpaired field of vision , that occurs due to a pathological process that involves parts of the retina or the optic nerve. Macular lesions cause Central scotoma.

questions.text:
A 1 year old girl is brought to the hospital for a routine visit. She was born at 35 weeks of gestation, due to preterm labour. The child takes no meditation and has no known allergies. Immunization chart is up to date.




Ophthalmoscopic examination reveals a red reflex in the left eye and white reflex in the right. Extra ocular movements are intact, and pupils are equal and reactive to light. Total retinal detachment is seen in the same eye. Corneal light reflex is symmetric. Ultrasound B scan reveals hematogenous subretinal mass with calcification. The most likely cause of the patients examination finding is
questions.solution:
This child has leukocoria(or white pupillary reflex), concerning for the most common intraocular tumor of children retinoblastoma, which occurs due to in the activation of the tumor suppressor gene RB 1. Sporadic retinoblastoma often presents as unilateral disease, whereas Inheritable retinoblastoma is more commonly bilateral.

Retinoblastoma is most commonly diagnosed in children age < 2. Immediate ophthalmology reference is required for treatment, to avoid metastasis to the contralateral eye and the brain, diagnosis is confirmed with MRI of the brain and orbits.

Choice a: Associated retinal detachment can cause leukocoria, but ROP typically affects infant born at < 30 weeks gestation.

Choice c: Uveitis is intraocular inflammation often associated with systemic disease ( eg: infection, juvenile idiopathic arthritis) examination can reveal leukocoria due to inflammatory debris, but eye redness and pain are also expected.

Choice d: strabismus or ocular misalignment can cause an asymmetric red reflex with increase in density in the deviated eye however the corneal light reflex will also be asymmetric not seen in this patient.

Educational objectives: Leukocoria , or white pupillary reflex in an infant or young child should require immediate ophthalmology referral to evaluate for retinoblastoma. Other presenting signs of retinoblastoma include strabismus and nystagmus.

questions.text: A 65 year old male who is the security guard in your hospital comes to the emergency department because of a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye . Five hours ago his experienced a transient loss of vision in the same eye which lasted for 5 minutes . He has hypertension, diabetes, hypercholesterolemia and peripheral vascular disease. He had acute myocardial infarction 6 years ago. His temperature is 36.7°C, RR 16 per minute, pulse is 88 per minute and BP is 146/88 mmHg. On examination visual acuity poor and anterior segment is normal. Fundoscopic examination reveals pale retina and bright red fovea. Suggest most appropriate method of treatment for this patient.

choices.text: Occular massage and high flow oxygen

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis cerebral retinal artery occlusion(CRAO) secondary to embolism. Sudden painless loss of vision is the presenting symptom. Risk factors include giant cell arteritis, hypertension, age >65 years, etc. It occurs when a severe abrupt diminution of blood flow through the central retinal artery causes ischaemia of the inner. Visual acuity is typically 20 / 800 or worse. Fundoscopy reveals diffuse steaming retinal whitening and cherry red spots. Immediate intervention includes ocular massage to improve retinal perfusion. Medical management and anterior chamber paracentesis to lower IOP.

Option a: CRAO is an ophthalmologic emergency, delay may result in permanent loss of vision.

Option b: Intravenous steroids are used in the management of vision loss associated with temporal arteritis.

Option d: Thrombolytics may be useful if initiated within 4 to 6 hours of visual loss but they are administered intra-arterially.

Educational objective : Central retinal artery occlusion is an ocular emergency treatment aiming to improve vascular supply(vasodilation) and sudden lowering of IOP.

questions.text: A 70-year-old lady  came to the emergency department complaining of extreme pain in her right eye and blurred vision. The pain began suddenly that morning while she was doing household chores and got progressively worse during her drive to the hospital. She vomited once and reports continued nausea.Her eye is hard and red; with hazy cornea; shallow anterior chamber and the pupil is 6 mm dilated and reacts poorly to light.Visual acuity is 20/200 in the right eye and 20/30 in the left. Likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Angle closed glaucoma is an optic neuropathy due to closure of narrow anterior chamber angle that prevents adequate drainage of the aqueous humor from the eye and leads to elevated intraocular pressure .This is a medical emergency that must be attended within 24 hours to prevent blindness.

Option a: Uveitis presents with moderate pain, blurred vision, corneal haze,keratic precipitate. the pupil is constructed with a poor light reflex.

Option c: open angle glaucoma has a slow painless loss of peripheral vision with characteristic features of increased intraocular pressure and cupping of the optic disc.

Option d: Patient usually complaint of blurred vision problem and glare.

Educational objective: Angle closure glaucoma occurs usually in hypermetropic female > 45 years with sudden painful loss of vision, coloured halos, corneal edema.
